description: My favorite sushi spot in SF! A real hidden, hole in the wall type place. The omakase was a good deal with fresh fish, but next time would definitely just pick and choose. The unagi was especially melt in your mouth. Definitely get reservations if you can as it can get packed since there are only 6 or so tables.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Charming little place with exceptionally fresh fish. Very reminiscent of Japan.

As others have noted they generally only sell what is fresh so not everything is available all the time. Take your cue from the Chef. The night we were there the hamachi was unworldly. 

You should call ahead for reservations even on the same day. They will work hard to fit you in. We found earlier dining is better, really no surprise. Also, note the place is cash only.

Minus 1 point for technical reasons. I found the tomago a bit disappointing and sometimes the brushed on sauces destroyed the structural integrity of the underlying rice.

But these are minor quibbles and I have found my new go to sushi restaurant.
author: E F.

description:
This is the best hidden gem I've found in San Francisco.

We came at 6pm on a Saturday. The sushi bar was full and the only other two tables had reserved signs on them. Luckily, they still accommodated us without a wait by seating us at the smaller table.

We ordered two sets of omakase. It was fresh and tasted delicious. The rice was seasoned so well and complemented the sashimi. Our favorite was the amberjack and hamachi. I'm not the biggest fan of hamachi, but this melted in my mouth and was so memorable.

I'm honestly surprised that this place doesn't have a huge line out the door. There's only one sushi chef and waitress but the service was still above and beyond. It felt like I was in a Mom and pop sushi shop in an hidden alleyway at Japan.

Also, the price surprised the hell out of me. Our two sets of omakase and tekka maki only came out to $45. What a steal, I'm in love with this place.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Sushi sushi sushi... my fav! Let's start by saying I've been here a couple of times in the past which this place has never disappoint. It's a very small place  that has about 15 seatings. It's always pack per reservations but the owners always try to accommodate as much as they can especially for walk in customers. They only open 3 times a week (thurs-sat). Even though they open at 5:30pm you can still call at 2p-3pm for day of reservations or future reservations. Mom and pop store. Chef reminds me of Jiro (documentary movie of the top sushi chef located in Japan). 

Sushi is very good and fresh. He picks up fresh fish of the day so fish options are very very limited. The price is very reasonable/affordable. The only flaw is the fish options are very very limited- yes I know I just said lol. They don't make other stuff like udon, donburi, etc. They mostly serve sushi, sashimi and small selections of rolls. If your ok with limited good sushi at a good price than this place is for you. Not: best to make reservations. 

Overall... I still love this place and will be coming back. 4 star.
author: Christy V.

description: I've been living in this area for 2yrs and regularly come here now. Amazing omakase at a fraction of the price you'd pay elsewhere in a relaxed environment :)
author: James L.

description:
We walked in on the earlier side. We were the only table with a couple sitting at the sushi bar. Service started out good but dropped once the dinner crowd arrived.

We ordered 2 omakase dinners, a couple extra nigiri, and a large bottle of Asahi. Our daughter had tobiko, avocado rolls, and tuna. The omakase is 6 or 7 simple, fresh nigiri.

Overall is very good. Friendly mom and pop restaurant and they do not serve trendy mayo stuffed rolls (a big plus).

Total bill with tax and tip was $100. Overall, a great value. I'd be happy if this was my neighborhood sushi spot but wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.

Bring cash. There's an ATM next door in Arguello Market if needed.
author: Zoran L.

description:
This is it. My #1, most favorite, bestest sushi/Japanese restaurant in SF, both in terms of taste and value. Okina wins by a long shot. This place is truly deserving of 5 stars.  

They serve very fresh fish, almost all of it in the form of nigiris. Very simple, traditional, nothing fancy. If you're looking for crazy sushi rolls (aka not-authentic-Japanese food), you best look elsewhere. Food is served to you authentic Japanese sushi bar style - meaning, if you sit at the bar (which you should), the chef serves the nigiris to you right on the counter. 

There are Japanese sushi restaurants that are comparable in taste (off the top of my head, Akikko's, Sushi Ran, Omakase, Wako, Kusakabe...), and they're fancier both in terms of atmosphere and preparation, but at those places, you'll only be getting something marginally more exotic for double to quadruple the price. Not at all worth it, in my opinion. 

The prices at Okina are unbeatable. Omakase is roughly only $25. Nigiris are around $4-5 per set. You won't find prices like this with the utmost freshness anywhere in SF. Okina is a steal. 

Atmosphere is great too. It's very quite, small, and intimate. 

This place is by all means, reservations only. You can call the same day, but it's almost impossible to do a walk-in. It's cash only.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Came in on Friday night right before close. Called ahead to ensure there was room because this place is TINY. But luckily I live really close to super easy for me to swing by.

Okina's super small and intimate. We sat at the sushi bar and started with omakase but ended up probably trying everything on the menu and somehow our bill was still really low. It's no frills sushi here, no fancy rolls- which as a girl who religiously goes for nigiri/sashimi at sushi places, this was heaven for me. As per usual, my favorite fish reigned to be yellowtail and ended up in me ordering yellowtail probably 3-4 times. 

Four stars for me because of the service. The couple who run this restaurant are extremely nice and attentive. My friend and I were on a steady stream of constantly ordering that was only possible because of them. At any other sushi bar, I don't think we would have been as well taken care of. I don't think Okina is for everyone since a lot of folks I know like their sushi "dressed up." But if you want simplicity, great service, and low prices, this is the place to go.
author: Arezou A.

description:
Average sushi... yes the $25 omakase is a good deal but we got jipped.

Looking at the Yelp photos, people got 8-9 sushi pieces. Last night, we only got 5! Wth. 

Also, because this place is only open Thur-Sun, no one answers the phone ever. It's a very small restaurant so reservations are must.

Sushi is overall just ok, not amazing. Cuts were on the smaller side. Rolls are pretty good deal though. A personal preference, they don't have plain salmon sashimi, only smoked salmon. They also started running out of sashimi towards the end of the night, which may be why we only had 5 per person? I am not quite sure how the bill added up, but the lady did mention she took off the cost of some of the sushi...

Service is excellent. Only 2 people running the restaurant (1 server and 1 sushi chef). 

I really wanted to like this place, but mehhh... it was alright. Btw it's cash only.
author: Janet H.

description:
This is maybe inner richmond's best kept sushi secret. We called at 2pm on a Thursday to make a reservation for 7pm that night. Reservations are highly recommended, since the place is super small and fills up quickly. They're open for the weekend only.

It's a one man show behind the sushi bar. Trust me, order Omakase plus a roll or some additional nigiri. As he makes the nigiri he drops 'em off just straight up on the bar in front of you. Who needs plates!? Omakase was about 9 pieces, and we ordered 3 more just to ensure full bellies. The quality is A++, especially for the price ($25 for Omakase). I also hear its BYOB without the corkage fee, but have yet to try.

Cash only! And there's an ATM in Arguello Market next door just in case.
author: Steph D.

description:
Alas, a simple sushi restaurant. The menu is sweet and simple with sushi, rolls, drinks.

We got the omakase, uni with quail eggs (fav), tobiko, and amaebi (delicious!).With our meal we had a large hot sake, totaling out to $75! Not bad!
author: Mako U.

description: Good, simple, fresh sushi!  No fancy rolls, but can't go wrong with 3$ sushi and cheap drinks.  The house special looked really good as well.  Great service!
author: Mary M.

description:
We managed to sneak reservations on a Thursday evening day of with no problem. The place is charmingly tiny, so be sure to make a reservation before you come to guarantee you have a seat. 

The menu is small and comprises nigiri, sashimi and rolls only, so we got (almost) everything (rolls not pictured).  My highlights were the yellowtail, unagi, and fresh crab (kani).  We put a high wager on tamagos which were fine but less sweet than expected (if even sweet at all). Just know that before you make three orders of them . 

Everything else was wonderful - service, intimate atmosphere, and reasonable pricing. That all with the quality/freshness of sushi means I'll definitely be back. Sooner than later for sure.
author: Christine C.

description:
Can't believe I never knew about this place since it's been there for 37 years! 

We didn't have reservations so we tried for walk-in and yay they took us. We sat down at the bar and our ginger and wasabi was placed beautifully on the bar counter. 

Everything we ordered was delicious and would definitely come back again when we're in the mood for sushi. Everything we ordered with sake was under $100. Super good deal for fresh seafood.
author: W W.

description: I almost don't want to tell you how incredible this place is, because I loved that I was able to walk in and get one of the very limited seats on a Friday night. Why it wasn't packed is an absolute mystery to me. Best sushi I've had in a very long time, most gracious host ever, and such a talented and funny itamae (sushi chef). Great selection, absolutely fresh, and done with such classic humble Japanese reverence for style and quality. It's the most authentic feeling sushi restaurant I've ever been to.
author: Justin M.

description:
Where to even start... Okina is hands down the most authentic Japanese food experience i've had here in America. The quality of the nigiri is only on par with the sushi I've had in Japan, as well as the hot matcha they bring out when you arrive and the otherwise excellent service. 

It's a very small restaurant, only open three days a week for four hours at a time, but the elderly Japanese couple who runs it is lovely and I've never had a bad experience here. They're very helpful an generous, as well as incredibly sweet and polite. 

I always recommend the omakase (chef's choice), as there are some amazing flavors and combinations i never would have tried elsewhere that I now love.

I loved my first dinner here so much that I even took my boyfriend here for our anniversary dinner.
author: Marian L.

description:
Don't be fooled by the low prices. This is a quality establishment run by some very warm people! 

Note: cash only, limited hours, and tendency to get booked up with reservations on Friday and Saturday nights, so try to call ahead.
author: Schuyler T.

description: I hesitated for so long about writing a review for this place because I don't want people to find out about this secret little gem! This place has hands down the best omakase in all of San Francisco. Sushi here is simple, fresh, and of superb quality. Tiny storefront so it's actually really easy to miss. Plus, they're only open 3 days out of the week, and the store can probably seat no more than 12 people, so reservations are hard to score unless you call in advance. The wife-husband team and the overall experience reminds me a lot of Jiro Dreams of Sushi. I remember back to my first time here, hubby and I walked out of the storefront after our meal, and were literally jumping/screaming/hugging each other, rejoicing at the fact that we've found the best and most reasonably priced little sushi joint in San Francisco!
author: Cathy C.

description:
I'll take sashimi and nigiri over a dragon roll always.
The fish is sweet, fresh, and seasoned well. The omakase menu is affordable as is the a la carte menu. Everything is made right before your eyes in a very clean, small, cozy venue with limited seating without feeling like sardines in a can. 

That's not even the best part. Chef has been doing what he does best for 30 years. He is nowhere near a jaded or grumpy 'ol grandpa. He is delightfully sweet and hilarious. He prepares each bite with ease while interacting and socializing away like there is nothing he would rather be doing. 

I asked chef where he got his fish. He told us about how his fish comes from different places... Spain, Philippines, Alaska, and he always knows how old the fish is when serving it. Before we knew it, we were immersed in his tales about how he started his business, what his upbringing was like, and what his sons do for a living. You almost feel like you were invited for a traditional sushi dinner in his living room and forget that you made a reservation in a place that seats about 10 people. 
The waitress was just as sweet. To say the service she provided was attentive is an understatement. She radiates such a warm and mild-mannered personality. Before we knew it, the meal was already over.

I'm not even clear how they totaled up our bill. We both went with the omakase, a couple of add-ons from the menu, and wine. Yet somehow the total was still about the cost of 2 omakase meals.

Most of what we ate was nigiri. Each order comes in a pair. Everything was presented directly from the chef's hands. No plates, which is the traditional way. 

Maguro (Tuna) - sweet and clean to the bite. The fatty tuna almost melts in your mouth. 

Hirame (Halibut) - smooth, subtle flavor,

Hamachi (Yellow Tail) - mildly sweet, meaty in texture

Kobashira (Scallop) - juicy scallop with scallions and tobiko wrapped tightly over rice

Amaebi (Raw Prawn) - very sweet, tender, meaty shrimp

Tamago Nigiri - deliciously sweet egg omelette

Tuna Temaki - sweet, fresh tuna in mildly vinegary sushi rice & cucumber expertly wrapped in crunchy nori

The only minor thing I would say is the cuts were not all sharp or uniform-looking, but the flavor was amazing.

Drink options are beer, wine, and sake. It was my mistake to choose white wine. It was weak and too sweet. It was only $2.50 a glass.

It's not too difficult to make a reservation, but definitely make a reservation and plan ahead. Okina is only open Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturday evenings. They only take reservations by phone no more than a couple of days in advance. Don't complain. It's a long-standing small business / sole proprietorship / mom & pop business, not corporate / restaurant chain / big box company, so don't expect it to be one. Definitely request the sushi bar!

I usually get annoyed when a restaurant is cash-only, but for this awesome little joint, I'll walk a couple of blocks to Geary and withdraw some green. All I can ask myself is why don't I come here more?
author: Joy W.

description: Small cozy restaurant that I always overlook because it seems to blend into the scenery.  Reservations seems to be a must since there aren't much seating.  My friend booked an early reservation and we sat at the bar.  The omakase of 8 pieces came out to be $26 after tips.  Everything was so delicious, I want to go again.
author: Karen L.

description: Price is very reasonable for the omasake but they don't have any flamed sushi or other food like other omasakes I've eaten.  If your looking for high end stuff then I would recommend u try other places but for a good value basic sushi bar this is the place !!!
author: Adrian Y.

description: I'm scared to write this review, because I fear that it will only make it more difficult in the future to get a reservation, because it still remains a hidden gem, despite being in business for almost 4 decades. This place is as authentic as it gets. Feels like you're in Tokyo - just one sushi chef and an assistant that serves beer and wine. No crazy American rolls, just freshly served, simple nigiri and maki, but it's all delicious, and the hosts are friendly and attentive. You can tell that the sushi chef (there is only one), has been doing this for a very long time and knows exactly what he's doing. Great place to visit if you want good sushi on the weekend, as they're only open from Thursday-Saturday.
author: Luis M.

description: A rare gem.  Exceptional sushi.  Unbelievable prices. Call for reservation day of. They have a limited schedule
author: Sandra A.

description:
I'm always scared of sharing my secret sushi places because I hate lines and I refuse to wait an hour for food. 

Okina holds a really special place in my favorite sushi place line up because the sushi chef is authentic, sushi is top notch, and there is no pretentiousness. The service is polite and quiet. You can't just barge in a lot of money and expect respect. You gotta show it to get it. 

No frills, but classic and traditional. They place the sushi on the "table" and you can eat it with your chopsticks or hands. You won't find any specialty rolls, just straight up traditional nigiri and simple rolls (tekka,kappa, etc). 

Cash only.
author: Wanster L.

description: I hate being a sushi snob but its true...i can't help it and it ruins me but whatever this place is probably one of the better sushi joints if you live near richmond or upper haight .  Come early or they will run out of Uni and other favorites.  If you know what kind of fish you like, order it specifically and I'd say do without the omakase.  cash only but service is great.  If i had to compare the quality to elephant sushi, I'd say elephant is still a tad bit better, and if I had to compare the value to Amami in san bruno, I'd say amami's value is better but this place is like a love child between the two that took half the good traits from each parent.
author: Vince L.

description: Authentic Japanese spot. Cozy. Reminds me of Kyoto. Good quality fish. Warm and friendly owners.  Everything was deelish and Hamachi was bomb.com
author: Josh P.

description: The old Japan guy is homophobic and racist. Went one night and he was treating these gay guys and lesbians horribly. The lesbians were Asian btw and he made them share ginger and wasabi and was belittling them for being gay.  Won't be going back. Supposedly, he's a Trump supporter. Hope he gets deported back to Japan for being a bigot. Didn't leave a tip as he didn't deserve it.
author: David K.

description:
There was an article on the Atlantic Monthly on the benefits of eating fish: one ought to eat fish at least a week. On that notion, I pinged T. It's our place really, though we've not been to it together, we have walked by it a number of times, each time closed. I made reservation because I know how the restaurant scenes are in San Francisco, or elsewhere for that matter. Unless you want to wait in line or be turned away at door, make the call and get yourself a table, like we did.

The small restaurant was filled by the time we showed up at 5 minutes before 7 on a Thursday evening. The one table that had a "Reserve" sign on it was ours, naturally. As forewarned by fellow yelpers, this place is small, tidy and has a system of its own. It did seem a bit like Japan, very small and cute, and extremely efficiently run by one chef and one waitstaff, possibly related. Ordered nigiri on the menu, they bring fixings and tea. Lovely way to start an evening. 

Food is decent but watching how the restaurant operates was even more entertaining. Four couples were turned away at door despite the fact there seemed to be tables set up, presumably reservations for other smarty pants like us. 

Something to consider coming here vs other sushi joints in the Avenues is that this place has a right type of atmosphere, it's unassuming, feels a bit stepping back in time, and the portion of the food more of the size you'd see in Japan.

I like it as an experience restaurant, something different to try, and perhaps at the end of it, you won't feel so stuffed like you would with other Americanized sushi joints.
author: Victoria E.

description: Okina is one of my favorite new sushi finds. Fresh sushi, quick service and made by a chef who truly loves his craft. The place is small and it's only opens 3 nights - thursday to saturday but you can call to make reservations. Cash only!
author: Kylee S.

description:
If you're looking for a very traditional no frills sushi spot with bargain prices, this is the place to come. As other reviewers mentioned, there is one Japanese sushi chef who serves the sushi. The menu is very simple and the only options are nigiri, sashimi, or simple rolls. Definitely don't expect anything fusion-y like a dragon roll.

For all salmon lovers, heads up they unfortunately only have smoked salmon and not regular sashimi salmon. :(

I personally felt very underwhelmed and unfortunately wasn't a huge fan. That said, it was cheap so you pay for what you get.
author: Sophia H.

description:
I have not written a yelp review in almost 3 years, but I needed to write about the amazing experiences I have had at Okina. My gf who lived in Japan for over a year says this is the most authentic sushi she has had since coming back to the states. She has never seen restaurant use a Shiso leaf correctly as Okina does. The chef is humble and quiet, but is extremely funny once you get him talking. Must sit at the 6 person bar for a true experience. 

I am only writing this review because I have come to love this place and it pains me to not see a 50 person wait outside. Granted there are probably 15 seats in the entire place. I enjoy walking in with a seat readily available at the sushi bar, but it would be better to see a fine establishment get the credit it deserves. Do yourself a favor and get here as fast as possible because the secret will get out.
author: Ian O.

description:
Last November I went to Tokyo for the first time and got omakase at the restaurants at the famous Tsukiji fish market. Since then, I've been craving for an authentic sushi experience in the States, and Okina definitely delivered.

We got the omakase, which was around 7 or 8 pieces -- I don't know what all of them were but we got some fantastic tuna, hamachi, smoked salmon, amaebi (raw shrimp), and a few more. Everything was super fresh and really good. We also ordered an additional tuna and a tamago, both of which were fantastic. The sushi chef makes ample use of shiso leaves on some of the nigiri, which gives them a bright and unique flavor. 

The total for the 2 omakase, the additional nigiri, and a large sake came out to $57. This place is my new favorite sushi place in the city.

As a note, this place is CASH ONLY -- I'd probably bring $100 for two, just in case you go crazy and decide to get 3 orders of uni or something. Make sure you sit at the counter, as the chef will ask you what types of fish you like as he serves you, so your omakase will be personalized, rather than the pre-set menu you'd get at a place like Amami.
author: Eric W.

description: I really like this restaurant! I went there at 5:30pm when it just opened, and I saw the restaurant was filled quickly. I had sushi and sashimi, everything was good. Very clean, the chef was nice too. I would recommend you make a reservation in advance. Great place!
author: Toto M.

description:
Finally, a sushi place in SF that I enjoy.  Seats maybe 16?  There are 6 seats at the sushi bar.  If you like sushi rolls, this is not the place for you.  If you like fresh fish for nigiri sushi, come on down.  Fish choices are limited but quality.  Prices are reasonable for the quality.  Cute Pop & Mom shop.

TIP 1:  CASH ONLY

TIP 2:  Book a reservation
author: Kim S.

description:
A very small & very laid back Japanese restaurant. The owner and his staff are so nice to chat with and he preps fresh sushi/sashimi with very reasonable price. 
I always do his Omakase. I wish I lived nearby..
I've never asked him what's today special!! Sushi rice is perfectly seasoned and perfect portion for sushi.
You should go if you have a chance. 
But Don't ask him to make some funky rolls. He won't do it;)
author: Tomoko R.

description:
Hands down the best sushi place in San Francisco. No frills and mostly nigiri, the best thing to do is ask for omakase and eat whatever the chef prepares. I have never eaten a bad thing here. In fact I have never eaten anything less than awesome here. To top it off, your bill will be less than most sushi places. $30 per person plus tip will leave you pleasantly satisfied. If you like sushi you don't want to miss this gem.

Tip: They are only open Thursday Friday and Saturday. Reservations for that week open at 2:00pm on Thursday. So if you want to go just call around 2 on Thursday that week and you are good to go.
author: Kim M.

description:
This place is legit! 

For starters, this place is tiny; so no large groups and make a reservation, if possible. The ambiance is very "no nonsense" in the sense that it's not a place where there's fountains or sushi chefs yelling out Japanese phrases (gotta love mall food courts). There's not even background music playing; it's very small, very intimate.

Now onto the orders, to be quite honest, you should really go with the Omakase (chef selections) if you're visiting your first time. What stuck out the most to me was the scallop roll, it was absolutely delicious. My friend, and fellow yelper, had been raving about the Uni with quail egg, and boy did she not disappoint with that recommendation. It was my first time trying it, and I must say, I'm now a fan. 

Great date spot, not good for groups larger than 5 (maaaaaybe 6), leave the kids at home with a baby sitter. If you're expecting something with fancy shmancy "bells and whistles" presentation, this place is NOT for you. 

And if my review hasn't yet sold you on checking out this place, the one and only chef is some original gangsta Japanese guy, super swagged out dude. How does that not make this place bad ass!?
author: Aaron C.

description: Secret sushi spot in SF, I try not to tell many people about this place because it really is a hidden gem.  The husband is a sushi chef and the wife does everything else. That's it.  Great quality nigiri, especially SB uni, for such a reasonable price.  Highly recommend this place, but a part of me is hoping it remains a secret.
author: James C.

description:
Wow! I can't believe I've been living in SF my whole life and never tried this sushi restaurant! What a gem in the Inner Richmond!

This place has excellent sushi for the price point. My boyfriend and I were shocked that several of the fish were imported from Japan! Lastly it was so cheap. We did the Omakase for two people...we also brought a bottle of wine (free corkage...!!!!!!), and without tip it came out to ~$85 total. Shocking. You aren't getting the super exotic fish here like barracuda etc., but he has all the standard fish like tuna, hamachi, mackerel, etc that taste superb. Some fish slices are thinly cut, but most are normal size nigiri. Also it was super easy to make a reservation! I think we made it the week of for a Saturday night. He was also personable and talked to us throughout the meal. The one sushi I remember vividly was his Uni. It came from Santa Barbara which is pretty typical, and can sometimes be a hit or miss depending on how fresh it is. He picked a super fresh one and it was quite mindblowing for Santa Barbara Uni!

Cons:
-Cash only. There is an ATM in the market next door though!
-No music in the restaurant. Kind of an awkward vibe. And the restaurant wasn't super packed either, so it has kind of a cold feel. Lighting wasn't very warm either since it's an older restaurant. 
-Fast meal in general. We were in and out within an hour. This probably isn't the place to bring your significant other for an anniversary dinner, but just a regular date night. Maybe even a weeknight if you're on the run. 

Anyway this is a SOLID sushi joint that I'm sad I didn't find earlier. COMING BACK HERE!!!!!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Great family run sushi with good prices but call to make reservations since they only sit 15-20 people at a time.
author: Jeff S.

description:
An authentic no frills sushi experience. 

The fish is always fresh and absolutely sublime. Aki, the chef, is a real master of his craft. The tuna here is always fantastic and other cuts always burst with flavor. 

With extremely limited English on their part you won't be getting catered to, and it's always a quick and quiet eating experience. You sit down, get tea, and order. The fish is prepared quickly and presented to you as soon as it's ready. 

It's extremely limited seating and fish selection, so come early and just order what they recommend. You can't go wrong!
author: Nate R.

description: Such a great place! It's how I imagine Japan to be like. A tiny restaurant with row of 6 seats by the sushi bar and a couple of tables. Bf and I both got the omakase, chef's choice, which consisted of 7 pieces. The fish varies each day, we ended having smoked salmon, tuna, squid, cooked crab...and a few other things. They were all good! Someone sitting by the bar asked him what his favorite fish of the selected selection he had, he said mackerel, so we got mackerel. That mackerel, soooooo good, sooooo glad we got it. We also ended ordering tamago nigiri and unagi nigiri. The unagi is heated up in the tiniest toaster oven, so fatty, buttery goodness. The tamago was just okay...Tani's Kitchen makes better tamago. For the amount of food we got, I thought it would have been around $80-100, it only ended costed us $55 with tax and tip, SOOOOO CHEAPPP!!!! I swear Kiki's costs more than this and that's the least authentic...I highly recommend making reservations! Only downside is that it's cash only and parking isn't the best.
author: Kylie L.

description: Open just a few hours per week and has some of the best fish around! Don't expect soup or salad. Pure sashimi and nigiri.
author: Don C.

description:
if you don't wanna shell out a lot of money on sushi, and still got the craving, i'd suggest to stop by nijiya to grab some from their bento section.

We came here for an early dinner.  Rice was already too cold. We sat at the sushi bar, and my question is what kind of sushi chef would place sushi on a slanted surface??? After we finished our omakase, I noticed him molding rice on his board for customers who weren't even there yet. Green tea was super watered down as well. No, it is not worth it even with the low prices.
author: Reba J.

description:
What is there to be said that hasn't already been said. This place is awesome. The food is basic-- in the best way possible. Not the widest fish selection, but the execution is perfect. 

I'll add some negatives, but this place is still 5 stars hands down.
- Better get a reservation, or no sushi for you.
- Better bring cash, or no sushi for you.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Logistics:
Opens Thurs, Fri, Sat evenings. Small, intimate setting, seats about 12 people at a time. Simple menu. Cash only.

Followed tips from other yelpers to make reservations, speaking directly to a staff person via phone (did not leave a message), and was successful reserving seats at the bar. (I called the restaurant a couple hours before opening time on a Thursday. Other yelpers have recommended making reservations up to 1 week in advance.)

Experience:
Chef was friendly and welcoming and made good recommendations for fish of the day: magaro tuna, hamachi, and smoked salmon nigiri. My friends and I also had the scallop, mackerel, sweet shrimp, snapper, and jack fish nigiri. The fish was fresh and sweet. The succulent sushi were little bites of happiness! 

Cost/quality:  $$/very good. Each person had about ten orders of nigiri  (20 pieces), which was more than enough. Total is approximately  $60.00/person (without tip). Though the price is moderately more expensive than other sushi places, it seems to be reasonable for the quality.

Will I return? Yes!
author: Amanda N.

description:
I love this place. Everything awesome about this place has been said. Their sushi is always fresh! The owner is spectacular and guarantees the freshness of his work. 

I do recommend making reservations, as this place gets packed very quickly.
author: Josh L.

description:
READ THIS BEFORE MAKING RESERVATION VIA PHONE: learn from the many mistakes that others have had to suffer through before you including the one that just occurred with me and my friend. 

They are only open like three days a week so when my friend called to make a reservation no one picked up and she left a message with the reservation information...or so she thought.....

....when I arrived, to my dismay, I was told they didn't have our reservation. I was confused and probed further to find that they actually DO NOT have an answering machine but when you call it sounds like they do. She told me that you can only make reservation when they pick up their phone. 

Moral of the story: if no one picked up, no one is there. DO NOT leave messages because no one will ever hear them....because it doesn't exist.

If you're wondering why I out three stars, it's because I love these hole in the wall places and it was seriously reminiscent of Japan....

...I'll be back.....after making a reservation....by actually speaking to a person.....
author: Melody G.

description:
Okina was just alright. The selection of fish is limited and there wasn't any uni when I went which is always a bummer. 

My husband and I went omakase and it was okay. The sushi chef served halibut, squid, tuna, smoked salmon, among others. None were really memorable, so therefore memory fails me on what the others were. 

I don't usually think about service too much, but when it's lacking, I really notice. The sushi chef just plopped down our two pieces of nigiri and mumbled the same thing each time he served us, something that sounded like "eat". Then another two pieces were plopped down..."eat". No explanation whatsoever of what type of fish he was serving us.

The guy next to us tried to order uni while looking at his menu, and the sushi chef angrily told him no uni and to just look at the fish at the bar to see what they have. Then what are menus used for???

I'm glad that I tried this place, but I won't be returning for round two.
author: Gina W.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! Found it by chance walking home and I'm in love with it. Quiet, traditional atmosphere with a simple and authentic menu. 
Gives great (nonbag) green tea, lovely service, and delicious handmade sushi. 
Loved it!! 
Although if you dislike wasabi, tell them beforehand as they put it directly into the sushi.
author: Monica O.

description:
CASH ONLY - MAKE RESERVATIONS or try your luck! 

A tiny, well-maintained, clean, and cozy mom and pop sushi restaurant. This place is a hole in the wall because it can be easily missed since they don't have any bright signs outside. 

This is the place to go if you're looking for fresh fish and none of that deep fried tempura or sticky sauce roll. It's clean, it's fresh, and it makes you feel like you've been eating healthy.

Portions are small and most sushi orders come in pairs. It's not too expensive, depending on what you order and how much you order. 

My favorites are the amberjack, smoked salmon, raw scallop, and halibut. 

Sushi chef is nice and the lady who takes the orders is friendly. They serve hot tea and the service is attentive. The lady who takes your orders is great with recommendations. If you are really feeling hungry, I'd say to try everything on the menu :P I don't think you could go wrong with trying anything here. It's delicious.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
People who commented that they were turned away have a big problem reading.
You have to make a reservation no matter what. If you knew it was a tiny place and they've turned you away once,  why repeat what you did the first time?
That would be the very deifnition of stupidity.... expecting the same results. I have never gone there without a reservation. EVER. The reviews told me that.

To the lady that came in and said it was Medicare chinese sushi,I read your other reviews and you don't seem educated enough to spell or write correctly, let alone judge people by status. First of all, he's Japanese, not Chinese. Secondly, people on MediCare shouldn't be made fun of. His prices are fairly cheap for fresh sushi. Especially because he chooses only the best and is closed on Sundays.

My review:

Ambience: 5 : not stuffy, very cosy and simple. 
Service : 10: Very attentive and friendly
Price: 8: BIG pieces of fish for a good price, Omakase was even just 60ish dollars.
Food: 10: let me tell you this right now.. this is no frills, no mayonnaise, no spicy tuna sort of sushi place. If you want that then this isn't it. But if you want to eat fresh, beautiful  fish, then this is the spot. 

Side story:

I once went here with my best friend and we were short 30 bucks. 

The owner and chef said, "it's okay, money doesn't  matter, only friendship". We were short and he let us go. He didn't know me at that time and it was one of the nicest experiences ever.
I came back after a few months and he recognized me right away and asked me how my friend was. I had told him I traveled from the East Bay just to eat there and he didn't charge me that much. I tipped him $30... 10 for dinner and the 20 that I had owed him. He never asked about that money either. 

:)
author: Patricia A.

description: Finally a sushi restaurant with a Japanese sushi chef!  Simple, delightful, tasty, and reasonably priced sushi.  No fancy rolls here just sushi and maki the way they were supposed to be.  This guy has been here for 35 years and the only problem is that they're July open 3 days/week.
author: Dan O.

description:
A solid 3.5 stars. When I am starving, the biggest compliment I can give a restaurant is that the food came out fast. I mean really, super fast. Just sit down at the sushi bar and BAM, faster than you can say Flash Gordon there is a piece of nigiri in front of you.

Came here 15 minutes before closing but I did not feel rushed. Ordered the omakase, which included tomago, saba, shake, hirame, hamachi, kani, unagi, maguro, amaebi, kaki, kobashira. The service was excellent and the sushi chef was the nicest, most friendly one I have met. He gave my eating companion and I free marguro sashimi and tamago. In addition to the ginger and wasabi given at ever Japanese restaurant, there was pickled daikon, which I thought was a nice snack to quell my hunger.

Parking was not an issue for me but it came be difficult in this area. Overall Okina Sushi is a nice, small neighborhood sushi joint (CASH ONLY) serving nigiri at a fast pace. 

What I recommend:
-- omakase
author: Andrew W.

description:
Got very lucky walking in by myself on a Saturday night and was able to get a seat at the bar. As soon as I sat down the chef offered and brought me tea and water. Fantastic quality fish, very affordable omakase, and friendly service.

One note of caution: they are cash only, which I didn't notice until I saw it on the menu. If you're caught by surprise, Arguello Market is right next door and they will do cash back with a $5 purchase.
author: Amanda D.

description:
I watched "Jiro Dreams of Sushi" then went to Okina.
Both chefs are bald with glasses. Cool.

Reviews said to RSVP. I didn't. Just walked in, full-on jewfro.
Price for omakase said "(Ask)". I didn't. Just ordered it.

He made 5 nigiri pairs way faster than I could eat them.
He put the assortment directly on the slanted bar surface.

It's a separate panel of the bar, above your dishes.
Other than wasabi, ginger, and radish(?),
nothing else touches this surface except when he wipes it.
So if you're nervous about food directly on the bar, don't be.

I let him choose everything I ate afterward, too.
I wanted to see what flavor story he'd create.
I photographed only some of the stuff.

He ended up repeating two items. Fine by me.
I believe he said they were the day's specials.
Unless you're deciding your own items, I'd say
stick with 7 or 8 rounds if you want no duplicates.

A skater walked in but was turned away.
I want to think it had nothing to do with his appearance.

Every seat that wasn't occupied was reserved.
So don't do what I did. Instead, RSVP. And skate faster.

(I have some stories I want to tell you about the folks
sitting beside me, but they're too long for the review.)
author: Dan B.

description:
I eat a ton of sushi, and though there are five
or so sushi restaurants throughout SF where I like to get it, Okina is without question my favorite. Yes, you have to call for a reservation, and there may be a bit of phone tag before you get the time/day you want. And yes, it's a low-key hole in the wall, so if you are looking for a fancy dining experience then Okina might not be for you. But if you love really fresh sushi, then I'd recommend sitting at the bar and ordering the omakase. The chef only works with fresh ingredients--nothing frozen--and it's a pleasure to watch him work. Take a fun dining companion who also loves good sushi, and you are guaranteed a great meal.
author: Rose G.

description:
ok i was pretty excited to try this place becaues of the reviews and finally went last night but was not that impressed. We made a reservation but now i'm curious if that's neceesary as it was not packed at all. It's a cute little restaurant indeed and the couple working there I thought was very nice. The menu is pretty small and simple but the cuts and taste were not that special. I think Tekka spoiled me. Price was ok Iguess. We got 

2 Nigiri Deluxe (which DOES not look like the yelp pictures). You get like 6 nigiris for $15.

Omakase which is like $25ish you get 10 pieces of 5 different types of sashimi. Again nothing super special at all. 

I also got the unagi which was same as every other sushi place. Was not that impressed at all.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
"I just put the freshest uni in my mouth. I don't even care if that sentence doesn't make sense. My taste buds are exploding."

- My tweet as I almost died from mouth orgasm.

As other Yelpers have mentioned, if you're looking for sushi rolls drenched in sauce or ridiculously fancy looking orders for your Instagram needs, you won't be finding it at Okina Sushi. Here you'll only find simple nigiri you'll be chomping down so fast you'll forget to take a picture for your social media. 

A girlfriend and I were finally able to try Okina last week and after we were out the door, we already had plans to go right back! Honestly the atmosphere of Okina is a bit intimidating. The restaurant is very quiet and small. We were seated at the bar and received hot tea and utensils right away. After looking over the menu quickly, we decided to stick with the omakase. I guess the restaurant is quiet enough that the chef overheard us and started on our order right away without us even ordering with the waitress. 

We didn't keep track of how many nigiris we had for the omakase, but oh my goodness, everything was delicious! Even the seaweed was extra delicious! The fish itself was so fresh and really had that "melt in your mouth" experience. We ended up ordering more nigiris after our omakase ended.Our favorites were the amaebi, uni, scallop, and amberjack! 

Okina Sushi is really quite a small gem hidden in the Richmond district. I highly recommend trying Okina, but remember to make reservations (they are only open Thursday-Sunday after 5pm) and to bring cash!
author: Judith L.

description:
This is the second time I have walked into Okina, seen plenty of open seats, and have been turned away by the owners/staff.  They told us the spaces were reserved for people coming at 7pm... it was ten minutes past six when we walked in. We were refused service.

The woman was rude, and I have been disappointed by this place twice and it's not worth the effort to attempt another visit.
author: Ross H.

description: My parents have been coming here for 30 years and they say the prices remain reasonable and the fish is incredibly fresh. Akio, the owner, definitely loves his job and knows what he is doing.  Not very much variety in terms of rolls, but if you are looking for authentic, high quality fish that is extremely fresh without the Americanized froo froo stuff, this is the place to go!! Make sure to check what days it is open before going and the store is small, so it is not great for large parties.
author: Frances H.

description: A true hole in the wall gem. The fish is picked up from the market at 3am the day of and is fresh, never frozen. The owner told us his fish comes direct from Japan. Authentic and delicious sushi. Basic dishes done to perfection.
author: Stephen C.

description: Really cool omakase experience, including a great sushi chef. Very authentic mid century vibe of a spot. The fish was very fresh. Enjoyed the whole thing, especially the hand rolls, which reminded me of sugar fish in LA.
author: Andrew K.

description:
You didn't hear about this place from me. This place is a secret.

Wait what? The bill was HOW MUCH?

.......that's it?????????

Not a huge variety of "unique" or "rare" fishes, but they have a solid lineup of the usual suspects, and great quality at that.

Finally, a sushi place in SF that doesn't smother their food in sriracha/mayo/teriyaki/unagi sauce. This is how sushi should be, people!

Warning: This place is not for your "omg that place has amazing rolls!" -type of sushi fans. Only come here if you want the real deal.

Let's keep this place on the downlow.. I would be devastated if it got too crowded for me to get a reservation!
author: Kazu O.

description:
Delicious fresh fish!

I have been here a couple of times, and it's always good! It's a fantastic mom-and-pop  restaurant run by husband and wife. The place can be somewhat hard to find since there is no sign or anything. The waitress, wife, is extremely kind and accommodating. One time my friends were unable to make it to our reservation due to an emergency, but she seated us at the table regardless. 

The fish is just simply amazing. Fresh and melt in your mouth! My friends and I had the omakase but since it was so good, we ordered more. The uni with quail eggs are delicious. The scallop is great as well. I love how the portions are small, but jam packed with flavors. The chef really knows how to bring out the fish' special flavors. 

But just be aware that you should make a reservation instead of walking in. Reservations tend to take up majority of the seats, so by the time you walk in asking for a seat, they're out of fish.

All in all, love it. Definitely will be back again!
author: Bonny C.

description:
I really don't think I'll be able to find quality sushi in this city to match up to the sushi I have back in LA. My friend took me here after being recommended from another friend, they do omakase for about 25 bucks, I was sold. 

What I found was a small small place, about 6 seats at the bar, 3 small tables in the restaurant and one sushi chef. He was perfectly capable of handling the whole restaurant, so much to the point that he put the fish out in front of me so fast that I felt the need to rush to eat to keep up. The serving manner wasn't what I was used to, but also not a deal breaker. He also had all the stuff precut and didn't do much to fancy up his sushi and rolls. Quality of the fish was definitely better than some stuff you'll find in the city, but not of the highest quality. Also since it was a small shop there wasn't too much variety of fish, even his salmon was smoked. If you're into that sorta thing then have at it, but I was bummed to find that he also used this in his salmon skin roll, which wasn't much crispy. I think our bill ended up at 80 something for two since we got extra sushi, more pricy than I expected for what we got. I'd go back, but I won't be running to go back again
author: Samantha C.

description: Small traditional japanese neighborhood spot. Owners are very nice, fun and friendly. The menu, as everyone says, is small and simple. Sashimi, nigiri, handroll or basic makis. Nothing special here but nothing to complain...it was perfect for what I was looking for...back to basics. The best thing here is the price...ate everything and it came out less than $80.
author: .I I.

description: Wow, this place is incredible. We sat at the bar last night, and really enjoyed our omakase meal. The chef is a older Japanese man and we had the pleasure of watching him prepare each piece of nigiri before placing it directly on the bar in front of us.  Everything is very simple and traditional, but expertly prepared.  The prices are surprisingly reasonable too. Highly recommended and we will definitely return.
author: Allen T.

description:
This place is truly amazing. The sushi chef is a Hiroshima native who's been doing sushi for over 40 years. Very friendly guy, goes to the fish market himself to select the fish he will serve you that evening. 

The decor is in a classic Japanese style, which I prefer. There is a limited selection of beer and sake, but this is a place you go to for the sushi and not the booze. 

I will definitely be going back.
author: Sam K.

description:
Have you seen the movie Jiro Dream of Sushi? This place is similar to that movie. An elderly Japanese man hand crafts your sushi and places them piece by piece in front of you. The man is seriously fast and you can blow through 40 dollars in 15 minutes if he isn't too busy. I ended up feeling a little intimated and rushed, but damn that was good sushi. I would recommend you don't sit at the sushi counter unless you want to finish eating in a very short period. 

It was cash only by the way. I had to run next door into the market to get some cash.
author: Logan T.

description:
Solid. Simple. Stellar. 

This place reminds me of what a small japanese sushi in the country side of Japan would be like. There's only 1 chef and 1 waitress. 5 tables and a simple menu. None of the fancy rolls are served here. Sushi, handroll or cut roll. If you love simple authentic sushi style like I do, this is definitely the place to go.
author: Sophie S.

description: Called to check if they took cc - no. But! They don't tell us they are fully reserved so we walk 8 blocks to find out they won't serve us.  never going there again.
author: Roberta B.

description:
I went here with four friends for a birthday dinner since we all agreed we wanted amazing, fresh sushi, and we wanted it to be cheap. I had never been there before but due to the glowing reviews, I just booked the reservation. 

It was amazing and cheap but also sort of strange, in a delightful way. First, there is a very limited menu. A small sampling of rolls and there were a few glaring omissions ex. no rainbow roll and they don't have edamame or any apps.

They do give you delicious green tea when you sit down and have tasty sake. We each ordered at least two rolls and the bill at the end was about half what any other (and some not as good) sushi restaurants would be.
author: Lauren C.

description: Don't waste your time calling or stopping in, like myself,they do not serve the public. I called asking if the are cash only, found I needed to stop at the atm, arrived to find an empty place open and not taking any seating. Bad business, bad service... Will not be back regardless of the food quality.
author: Patrick W.

description:
You'll need a reservation and bring lots of cash!  
The place is tiny, and we lucked out and got a table without reservations at 6pm.  Location has great street parking available.  The menu is simple and we got all nigiri- favorites for the evening were smoked salmon, mackerel, ebi (Raw shrimp), and hirame. Enjoyed all the food and look forward to coming again.
author: Krystle L.

description: It's your basic restaurant/ nothing fancy but the atmosphere is homey and the sushi is bomb for the price! Will be back for more fresh shrimp!
author: L G.

description:
On a quiet street in the Richmond district lies a quaint little hole in the wall named Okina. 
Inside the quaint little hole in the wall is a tall, soft spoken, bald headed, and smiling sushi chef.. Chef, Akio san

Be smart. Make a reservation. This place is tiny and houses maybe about 15 people (7 at the bar and a couple of tiny tables) 
This place is also very very quiet. 

If you were dining here last week on 04/05/2012 I am so sorry. I was one of the loud Asian girls sitting at the sushi bar. SORRY! 

So anyway.

A short, simple, no frills menu that gets straight to the point: SUSHI. 

There is no rainbow dragon 5 secret sauce bullshit here. No way. This is for the no nonsense feckery sushi purists. If you're a germaphobe, don't eat here. Sushi is served traditionally ON THE SUSHI BAR. Yes, he puts the sushi ON TO THE BAR, not on a little plate placed in front of you. 
Go with omakase and let Akio san do his magic. He does not drink while working, so please respect his wishes. Although he is 70 something odd years old (hence why Okina is only open 3 days a week. He's an old man okay, be nice), he still makes sushi deftly. 

Excellent quality fish although I must note that I especially enjoyed the ikura. He marinates the roe himself with a little sake. Ikura was not overly salty like many as Nobu K would say "jive ass" sushi spots. 

When dining here, eat the sushi the legitimate way - right off the sushi bar, with your bare hands, no soy sauce. 

BRING THE GREENS BECAUSE THIS IS CA$H ONLY! still, very cheap and affordable.
author: Susy C.

description:
I just don't get the good reviews. I came here with a gf and having been at most raved about sushi place in sf, this one belong in the sunset, chinese own Medicare sushi category but overpriced. Will never be back. 
I should have know better m, the place was completely empty. :(
author: jasmin t.

description:
came here recently after probably a 8 year hiatus,, how have I not come back after all these years after leaving USF?

The old japanese man is still there, still gracious, still making some of the most simple and best tasting sushi rice.

All nigiri only, no hot food, not even miso soup. For nigiri purists for sure.

Although he only has the standard cuts of fish, maguro, smoked salmon, ebi, ikura, uni, hamachi, kanpachi, etc. all are prepared very well with great sushi rice.

My hubby and I went to HH and after leaving unsatisfied we were craving sushi. We thought let's give it a try and go back to the old man. We walked in a got a table right away! I think we got lucky as all the other tables near us had reserved signs on them and after we were seated many couples came in only to be turned away.

$5.50 for a pair of uni, smoked salmon was devine.

I will go back again for sure really really soon!
author: Petri Y.

description:
Okina is the best no-frills nigiri spot in the city. 

The sushi bar here is a great experience - sushi is served right on the counter top, and the sushi chef is very friendly and funny. He's over 70 and still doing what he does! He seriously looks like he's enlightened in the art of sushi.

Now, don't go here expecting crazy creative rolls, daily specials, or an extensive sake list - This is a very basic sushi restaurant. And cheap at that! Omakase is $25 and its 2 pieces per tasting instead of 1. The chef has been doing this for over 30 years and he has his set way of doing things. The saba here is especially good, and I normally don't even enjoy saba nigiri.

While i respect that he has his way, there are some downsides:
  - It's cash only.
  - Salmon is smoked. He says it's "safer", but I personally don't like smoked salmon nigiri.
  - No fried amaebi heads with your amaebi nigiri. He says it's not safe. 
  - Uni is just soso. 

Try it if you love good sushi with a down to earth, comfortable experience. Be sure to make a reservation - you can call the day before or as soon as they open on the day of.
author: Julie K.

description:
The food at Okina sushi is much like its atmosphere - simple, unadorned & unassuming. And the menu is just as straight forward: simple rolls, nigiri, and sashimi. 

I respect the mom & pop vibe of the restaurant, and the food was generally pleasing, but it wasn't a "blow my mind/I must make an out-of-way trek here" kind of place. 

I can't even muster up enough sentences to describe Okina. It was just average to me, but give it a try if you're in the area, looking for simple sushi and a really chill atmosphere.
author: Monelle A.

description:
In my estimations thus far Okina is the best "authentic" style sushi place in San Francisco. If you crave California style fusion rolls laden with avocado, spicy mayonnaise, chicken, etc. do not waste your time coming here, this is purist sushi. 

The spartan menu consists simply of nigiri, sashimi, and beer. Sashimi is priced the same as nigiri, which is fairly unheard of. Once you go you will realize this is because he uses the same sized sashimi cuts for both the sashimi and the nigiri. What fish is available will vary each time you come, as allegedly he only opens the restaurant with the freshest fish of the day. 

Important to note, if you cannot make and keep a reservation do not come here. Walk-in dining is virtually unheard of and somewhat frowned upon at this tiny 12 person seating restaurant. They take reservations same day if you call the hour they open and it is possible to book a day or two in advance which is HIGHLY advisable as they book up for the entire weekend fast! 

The bottom line: best raw authentic sushi, hours and reservations take some attention to detail to successfully execute, overall completely worthwhile, real hole in the wall, bring a date or a friend not a group.
author: Tomas K.

description:
First of all, don't bother going in if you can't speak Japanese. The lady was RUDE and it looks like she was pretending to be dumb and illiterate so we would just leave. I went in just to order take-out and when I told her that, she just stared blankly back at me and told me I needed a reservation.... WHAT? I haven't even heard of this place and was only there cause it was within my vicinity. This place really deserves the empty seats in its restaurant! Simply horrible!

p/s I sense this place is trying to emulate the infamous Jiro restaurant in Japan. Big fat, F-A-I-L
author: Jingi A.

description:
We got really lucky with this place. It was on my bookmarks to try for the longest time. We came on a weekend night, spent about 15 minutes searching for parking (by the way, this is a tough area to find parking!), walked in without a reservation, and were able to be squeezed in before a reservation in 40 minutes. We figured we were there and we might as well. It was very accommodating of them to fit us in like that. Service was outstanding!

Although I was hesitant about getting all I wanted in 40 minutes, I did not feel rushed at all and we left feeling like we spent a good meal there. 

My date however brought up a great point - to be this type of sushi restaurant, you have be up to par. They have almost everything done right - the whole set up is so authentic feeling. One sushi chef (very friendly), small restaurant, limited seating, nigiri and hand rolls only, and the sushi is served right there on the counter. It was very fresh fish, however, it wasn't mind-blowing. 

Point being - try it out, I'm glad I did. It's not a place I'd visit again, at least not until I have more money!

Make a reservation so you will have a chance of eating here. In the 30 minutes we were there, they turned away 2 people because of limited seating. Also, cash only!

If this place were a bit more affordable, I'd love it. But it's a lot to spend for a little. I appreciate that they only serve simple sushi - nigiri and hand rolls - that's my type of sushi joint.
author: Junel S.

description:
Sushi here was quite amazing. Probably one is the better sushi places I've ever been to in the U.S. The quality is top notch and the price- they practically are just giving food away!
We had the Omakase but I think we were better off ordering a la carte since it was pretty much the same exact thing. 

The place is small with only a few tables so make sure to call and make a reservation. We lucked out and called an hour before we came.

All in all I cannot wait to return to this hidden gem!
author: Paul K.

description: We've been to Okina over a dozen times and have found their sushi tasty and of great quality. What has kept us away in the last year is Okina's owner and only sushi chef. We often feel treated as an inconvenience and not valued customers who are accommodating and often leave more than a 15% tip for the waitress. If you want better service, a vast menu selection and superb quality food, try Ace Wasabi on Steiner. Sit at the bar with Yuben or Will.
author: Christine Y.

description: Traditional Sushi bar, super tiny so you have to make reservations, at most 4 people. There were only 3 tables and 6 seats at the bar. I got the omakase for around $28 and got 18 pieces of nigiri so great deal! I think it changes depending on what fish is fresh but my favorites were the prawn and yellowtail. Afterwards we were still hungry so we ordered a yellowtail roll and mackerel nigiri. Delicious fresh fish. Great for date night, sit at the bar!
author: Ming C.

description: Came here expecting to experience Japan-like sushi. Supposed to be fresh, tasty, melt in your mouth? Not this place! The sushi chef was nice but it's just okay here. We sat at the sushi bar. There's a board in front of you and that's where he placed our food when we ordered....umm...not sure how clean that is. Very limited selections on the menu and fish. They didn't have fresh salmon?? Only smoked salmon...huh..interesting.  No Uni, no scallop...Rolls had a lot of rice...not good.
author: Alyce l.

description: Great sushi if, like me, you love nigiri and sashimi, but people who like inventive rolls may be disappointed.  Small restaurant with limited seating.  Main drawback is that it is pretty much only open on the weekend.
author: Anthony D.

description:
The best thing to do with this place is to call the day of or the day before to reserve seats. If you show up with no reservations, you will be turned away. Do not chance it. 

They have very odd hours of operations. They are only open from Thurs-Sat. 5pm to 10 pm. I'm pretty sure this is a hobby for them and they live upstairs. 

A really cute woman and her husband run the place. She is very sweet and great at recommending food for the table. 

The best part of this place. The sushi is super cheap and fresh! The sushi is not perfect, and smaller portions than most places. BUT even given the size, the deal is awesome. Our omakase cost 20 ish dollars!! WOW. 

Uni and Toro were our favorite. Definitely coming back here. Since it's outside the regular Richmond area, there were a lot more parking!
author: Winny F.

description:
Step 1. Make sure its Thursday-Sunday.  If not, starve yourself until then.
Step 2. Call them and let them know when you're coming in.
Step 3. Go in at that time.
Step 4. Order the Chefs Special.
Step 5. fpoiawehgpiuhgajfsdlfj SO GOOD
author: Jenny S.

description: Best sushi in the city, that's not even considering the price. Home owned and prepared with care and respect. This is as close as it gets to an authentic Japanese experience.
author: Mish A.

description:
Have you seen Jiro Dreams of Sushi? 

Come here if you want to pretend you're at Jiro's
author: Tatyana K.

description:
Simple and delicious, this is the best sushi I've ever had.  
You should order the chefs special, an assortment of the freshest fishes he has for the day.  It may be daunting because there's no price tag but don't worry it's very reasonably priced (~$30 for 14-18 pieces of nigiri.)

The amberjack, yellowtail and uni are amazing. Go early, items sell out quick.
author: David Z.

description:
I'm pretty hesitant to write a review for Okina sushi, because I'd rather not see my favorite sushi restaurant be oversaturated with San Francisco foodies. 

This is not the place to go if you want your Philadelphia and Soft Shell Crab rolls. Do the omakase if you don't know what you're doing because Okina is a no bull, traditional sushi restaurant. Service is awesome and try and spark up a convo with the chef, very interesting guy. Love this place.
author: Cody M.

description:
CALLING ALL SUSHI PURISTS!!!

If you enjoy monstrous Americanized sushi rolls drenching with spicy mayo, you can stop reading this review because you will NOT find this at Okina. Personally, sushi is about enjoying fresh seafood and fish in its most unadulterated form and this IS what you'll find at Okina! 

R E S E R V A T I O N S:
A MUST! Okina is a small restaurant with several tables and sushi bar seating. 

On Saturday, 11/20/10, my friend and I came to Okina at 8:30 PM. We had reservations at 8 PM, but thanks to the lovely hail and thunder we were running late. I called Okina to let them know and they said it wouldn't be a problem.

NOTE: Okina is ONLY open Thursday, Friday and Saturday for Dinner (5 PM - 10 PM). 

M E N U (CASH ONLY):
Okina has a very small and limited menu:

*Nigiri Combo Plate: ($11.50-$14)

*Chirashi ($11.50): Assorted fish on a bed of rice

*6 Maki Rolls ($3.30 - $3.60): 
CA (crab and avocado), NY (prawn and avocado), Alaska (salmon and avocado), Hamachi (yellowtail), Tekka (tuna) and Salmon Skin roll. 

*16 Nigiri/Sashimi ($2.30 - $4): 
Tamago (egg), Saba (mackerel), Smoked salmon, Ebi (prawn), Hirame (halibut), Hamachi (yellowtail), Kani (real crab), Ikura (salmon roe), Tobiko (fish roe), Unagi (eel), Uni (sea urchin), Ika (squid), Maguro (tuna), Amaebi (raw prawn), Kaki (oyster), and Kobashira (scallop). 

You can add a quail egg for $.30. 

*Drinks:
Beer and one kind of sake (room temperature).

F O O D:
*MAKI ROLLS: CA, NY, Alaska and Hamachi

All of the maki's were SIMPLE yet GOOD! The FRESH crab, prawn, salmon, hamachi, and buttery avocado were tightly bundled up with soft, yet slightly al-dente sticky rice that had mild sweet tartness complementing the natural sweetness of the seafood and fish.

NOTE: Okina's maki rolls are small and compact. They're about 50% smaller than the typical monstrous rolls you will find at other restaurants, 

*NIGIRI: Amaebi and Uni w/ Quail Egg

Both were AMAZING!!!

As if the Amaebi was caught from the Northern waters of the Pacific Ocean that morning, it was amazingly fresh with a sweet and clean finish. 

The Uni was by far the BEST I've ever had! It tasted like a soft, creamy, sweet custard with a delicate brininess like a fresh ocean breeze that melts on your palette. The quail egg added a velvety layer bringing decadence to a whole new level!

*SASHIMI: Hamachi and Maguro

Both the Hamachi and Maguro were perfectly cut at an angle and across the grain exposing a large surface area which highlighted the fresh and buttery flavor of the fish.

S E RV I C E:
True Japanese Hospitality!

Upon entering Okina, we were warmly welcomed by Chef/owner Akio-San and the waitress. The waitress promptly took our order which was brought out within minutes. She was attentive without being overbearing and always made sure our teacups were filled.

After finishing our meal, Akio-San graciously thanked us for coming and saw us off. He is so genuinely sweet and friendly that you can't help but love the guy.

P A R K I N G:
DIFFICULT! Okina is located in a very residential area of Inner Richmond, so expect to spend a good amount of time circling around. I highly suggest taking Muni and/or a cab instead.  

When it comes down to authenticity and high-quality ingredients at affordable prices, Okina definitely fits the bill to a "T". 

I finally found my FAVORITE sushi joint in SF! A big hearted Arigatou Gozaimasu to Akio-San...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: This place is legit; the staff is Japanese and the chef knows his sushi. I definitely plan on going back and strongly recommend this place. Additionally, this establishment represents an old school breed of Japanese restaurants in San Francisco - solid food without catering exclusively to yuppies - and is definitely worth trying.
author: Herman R.

description: I almost don't want to write a yelp review in fear that this place will get ridiculously busy.  Then again this is the type of place where every table it taken up by reservations so don't expect to just walk in.  All of the sushi we got was very fresh.  We ordered about 15 pieces each since we got a bit excited.  My favorite was the uni, amaebi, and toro.  I do wish they had a fatter toro or mirugai since those are my favorites but I think overall they had a pretty fair selection for place of this size which is only open 3 nights a week.  This place is amazing bang for your buck, it almost feels like there has to be a mistake and you are robbing them or something.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
If you don't look carefully, you can drive by this small restaurant in the Richmond district of the city. Nestled next to a supermarket, Okina has some of the best sushi I have ever tasted. Due to it being tiny, it's best to make a reservation, as if the place is full, you ail be turned away.

Our waitress was quick to seat us, provide menus and tea. After ordering a couple rolls, she shook her head at us and put in our order. We were definitely confused, whether she meant we ordered too much or too little. It was hard to tell, especially considering how inexpensive everything was. Our sushi arrived only ten minutes later. The pieces are on the smaller side, so we realized we had not ordered enough. After devouring the sushi, we ordered a few more rolls and sashimi pieces.

Honestly, what most stood out to me was the yellowtail sashimi. It just melted in my mouth, like it did when I was living in Japan. You must must must get sashimi here.

The food was delicious. Our service was great. A very quiet and intimate restaurant. What more could you want?
author: Saroya W.

description:
Most authentic sushi bars I go to usually the sushi chef is more quiet and serious, and the waitress is more friendly and outgoing, but at Okina it was the opposite.  I'm not blaming the waitress, like many authentic ethnic restaurants if you're not one of them and it's your first time there they won't take you seriously, but the chef was nice enough to seat me at his bar, and the waitress eventually warmed up to me because I ordered omakase, and she was impressed how I ate the nigiri by using my fingers instead of chopsticks, and by turning the nigiri upside down and placing the sashimi part on my tounge.

The chef was like a polite robot.  Moving like a machine and every time he placed something in front of me he would say "hai, arigato ogozaimasu, thank you sir".  Later on he got to know me a little and was smiling and laughing.  Like I mentioned  before the waitress was telling how impressed she was with my sushi knowledge.  I gave them it was $42.00 for omakase and tamago, VERY CHEAP.  I gave them a large tip, and the waitress rushed over and pulled out the chair for me as I was getting up.


RESTAURANT RULES:

1) Cash only, if you don't have cash then you can use the ATM inside Arguello Market next door.

2) They do accept reservations.  That way you don't have to show up extra early.

3) On their door it says their hours are Thu, Fri, and Sat from 5PM - 9PM, CLOSED ON SUNDAY, MONDAY, TUESDAY, AND WEDNESDAY.

Overall Okina is a good, simple old fashioned sushi bar, no large sake lists, small fish selection, and as I mentioned before VERY CHEAP AND GOOD, and I LOVE IT!
author: Rudi A.

description:
I've once went here before with a couple of friends, we tried various nigiri and sashimi rolls. I love how the rice goes so well with the fresh fish! This little small place is perfect for a date, because it's so quiet! I would only recommend this place if you enjoy the simple taste of traditional sushi.... It is something different than your usual sushi places in SF like Kitaro, or San Mateo's Sushiritto and Old Town Sushi. There ain't no Lion King or Mountain rolls here! Just simple and freshly served traditional sushi ---- Enjoy sushi at its finest  without any special extra stuff.

And the chef has the brightest personality yet! You sure can tell how passionate he is with making sushi.

AND OH YES, be sure to reserve a spot, especially with groups.
author: Angela L.

description:
Don't know why you would give this place a bad rating.
Don't be fooled by the bad two bad reviews near the top of the page.   Sushi-boats it is not.  The food is simple, clean and tasty.  Don't expect flash, just good quality sushi with imported fish from Japan.  Only open a few days a week and only has two employees.  Keeping it simple personified.  If you are expecting fifty different rolls to choose from, skip it.  If you want simple good sushi, go for it.  Call for reservations.
author: Leon S.

description:
Okina has been open for over 30 years in the same location. Clearly they are doing something right!  The place has a great homey feel and the sushi chef is a sweet man. I would come here all the time if I lived close by.

It's just sushi, quite traditional sushi. No crazy rolls, no giant sushi that can't fit in your mouth in one bit. It's just fresh fish and rice. What can be better than that? Didn't make a dent in my wallet either.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Annoying attitude, ridiculous reservation policy (you would think they are the French Laundry of sushi bars) and pre cut sushi in a case.The quality of the fish was disappointing. What decent sushi bar serves pre cut fish?? 

The photos of the food on Yelp bear no resemblance to what we were served! We ordered the Omakase which was a joke. Nothing but ordinary items served with an indifferent attitude.

After reading the glowing reviews on Yelp, I really thought we were in the wrong place. We sat at the sushi bar and the "chef" acted like he was doing us a favor by serving us! He actually made us feel unwelcome.  Don't waste your time on this less than mediocre sushi bar.
author: S W.

description: I came here on a Thursday night after work with a girlfriend; she just moved in right around the corner so we were excited to explore. It's definitely a unique sushi experience. It's authentic; no bells and whistles, just a very simple and traditional menu. It's a very small place, we were lucky to come in before it got really busy. All but one table were reserved and we were lucky to snag it. Plan ahead, cash only. Overall, good experience. Go for high quality fish, not for fancy, rice heavy, rolls.
author: A L.

description:
They get 3.5 
Really cute hole in the wall, felt like I was transported to Japan. I sat at the sushi bar and the sushi chef was very nice and had a calm demeanor. There are no specialty rolls at this place, only sashimi, nigiri, hand rolls, and 6 piece basic rolls. My friend was raving about how cheap it was so we ordered up a storm! I liked the Hamachi, Smoked Salmon, Tuna Nigiris the best. Problem, I HATE wasabi!! and I got a huge mouth full of wasabi not knowing he stuck in in the rolls! EWW!! That ruined my taste buds for the rest of the night and I was afraid I would bite into more wasabi. What turned me off the bill at the end, $85!! for the 2 of us. Damn don't come when you are starving!
author: Karen T.

description:
Solid 4 stars. Fresh fish. Good rice. Cold Beer.

FOOD -- Omakase onegaishimasu! I told the chef that I ate everything, but prefer to not have squid.
Rice, wasaaabi, fish: the way nigiri should be made!

We went through 12 orders of nigiri. In no particular order: hamachi, amaebi, unagi, ikura, tobiko, maguro, smoked salmon, hotate, amberjack, hirame, saba, and kani.

SERVICE -- Sit at the counter. The old man is awesome to talk to. The crowd at the bar was great that night, and we each got a few freebies -- nothing big, but we had some cut of the tuna and tamago.

PRICE -- For what I got, I left with $38 pre-tax/pre-tip - pretty darn full and happy with all the variety. I read somewhere that the chef wants to provide the freshest fish at the best price possible - San Francisco's version of Jiro-san!

NOTES -- Good for small groups, but best at the bar with a buddy.

CONCLUSION -- Great unpretentious, traditional, no-frills sushi with a fun chef. Learn some Japanese, eat, drink, be merry!
author: Stanley L.

description:
Josh K couldn't have said it better... this is a shrine of sushi in SF.  In short its everything you would expect of a serious sushi restaurant straight out of Japan.  Serious... quiet and small, but friendly with some of the best Sushi you are going to find around the area.

   This isn't  your standard sushi restaurant.  Its not bustling and loud with your standard sushi fare and standard sushi patron.  No this is something entirely different.  Think of a place for those whose truly appreciate good sushi and the atmosphere that comes with it.  That is what you will find here and nothing more.

   You pretty much have to get a reservation to this place so don't forget that.  The bill is very reasonable for what you will get here.  You will not be disappointed here... ever.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I went here with my husband while vacationing in San Francisco. It was delightful!  We were able to make reservations, which was nice. We sat at the counter and enjoyed the quiet, back-to-basics vibe of the restaurant.  We ordered omakase and got five or six different pairs sushi pieces.  The fish was just perfect.  This was our first experience with what I understand is a traditional sushi restaurant.  The chef made it in front of us and placed it directly on the wooden bar.  We picked it up and ate it with our hands. It was exciting to think that we were finally "doing it right."  

The chef and waitress were cheerful and friendly.  We ended up ordering several more pieces of fish enjoyed with bottomless tea.  We left feeling pleasantly full and relaxed.  

IMPORTANT NOTE: The restaurant is cash only.
author: Mary N.

description:
HUGE plus for this restaurant: YOU CAN MAKE RESERVATIONS. Not like the other pretentious sushi restaurant nearby where you have to wait in line for 2 hours...

My boyfriend and I went to eat at Okina after watching Jiro Dreams of Sushi.  I thought it was awesome that the chef looked like Jiro (bald, Japanese with glasses) :)

The restaurant is run by the Japanese chef and his wife. Reviews were right about it being VERY quiet inside. At times I felt like everyone could hear our conversation, but at the same time it didn't matter since it made us focus more on the food and our experience eating it.

We sat at the sushi bar, which I liked a lot. Mainly because I could watch the chef making the sushi, and also because we were talking to him a lot of the time. At the sushi bar there is a wooden bar in front of you and the chef puts your sushi directly onto it as your order.  I ordered in Japanese and he was surprised that I could speak, and that got us talking about lots of other random stuff. The chef is such a nice guy, very friendly, patient, and made delicious sushi!
