Overall we had a GREAT experience at Okina. The prices were VERY reasonable. $4.50 for Uni! We spent as much as we would've spent at say Isobune, but with 10x more fresh sushi, and wayy better experience.

Next time we're craving sush -- real sushi -- we will definitely be coming back to Okina :)
author: Gina R.

description: Ate here for the first time last night. Menu is basic, but the food is fresh and delicious! I mean, really, really good.  It's also fairly priced. Really cannot say enough about it! It's a tiny place, not much by way of ambience. Cash only.
author: Midori H.

description:
This place is seriously a shrine of sushi. You go in and there is a counter seating about 5 or 6 people. Other than that there's only two or three tables in the whole damn place. And it is almost as quiet as a church inside. I actually felt a little embarassed because I came with my polite though sometimes rowdy usual crowd of friends and I knew I wouldn't be able to stop the "that's what she said" jokes from shooting across the table. Luckily I don't think the itamae is terribly great at contemporary English mannerisms and he didn't really catch on -- or he didn't care.

Hot tea was great, sake was solid but basically just OK, that's not what you come here for. Of course, you come for the sushi.

5 of us all ordered Chef's Omakase, 9 pieces or so and the price was very reasonable, $25 a head. Each piece was divine. We then ordered some more sushi combos to sate the rest of our hunger (and my hungrier friend got a chirashi box for herself -- she said it was good.) After a couple rounds of sake and some beer it was still only about $35-40 a person after tax and tip. Pretty amazing especially considering the great experience we had.

I'll be returning regularly to my new sushi shrine.
author: Josh K.

description: Minimalist, delicious, and fresh! Yeah, it's no Japan so stop with your foodie high expectation BS, kids. It's reasonably priced, gets the job done, and the ambiance is simply serene. I'm not overwhelmed by crazy fried cream cheese with a cherry on top sushi options. The place is modest, humble, unpretentious, just perfect. One chef, one server, about 5 tables and a bar. If you're smart, you'll make a reservation ahead of time and bring plenty of cash.
author: Lisa N.

description:
This is a quiet, old-school, inexpensive sushi place.  A great place to come if you don't need any fancy rolls.  The sushi was fresh, tasty, and well-balanced.  There was only one itamae, and he was really attentive and wonderful.  

Don't come here if you want teriyaki or dragon rolls!  Come if you want tasty reasonably priced traditional sushi in a small quiet setting.
author: Go S.

description:
Been going here for 5+ years now and will continue to return when in the area. The sushi is simple, fresh and satisfying. NO frills and mayo-ness here! The sushi chef (awesome) is also the owner of this small place. 

Seats no more then 6 at the bar and about 4 small tables ranging between 2-4 seats. Making sure you have reservations is key. The only two downsides are lack of parking and limited time availability. (They are only open Thurs-Sat from 5pm-10pm) Though that won't stop me from returning. I love this place.
author: Jess N.

description: Not impressed. It's the only sushi spot I've been to that has pre-cut fish in the display case. The quality of fish was poor, the service was meh, and we left in shock that such a highly rated place could be such a major disappointment, and so over priced to boot. The authentic appearance is wildly deceiving. Save your money and your taste buds and go to Yuubi down the street--the exterior may look cheesy but the quality, price and experience is infinitely better.
author: Julia H.

description: Just tried to get seated here and was denied service. Open seats in the place that weren't reserved. However another couple walked in and was promptly seated when we left. Terrible service. Thanks for not wanting my service
author: Ian B.

description: I lived in Japan for seven years and I was impressed by the quality of the sushi considering the price point. I found it very affordable and offered a great look into what real sushi should be like in America. Preparation skills aside not all ingredients can feasibly come from Japan. The Japanese owner and chef, living here now for over 30 years, prepared foods at the sushi bar with only one waitress in the entire restaurant. On a busy night this was nothing less than amazing, but I could see how in someways service suffered. I would easily go here again or try to make this my go to sushi place.
author: Matt P.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying that after my girlfriend and I had our fill of Okina -- 11 "courses" of nigiri at less than $60 before tip (what a deal!) -- we... went to KFC/Taco Bell.

We left fairly full but not satiated.

Thursday evening, 2 of us sitting at the bar, omakase as usual.  The rice was a little looser and colder than I would've liked and the fish was good.. enough.  Well, it wasn't rancid.  Out of the 11 things we had -- amberjack, tuna, smoked salmon, ami ebi, uni, ikura, squid, 2 types of mackeral and i forget the rest - none were really tasty except for the amberjack which was paired with a shiso leaf.  I'm a sucker for anything with shiso.

I liked the prices.  We got out of there for less than $60 and that included a large Asahi split between us.

I really like the sushi chef; he's much more amicable, friendly and KID-friendly than either Ino or Hama-ko (who is notoriously kid UNfriendly).  However, I would still rate Ino and Hama-Ko as the top traditional sushi restaurants that I've tried in SF.   Maybe stick Yu Zen in there as a definite 3rd.

Unfortunately, I would probably even go to Zushi Puzzle, Kiss, Sushi Zone or Koo (yes, I'm know I'm mixing up my sub-genres here) before I come back to Okina as my experience, while pleasant enough, did not meet my expectations for good rice, flavorful and fresh fish or at least something to excite my taste buds.
author: Brian T.

description: If you've seen that Jiro Dreams of a Sushi documentary, this is the SF version. Simple in every regard. But the sushi has flavors complex and bountiful.
author: Noah D.

description: Was refused service when there were plenty of open seats. The lady was very rude and it is apparent they pick and choose who they seat. Don't waste your time.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
My new fave sushi place in the city!  I can't believe I never knew about this place before.  It's a small hole in the wall place with two tables and a sushi bar that seats 7 people.  I heard from a couple of people that the fish was really fresh and that I should check it out.  The menu is very simple - nigiri, sashimi, simple rolls, and a few drinks (sake, beer, and tea).  The best part is the PRICE for the quality you get...wait for it...let me first tell you what I ordered...

Nigiri - Amberjack, Mackerel, Hamachi, Scallop, Squid, Smoked Salmon, Uni

Sashimi - Scallop, Squid, Hamachi

Rolls - Salmon Skin roll, Unagi roll

Large hot sake - one order

Guess how much...a whopping total of $56!!!  Unbelievable, an order of sashimi cost the same as an order of the nigiri for the same finish.  The Chef and his wife are both really nice.  

Make sure you make reservations ahead of time and bring cash! :)
author: Sandy L.

description: Make reservations a day or two in advance and try to get seats at the sushi bar for great presentation of food and conversation with the chef!
author: Timothy L.

description:
Reservation? Check
Early in the evening so they can't run out of the good stuff? Check
Restaurant half empty so the chef doesn't feel rushed? Check
Omakase? Check
So a setup for an ideal meal, right? Wrong.
Fish was just ok. Rice was COLD. It felt like it was a platter prepared earlier in the day. At Safeway. I got suckered in by the potential positives: small, mom & pop, hole-in-the-wall sushi place, a yelp reviewer compared it to Ino (one of my favs), specializing in only sushi/sashimi... Bottom line: Avoid.
author: CHi C.

description:
No frills, sushi & sashimi only type joint. I think this is what we might call "authentic." No sriracha!! Not a good place to go as a vegetarian, or someone who likes any sort of salad or anything extra along with a a few rolls. The menu is tiny, but the fish is fresh and everything is prepared perfectly.

The place is also tiny. They do take reservations though, and it seems like you can generally get in if you try. I honestly couldn't figure out the hostesses method to turning people away or letting them stay...I guess she just has a good system in her head...

I recommend coming here at least once. It sucks that it's in the avenues...
author: Caitlin H.

description:
I love their Lion King Roll and their cream cheese Philly roll and their other sauce drenched baked/fried/blahblah roll. 

Oh wait none of that exists here at Okina Sushi. This is a tiny and homely sushi restaurant. There is nothing fancy about this place. A few tables set up and a sushi bar. There is only one sushi chef. I liken him to a master artisan, diligently and purposefully working on his master craft. 

The menu is simple. Minimalist. By the pure simplicity of the menu, you can tell that the emphasis of the food here is on the freshness of the fish. What a odd and novel concept. 

Sashimi. Nigiri. Sushi. That pretty much sums up their entire menu. Every item is under $5. The main ingredients are fish, rice and seaweed wrap. That's it. 

This place doesn't win you over with its gimmicks. It's just simple food from a simple place.
author: Allan Y.

description:
I awake from my Yelp slumber!!! MUAHAHAH.

How to keep this short and sweet...

If you want to sit at a for reals table, I believe you need to make a reservation, otherwise, you sit at the bar in front of the chef.  It's not a bad seat, but just an FYI.

Selection is very simple and small.

Fish is SUPER fresh. Had the tuna, halibut, yellow tail, mackarel, amberjack (VERY buttery), CA roll, hamachi roll, and tuna roll.

The size of each piece is lackluster...meaning that I am pretty sure I can stuff all the pieces of the CA roll and half of another roll in my mouth or maybe two full rolls if I were ambitious enough. However, the quality of the fish makes up for it.  True, some may say it's bland, but you really get to taste the texture and the fine qualities each piece of fish has to offer.

Small and cozy place. Overall, a very nice experience.  Seems like you'd have to spend a lot to get full though or maybe I'm just a lard ass. :T 

I'd suggest that this is a place for a small and light dinner. I was feeling extra healthy and pretending to fulfill a resolution that night and we sampled about $30 worth of sushi.  It all went down the hole because we ended up attending what I would like to call - second dinner.  Then proceeded to stuff my face.
author: Dolores L.

description:
I've hesitated to write a review for Okina because, quite selfishly, I want to keep the secret all to myself.  But I owe my fellow Yelpers, so I'll admit it - this is the best sushi bar in the country.

That doesn't come lightly.  I've been to Japan several times and have been to the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo at 5am for fresh sushi; and as I write, I'm on a plane coming from from NYC where I've been to many of the top sushi restaurants.  Okina blows them all away.

I don't even know where to begin, so this is a random list.

Positives:
-- The sushi chef.  While his English is broken, he's a pleasure to chat with.  He shared that he's been in the business for over 30 years and doesn't do it for the money.  In fact, we tried to convince him to raise prices and expand, and he just smiled.  He does it for the love of the art.
-- The sushi.  Fish is flown in daily or weekly from Japan.  We asked why not use local fish, and he just smiled.  He said he knows exactly where he wants his fish from, and does not deviate. Because of this, they are only open 3 nights a week for only a few hours each night
-- The atmosphere.  Very cozy and intimate, feels quite authentic.
-- The staff.  Errr, the one server.  She is very friendly and has also been working there for years.
-- The soy sauce.  I hesitate to share, as the chef was pleased to tell us the secret, but even the soy sauce is custom made by the chef.  He finds most soy sauce too salty and overpowering.  His version is delicious.
-- Price.  I feel guilty paying what we pay.  I always let the chef choose (Omakase) and it never comes out to more than $40/each, and you can easily fill up for $20.  The Sake is very cheap, I don't remember how much, but it was less than $10 for a bottle, I believe.  It's just stunning.  In NYC this experience would cost easily $150 (in fact, the place I was just at was $120 for the Omakase and drinks were $16 each).  Such an amazing deal!!
 
Negatives:
-- Parking can be tough to find.  The best bet is not to try finding it on the little streets (everything you think is a spot is either a cross walk or driveway) and go straight for Fulton St.
-- Hard to get reservations.  It's small, so plan in advance.  Not good for large groups, unfortunately, max is 4 people.
author: Greg B.

description: THIS PLACE IS SOLID. yeah
author: Paul K.

description: Things have turned around 180 degrees! This is now one of our favorite places!! The sushi is delicious and now that we know the procedures, it is easy to get same-day reservations!
author: William L.

description:
Lets be real, very few things in life are authentic.  
dimple insertions, fake id names for online dating, the list run long like the New York marathon.

So when I discover something authentic, there are only two choices. you either hoard the hidden gem, or share it with the world. hoping that someone had the very same great experience.

Introduce from fellow Yelper Teresa N, I did not know what to expect.  
With my jazz hands I tango through the sushi house.  It is cozy... even barren.  The minimalist decor allows the patrons and the chef to play center stage.

dashing toward the sushi bar at our reserved seat, me and my Shanghai date pause only to hear our own breathing.

this is the part where I make my disclosure.  If you're looking for an energy pack rock concert dining experience, quickly flag a cab and head over to the likes of Blowfish Sushi.  Instead, Okina is a sushi house.

Charm does not come from vibrant music or attractive female waitresses  
"May I help you gentleman" ...

Instead, the vibe is a sanctuary.  With a full bar and attentive ears, easily I can over hear conversation.  

Starting the show, greetings from the master chef.  With chiseled face, bald head, he resembled a samurai.  

starting off with saba, a vinegar cured fish with a strong fish taste 
The chef offered three kinds ranging from salty, well.. .to more salty. 
The three versions reminded me of an ascending salty note on a piano.

Served directing on the sushi board, the nigiri pieces displayed the incredible knife skills.  Each piece of nigiri has smooth finishing cuts.
Not since my food journey in Tokyo, have I found a sushi house.

Continuing my curious journey,
With vibrant yellow tones, the uni (sea urchin) was creamy with sea sweet tones.  

Skip the maguro (tuna). The slice was thin and lacked character.  Stealing the show, the hamachi (yellowtail) is worth another order.  Just one bite, the buttery fish reminds me why raw fish is worth eating.

All the while I consume fresh fish, the chef tells stories.  Reminding me of my grandfather, he told stores about World War II.  

Not knowing that Japanese history channel was on the menu, I enjoyed his stories.  Somehow, this adds charm.  In a culinary world where most meals lack connection to the owner, the experience was refreshing.

Aside from being the sushi chef, he played the role of story teller and comedian.  Sure, I did not get all his jokes, but who is complaining when my palate was being stimulated constantly.

Finish the meal with Kani (crab roll).  For a buttery and sweet combination, the unagi (eel) does the trick.  

For a taste of a classic sushi house, Okina hits the spot.  For an authentic Japanese spot that adds a more hip hop charm, Hime is a great choice.

Note: I attached a photo of the menu for pricies
Enjoy Yelpers
author: Rayfil W.

description:
You've got to respect a restaurant that is all about authentic dining.  Okina Sushi is a no frills sushi restaurant but it delivers where it counts - the food.  The menu is tiny, minuscule really, but it is beautifully straightforward.  Okina offers nigiri, sashimi, hand rolls, and maki rolls . . . and that's pretty much it.  Whatever fish the chef has on hand that day is what is being served . . . and on my visit it all seemed quite fresh.  

The great thing about Okina is its prices . . . which are really reasonable (like $3 for two pieces of saba nigiri).  The downside is the place is cash only and is only open Thursday-Saturday.  If there is room, don't miss the opportunity to sit at the sushi bar; sitting there definitely enhances the Okina experience.
author: Oski B.

description: This is sushi like you have never had before, and the setting is intimate!! Always get the omakase (chef's special selection) and sit at the bar for the full experience
author: Caitlin T.

description:
Simply my favorite shushi restaurant !

A minimalist restaurant were the focus is on food and friendly customer service.  The chef is the nicest guy ever who works magic with those hands. You gotta love this guy. There is also one really cute waitress who is excellent.  You gotta love the girl.  You gotta love this restaurant.

Sushi bar is the best way to enjoy your experience here.  Try the omakase, and sit back and let the chef plop his creations right on the counter. Fantastic quality and service for the price. 

In fact, it was so good I am still enjoying the sushi smell on my paws (fingers) as I write this review.  :p
author: Gregory C.

description: Finally got to try this place after not being able to twice because we didn't have a reservation. Made a reservation and loved every bite of it. Make sure you love nigiri and sashimi for the most part because they specialize mostly in plain ol' FRESH FISH!!!! I will definitely be back again.
author: Colin B.

description: One of my all time favorite sushi spots in sf, straight up sushi, none of that fried or specialty made up rolls.  Love it.  If you like sashimi this is your spot, otherwise you should head toward the marina and get your sf volcano mango philly rolls there.
author: christopher h.

description:
If you want just good ole' simple good quality sushi, Okina is your place. 
The seafood was so fresh that there was no fish smell. The seafood literally tasted soft and buttery, as if it was caught that day.  

Besides the sushi being absolutely delish, the place was clean and quiet...you could actually hear the dinner conversation.  My new favorite sushi place.
author: N S.

description:
This place is amazing. They serve nigiri or sashimi only, don't have any fancy rolls with cooked stuff in. The owner is Japanese speaking and his English is little sketchy, but he likes to talk. 
We are regular customers there and he has been so good to us and sushi's super fresh and it's ridiculously cheap. We always tip him a whole bunch. He allows us to bring our own sake, dessert, anything. 
Only opens on Thurs, Fri, Sat nights. I actually went today and he's closed for the year.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Maybe the nay-sayers came on off days, maybe they expected something different, or maybe they're over dramatic food snobs, because Okina is fantastic. 

A real sushi place, it's a very small hole in the wall sushi bar, fitting maybe 20 people at most. The fish is caught fresh daily and expertly prepared by the same chef as it has been for the past 20 years: Aki. Don't expect extravagance, expect only real sushi and a real experience.
author: Nathaniel R.

description:
For some reason I feel like I must have visited Okina on one of its off nights. Not saying that things weren't good, but not as good as I'd expected. The nigiri didn't pack as much flavor as other sashimi I had, some piece were actually kind of bland which was the main reason for my disappointment.

BF and I went for Omakase (chefs picks) so we sat at the bar. THe chef was nice and the staff were friendly. The place is also tiny so if you want to have dinner here I definitely recommend making reservations in advance.

What I liked: 
- This place is strickly sushi, they don't have a kitchen so don't expect to be able to order chicken teriyaki here
- Sitting at the bar, the chef gives you little bits of extra sashimi sometimes
- Their ameibi and white tuna were good and memorable
author: Nicole L.

description:
Best sushi in the richmond in my opinion! Beware okina sushi is strictly japanese style- very fresh, very simple- and you won't find a crazy deep-fried spider roll anywhere on their 1 page menu. I always end up at okina starving & it takes a ton of their tiny rolls to fill me up. i recommend sharing two of their plates (which give a variety of fish) & then ordering other rolls/sashimi to try. yum!

*make reservations!*
author: K T.

description:
Okina is a hidden gem. Come here if you are looking for good sashimi and sushi for really cheap! Yup, you will definitely get your bang for your buck. We had an assortment of sashimi -- hamachi, maguro, toro, smoked salmon, etc. 

The sushi chef is also really friendly and kept saying "thank you" every 5 seconds ;)

Thank YOU!
author: Helen Y.

description:
I love that this easy-to-miss place is in my hood.  I swear, I've walked by this place a ga-bazillion times and never knew Okina was here!  We came here one Friday night and luckily, it it was not busy.  We were greeted by a quiet and sweet waitress and the chef was busy behind the sushi bar.  Good signs so far!

The menu was simple, fish looked amazingly fresh and prices were reasonable.  If you're looking for a lavish spread, look elsewhere.  This is sushi at its purist!  We ordered a good portion of the menu and everything tasted as if it was fished right out of the ocean and prepared for our sushi craving pallates!  We even tried the sea urchin.  It was definitely something to try, but not to try again.

Sake and beer is also a must.  They serve the sake with lil cups resembling mini teacups that I used to use for tea parties.  Cute!  We got a lil drunkie and literally stumbled ourselves home.  Not so cute...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I loved this place. Not just for the incredibly fresh sushi, but for the company of the cutest Japanese chef alive who had stories on end about the history of his prized restaurant. I ordered the omakase + a few more other choice pieces of toro, oyster, and uni, and melted happily into a sashimi wonderland. The best part? The total price for ton of sushi (2 omakases + more) came about to about $75. Trust me, we ate WAY more than $75 worth.

Okina is only open on weekends starting on Thursdays, so make your reservations now!
author: Genevieve W.

description:
*
                               **The following takes place** 
                           **between 9:00 PM and 10:00 PM** 
  (re-instating a classic from June 09 and a tribute to the series finale) 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                                             _____________
                                             |  OKINA SUSHI |
                                             -----------------------
----------------------------        =============       ------------------------------
|                                   |       |   come |     in      |       |                                    |
|                                   |       |   for      |  sushi  |       |                                    | 
|                                   |       | ~~~~~~~~~~~~|       |                                    |
|____________  __|        |                            |       ------------------------------
                                             |                            |
                                            =============

Three distinguished officers from CPU (Counter Pseudo-Sushi Unit) took a break from pursuing nucular threats, government agency betrayals, corporate pirate fraud charges, investigating corruption in government bailout and hostile takeovers of the sushi fish supply distribution systems etc, descended upon a local favorite watering (or should I say "fish") hole inbetween all that work and BS, to map out their next strategy.

           Chef owner Matsuoka Akio, one of the nicest chefs you 
            will  ever meet.
                                                     \
                                                      \                                           
                                                       O 
                                                       /|\           
                                     =================
                                          x  x      x x     x x--- sushi directly on the counter
names                              O       O        O       Bam Bam Bam!
changed to                       /|\       /|\        /|\       laid down very quickly
protect the                        | |       | |        | |       Emril Lagasse style     
innocent                           /          |               \                     
                                       /             |                 \
                                 Agent      "Jive"              \
                                 Doyle       Bauer       Director Furoyo from CPU Japan

The meeting contained confidential exchanges, but their enemies were able to wire tap some of the conversations.

Bauer: "Repeat, repeat, the owner looks like a cross between the Dalai Lama and Robin Williams! (Mork and Mindy era) 27 years in the business and still going strong! Armed with a knife, experienced, proceed with caution! You, cover the left side of the building! I'm going in!"

Furoyo: "The owner looks so young!"

Doyle: "hmm-mm, and sexay too!"

Bauer: "WTF, WE NEED A RESERVATION IN HERE NOW!!! We're losing our table!"

Cute young waitress from Hokkaido puts down some tea cups.

                                                     **9:09:57**

                                                     **9:09:58**

                                                    **9:09:59**

                                                   **09:10:00** 

                                             COMMERICAL BREAK

The officers then proceeded with:

Maguro
Saba
Hirame w/ shiso
Aji
Ika
Saba sashimi
Hamachi
Uni
Tekka maki

At various points of the meal, Jive Bauer had some momentary lapses in sanity upon consuming the nigiri sushi.

First piece of maguro nigiri, the sushi rice tasted very different from other places, could not figure out why. 

Ika (squid) was dressed exactly like most unagi...spread of slightly sweet sauce and sesame seeds. Ikagi? Unaka? Bauer started to go crazy.

The saba made him increasingly horny, it must be the stronger salt accent, oily texture$, and one of the strongest highlights of the night. Then again, the dirt cheap how-the-f**k-does-the-old-man-make-a-profit prices could be the overriding culprit. 

"Hmmmm looks like pre-sliced fish", thought Bauer.

"Who gives a f**k, this $h!t is cheaper than the competition anywhere else!", concluded Bauer. "So cheap,so downschool! DAMMIT!!!!!!"

                                                     **9:59:57**

                                                     **9:59:58**

                                                     **9:59:59**

                                                   **10:00:00** 
         
                                                     **BURP!**
author: Ken K.

description:
I absolutely love this place. It was seriously a hole-in-the-wall and sat roughly 15 people max.... Or maybe 20? 

My friend and I got seated right in front of the chef. Everything we ordered, he would lean over the counter and place right in front of us. The fish was SO FRESH. We only ordered nigiri and everything came in pairs. I enjoyed every nigiri after nigiri. It just kept coming!!

I learned that we aren't suppose to each nigiri sushi with chopsticks, but with hands. Apparently that's the authentic Japanese way to do it. 

Love it! Try it!
author: Rosanne L.

description: Strictly a sushi restaurant, Okina is a very small, neighborhood sushi restaurant operated by the sushi chef and waitress. Menu is very simple with the typical rolls and nigiris. I went for the omakase where the chef chooses what you have. From sea urchin to toro, all the sushi tasted very fresh and high quality. It almost feels as if you are eating at a sushi restaurant in a village in Japan. Prices are very reasonable compared to other sushi restaurants in SF. Be aware they have no kitchen so do not expect Bento boxes or Teriyaki dishes.
author: Ed L.

description: Great sushi, but horrible customer service. They won't take you if its 30 minutes to closing because they don't want you to keep them late, even though on average we are done in 20 minutes (I told her this), then they try to say it's because they are almost out of fish. Another time when I was eating there I over heard the woman take a couple to go orders and even one from someone who walked in. One day on my way home I stopped in to get to go and was scolded then felt so uncomfortable that I have made my visits less and less. I use to frequent okina and every time I was made to feel like I wasn't wanted. My husband and I tip well too as we both used to work in the service industry; Really think the woman is racist
author: Roxanne M.

description:
Don't know how this place has 4 stars.  Except it is nice and clean on the inside and they give you green tea.

Got the omakase.  nothing was that good.  presentation wasn't good.   cuts of fish didn't look or taste good.   variety was the bare minimum.

yelp fail...
author: Steven F.

description: Best sushi you will ever eat in your life! Call in advance to reserve your table and savor every bite!
author: Tashina G.

description:
I think I would come here a lot if I lived nearby. It's very bare-bone, no cooked dishes, the only hot thing you will get here is a cup of green tea! But..I like!

You have standard options of fish, but it's only open Thursday-Saturday, so expect good quality fish! The sushi chef is super cute and friendly, and at 67, he's got quite a lot of energy!

I want to come here again! The nigiris were good. Not the top quality like Ino and Koo but the best prices out there for nigiris!

1.) Food taste  - 4 stars
Good sushi

2.) Cleanliness, freshness - 4.5 stars
Very good, he only goes to the fish market 3 times a week and opens 3 times a week so expect fresh fish, and nothing sitting out for long!!

3.) Presentation - 4 stars
Very simple yet authentic, but no frills and fancy shmancyness.

4.) Location/price - 5!!!! stars
The location is a bit hidden, so it's kind of funky, but you can't top the prices here.... $2.30-$5 per pair of nigiri? What the? !!!! :)

5.) Service - 5 stars
Top notch, friendly people, fast.

Overall a great experience
author: Veronica S.

description: So good! Limited/basic menu... But awesome prices! Everything was really really fresh, service was good, and the atmosphere is great. Very traditional hole I the wall mom/pop sushi shop! Will go again and again and again!
author: A S.

description:
Simple Menu! No fancy rolls.  Just like the ones in Japan. Make reservation.  This place is tiny restaurant with only three tables and 5 bar seats, and they do turn people down.  

The fishes are super fresh.  When we sat down, we saw the bar was full of fishes, and by the time we left, the fishes were mostly gone.   You know the fishes are fresh if they sell everything out!  

Will come back for true Japanese sushi!  

And for the amount we ate, it was cheap!
author: Deb L.

description:
2 stars. 

Came for a late Friday night dinner. Ordered the omakase, but had to supplement because we didn't feel it was enough food.  The fish seemed fresh, I just really didn't appreciate what they did with it--the salmon nigiri was smoked salmon (bleh), the tuna nigiri was covered in some sort of fruity-tasting sauce (meh) and the unagi nigiri was covered in some sort of weird spice (eh).

The place was so quiet, it was like eating in a library. The service was kind of absent (the tea cups were empty for a while before the waitress noticed, we had to ask for water two times before she brought it even though we were only one of three parties, etc.).

I'll definitely pass on a second opportunity to come here.
author: Nora G.

description:
Fans of Okina Sushi please don't hate but this place was lame... I just ate there 10 minute ago and this review is more fresh than the fish. true story.

Atmosphere:

It's tiny intimate place which wasn't bad but there wasn't any noise at all. I felt like I was in an empty gym and my chewing was echoing off the walls... a little music would be nice, or even if the chef hummed while preparing the food. I would even appreciate the wooshing sound of a fan to spice things up a bit but no... it was silent. kinda awkward...

Sushi: 

I'm not a sushi snob by any means but I don't see what the big deal is. Sushi was average. I am currently trying to get the Unagi bones out of my throat... Why can't we have regular salmon? Smoked salmon doesn't seem very Japanese but maybe I'm just uneducated... The selection was very limited and I now realize that the reason they are only open 3 days a week is because the sushi chef spends the off days cutting everything into small, individually sliced portions... 

Anyway, won't be coming back here.
author: Phil W.

description:
Do make a reservation! I was sad to see many a diner turned away because most of the seats were already occupied or reserved. 

Bf and I sat at the bar, which was delightful. I loved watching the sushi chef meticulously make sushi and plop it down on the wooden counter in front of us. 

We ordered what felt like nigiri after nigiri (a la carte) and finished off with the special, which was raw oyster. I've never had oyster as a part of nigiri before, but it was extremely refreshing and a great way to top off our meal.

I loved the amaebi, which we actually ordered by happy accident because the chef misheard us. Best mistake ever. 

All of the fish was very fresh, the rice was at perfect temperature, and the service was fantastic.

Also plus points for the quiet and peaceful ambiance and a great dining companion. 

Oh and the price was not bad at all! I was actually quite nervous upon the arrival of our bill because I felt like we just kept ordering and ordering but with tip it came out to around $20/person which in my experience is great value for fresh sushi. 

Okina has a simple elegance that is quite rare and makes for an excellent dining experience.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Sat at the bar for a quick bite to eat. 

Restaurant is really tiny and so are the menu options. I was a little disappointed that for a sushi bar whose tagline is to be authentic, they didn't have fresh salmon or toro available. 

But everything else about the restaurant is pretty solid. For the bar, it's kinda neat that they just place all the pickles/ginger/sushi right on the slanted wooden bar. Extra star for that, felt really authentic. 

 - amberjack: rice and fish with a slice of shiso leaf inbetween
 - hamachi: topped with scallions and tobiko
 - tuna
 - scallops
 - California roll: kinda small but was yummy
 - salmon skin roll: not enough crispy skin

decent portions and fair prices. Just grade your expectations for the small place and small menu.
author: Ray J.

description: If you want traditional sushi, this is the place! Very very good! Everything is same day fresh!!! Owners are wonderful people!!! Tip: make reservation :)
author: Zoah Z.

description:
To preface: I live right around the corner from this place and Arguello supermarket.  The building is owned by the chef himself and is only open on weekends.  He is very Japanese.  I really like sushi.  All kinds.

After coming here several times over the past few years, despite genuinely wanting to like the place and food, I have come to the conclusion that I am not a fan.

The sushi bar is setup where Chef-san places your order directly onto the wooden bar along with the pickles allows lots of interaction and Chef-san can be engaging, he likes to say thank you... at the very least he has a funny accent.  But, when I go somewhere to eat the primary focus is on the food.  All else is secondary.  The food here is not very good.

He says he gets his fish fresh from Japan, don't really know the purveyor he gets his stuff from, but I'd rather eat fresh local fish than mediocre Japanese fish.  The aji on more than one occasion was a little on the unpleasantly fishy side.  Especially with an oily type of fish it is very apparent when its not fresh.  Instead of fresh salmon, he was serving smoked salmon that was lean, grainy and probably colored due to its unnatural pink hue.  The best thing I had there last time were the scallops, everything else was uniformly meh.

All the fish sits stacked pre-portioned in the case.  When it got portioned is up for debate.  I understand that it's pretty much a one man show, but when there so few customers sitting at once I'm sure cutting fish to order isn't so hard.  Plus, it adds to the experience as opposed to grab and go sushi.  It could be that he's old and can't move as fast or maybe it's just apathy, either way it doesn't make for good eats.

Not meaning to knock on the other reviewers, but really?  Five stars, four stars?  I understand that there aren't many places in the city as quaint as Okina, but that itself doesn't warrant a higher rating.  Quality sushi and fish comes at a premium and maybe Chef-san is going for the middle road but in my opinion it probably be more fun and cheaper to go to a sushi boat place instead of Okina because at least you get what you pay for.
author: Lon H.

description:
I have to admit that I came here not knowing what to expect except: you can only go with reservations and if you don't reserve, big chance that you will be denied. Exclusive I thought.

If it wasn't lit, we'd probably miss this place but when we stepped in, the atmosphere transformed to a quiet and serene sushi house. Since there was only two other patrons there, I felt kinda bad making a noisy entrance with our relatively large group shuffling our bags and belongings--it seemed like the rule was to keep noise to a minimum though we find out differently later.  

It's REAL AUTHENTIC sushi with no frills, fancy designs, or any thing cooked (other than rice and tamago) for that matter.  Everything here is straight up fresh and raw.  The rice is different from your usual sushi place but it's best eaten without soy sauce. I loveeeed their scallop.  The BF says they have one of the best and freshest Uni that he has ever tasted--actually he loved most of the fish that he ate here.  I'm not much of raw fish person but I am sold with what Chef Matsuoka Akio has to offer. 

One warning: Parking sucks, take the bus or be prepared to take a long stroll.
author: Natalie G.

description: No frills nigiris here.  It didn't feel chill though so we didn't come back.  It was super quiet and this place is pretty small.  I would handily recommend this to anyone looking for some serious nigiri action.
author: Erika C.

description:
The chef was a Hiroshima A bomb Survivor when he was 6.
At the age 7, he already has decided to work in kitchen at any restaurant because he was really hungry, there was nothing to eat in the city of Hiroshima after the A-bomb.
He thought it'll be such a GREAT IDEA to become a chef only because he can eat.
When he was 14, he went to work at a Kappo restaurant in Kyoto with No  doubt. But soon after, he realized the job wasn't as easy as he thought. 
IT WAS A VERY TOUGH JOB. 
He was there for 9 years.
In 1962, he came to US, worked as a sushi chef at the1st Japanese restaurant in Manhattan.

Anyway, ........ Back to the Sushi Goddamnit!
FXXX it!

I was with my GF and my old friend.
Having a good time.
But the chef started to talk about his life history at me.
Fine.

Okina dosen't provide many choice of fish and High-end-Sake list.
Okina is standard old school sushi with SoSo Sake.
That's another reason why I like the place.

But compared to eating Sushi at Ino in Japantown, another 5 star from me, great sushi chef in SF, great variety fish, which is such a FXXXin' religious experience, and paying 3 times more with great pressure, Okina is just comfortable, easy going, bon prix!

I had,
Maguro
Saba
Hirame with shiso
Aji
Ika
Saba sashimi
Hamachi
Uni
Tekka maki
+ small Asahi = $35.00

You don't find the price in the city.

There's no edamame, miso soup, salad, tempura or anything else that you'd expect from an AMERICAN JiveAss sushi restaurant.

Don't bother asking for edamame, tempura or teri-yuki...you won't get it...this is old school sushi, muthafuxxahs!

There is a problem to all Japo Sushi chefs in the city.
Especially Old School type Sushi bars.
They are all such a dick head.
They chose customers.
They always give good service to their favorite customers ONLY.
There is NO such thing as serving every customers equally in REAL SUSHI in Japan.
So, when the sushi chef dislike you in any way, he'll give you SHIT intentionally.
Hell yes, they do.

Sorry FXXXers.
Suck it!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Bless this place. One of the best places I've had for sushi thus far. It's also really convenient to my place. The owner/sushi chef is a master. He's had this establishment for over 25 years! 

The menu is quite traditional, as there are no rolls with a bunch of random ingredients. Not that I have anything against those type of rolls, but if you're craving fresh ingredients with a bit a simplicity, then give this place a shot. If you're brave like me, add a raw quail add to the uni - it's heaven in a bite. I drool as I write this. 

The place is small, so be sure to make reservations. Makes a great date place! :) Parking isn't all that great, so try to come earlier if possible. 

Did I also mention he's only open a couple days of the week? Only Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Guess he's doing pretty well even after all these years!
author: Kanara T.

description:
atmosphere +8
food +6 
Value +8 

Note feel like a sushi spot in japan . understand about small place you wont have much choice to buy lots of variety of fish but everything he offer on the menu is freash .. althought the rice portion is not match with the fish  kind of over amount . but you get what you paid for rice itself have a very good flavor nice well balance even tho hes using not really hight quarltily rice vinegar but hes well care about his rice temperture (notice he's using a small wooden rice container instead of a big silver one and leave all the surfece of rice to dry from air ... totally understand him on his phisophy on his business .! bringing real affortable sushi to the naborhood !
author: Chaichat N.

description:
This is the first place I ever had sushi. I was about 20, and my friend Kathleen Chan took us there. Kathleen was like a drug dealer of foodies. She'd find out we'd never had certain things and it would become her personal mandate. We'd all leave our workplace on Clement Street at about 1am, and we'd take our tea ducks, our fresh lobsters, whatever, go to someone's house and have a feast party. Those were some great days. 

Just walking into this place was an experience. It's a haven on a foggy richmond night, in fact surprising it would be there on this street. The interior  is very clean and peaceful. Kathleen ordered for me and my friend Matt, and I believe we had some simple rolls followed by tobiko nigiri with quail egg. I so wish I could be a fly on the wall now and see what we ordered and how we reacted. Extra star for the memories.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Oh, boy did I want to love this place: weird hours, run by an adorable Japanese dude who says thank you at least twentymillion times during your meal, barren walls that scream WE CANNOT DIVERT OUR ATTENTION AWAY FROM MAKING SUSHI LONG ENOUGH TO EVEN BOTHER DECORATING THE PLACE. Seems like all the ingredients for a steel cage match of hardcore sushi awesomeness. 

It's OK.

The menu is super limited, with about 9 types of fish and nothing that you can't get in an airport. That's not to say the quality isn't excellent--it is, but I hate to say that that's not very impressive to me in San Francisco. I can get excellent quality, sushi-grade fish at a half-dozen different locations. 

The three of us ordered the omakase ("chef's choice"), which is basically you saying to the chef "get creative, stretch my palate, and charge us up the ass." He did none of the above. It was the standard toro, jackfish, mackerel, and so on. But good news: it was cheap as hell.
author: J B.

description:
I'm all about doing one thing and doing it really well. What you see in Okina's fish cooler is the new West Coast's, Aaron Copeland "Rodeo" soundtracked, ad campaign - "FISH... it's what's for dinner." 
Did cowboys ever eat raw?

This place feels like the real deal, a little bit of Japan in the non-descript USF neighborhood of Lone Mountain. After entering Okina and cheerful irasshaimase's faded we were asked if we had reservations. I was impressed to see a reserved sign at the bar. I think all restaurants should use this fear/guilt-inducing tactic because immediately I thought  "damn, this place is so good I should've made a reservation. It must be a rare treat to sit at the bar."

Artificial or legit guilt aside we were quickly seated at the few remaining places at the bar. I was a tad disappointed that no hot towels were dispensed but fresh, hot, green tea made up for it. No need for plates as the chef deftly dolluped an interesting assortment of cucumber, pickle, ginger, wasabi on the clean, lacquered, wooden counter. I was cool with eating off it, but only after talking down my inner germ freak, eyeing about hopefully for a bleachy wipe-down.

The chef was perky, oldish, calm, friendly and very bald. He quietly attended to us while saving his chatty-cathy side for his waitresses. This spry old fox prepared our sushi faster than I'd ever seen before. That's when I noticed something fishy in the immaculately arranged fish cooler, and it wasn't the halibut. Hey, wait a minute, it almost looked like everything was pre-sliced. He may have taken mis en place too far. I was a bit turned off that our Toro was more piecemeal than one big slice on top of its rice bed. This configuration sometimes led to the sushi coming apart before touching them with my chopsticks.

Some things we enjoyed were the surprisingly good (whole pieces of) smoked salmon. It was very mild and tender not like lox. The hamachi was equally delicious (and whole) but I've had fresher and the temperature was too cold. The real crab and avocado california roll had a clean, fresh taste. The pieces were perfectly bite-sized and sported a seaweed exterior making it cuter than a sushi magnet. The unagi was fatty and tasty but could've used more time in the toaster oven cause I like my eel CRISPY. Its sauce was a bit unusual for me, less sweet carmelized soy sauce and more vinegary.

Speaking of vinegar, I noticed that the sushi rice was a bit peculiar and its vinegar more assertive than at other sushirias™. I didn't mind it, but noticed sometimes it distracted rather than complemented the fish flavors.

I like this place a lot. Okina's the epitome of Zen, simple, unassuming and very authentic, achieving its single purpose with aplomb. Just remember to bring some cash so you don't find yourself making making a mid-dinner dash to the ATM next door.
author: Brady K.

description:
The greatest sushi I have ever eaten.

This man is truly a master. When I go to Okina I like to just sit at the bar and let him do the selection, or as I think he calls it "Chef's choice." The value is excellent, the service is always great.

There is nothing to be said ill of this place.
author: Jay C.

description:
I love coming to this place. Its always been a pleasure eating at a place that doesn't have teriyaki sauce drizzled all over it just to impress and hide the stench of disgusting fish. There is no soup, salad or edamame, so don't ask. The menu is very basic, a few rolls, hand rolls, nigiri and sashimi, no fancy rolls with mayo + teriyaki sauce, no tempura, no fillers.

Beware of terrible parking, you may end up like me circling for 20minutes.
author: Alan T.

description: Love this place... It's very small (about two tables for four, one table for two, and six seats at Sushi Bar), but sweet and feels like home.  Before we went, we reviewed the yelp, and took the advice of making reservation.  The restaurant is a bit hard to find for the new comers.  We got there half an hour earlier than our reservation, and the waitress was very friendly and accommodated to seat us.  If you try to get all different kinds of rolls, Okina is not for you.  If you appreciate simple menu, nothing fancy, but great Sushi, this is the place.  Love the fact that, NO lines out there; you can relax and enjoy the food.  Fish is very fresh and price, OMG... unbelievably sooooo reasonable.  Two of us: ordered the Chef Special + extra order of Uni and Amaebi for under $70.  Okina is on my Will-Be-Back list.
author: Q L.

description:
As sweet a spot for sushi if there ever was one.  This is a quintessentially quaint hidden jewel with quality food and friendly service  for a very reasonable price.

If you are looking for the wild & crazy designer rolls, you won't find them here and you may be disappointed by the menu.  This place isn't for everyone, but for me that's part of its charm.
author: Charlie B.

description:
So very disappointed. One of my joys in life is trying new sushi spots all over SF, the country - heck, the world. I admit to not knowing everything about sushi but I can definitely judge the quality - er, at least my enjoyment - of sushi based on 3 things:

- salmon nigiri
- hamachi nigiri
- sushi rice

None of these met my expectations. I'm an optimist too. I always have something good to say - but after my 1st visit to Okina (after a 20 min wait), all I could say was "wow, not impressed." The rice tasted weird (too sweet) and the fish really had no flavor. Even the quail egg on tobiko wasn't as enjoyable as Tsunami's version...and I don't even love Tsunami.

Based on reviews, I expected this place to be on par with Kazu - my favorite sushi spot in SF. I'm willing to go to a mediocre sushi spot if there's something else to entertain me - like good sake, ambiance etc - but this place is deathly quiet. The service was poor as well. The waiter told us that we'd have to wait 45 minutes at least. After 20 minutes, we were seated. Good thing we didn't believe him and didn't leave to try out Sushi Bistro.

Enough complaining. I'm just disappointed. I'm sure there could be better nights at Okina - but not sure I want to chance it.
author: Deann M.

description:
Sushi is one of my fav foods and finding a good sushi joint has been tough. Okina is now one of my go-to sushi spots in SF.

If you like Nigiri, then this is the place for you. If you are looking for fancy rolls, this is not the place for you. The staff is very friendly and the chef is super sweet. He says 'Thank you' just about a million times. The fresh is fish, but quite odd how everything is pre-cut. I love how everything is very reasonably priced for the quality. Definitely a good place for just plain, no frills nigiri, nothing fancy added at all.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
The atmosphere is really comfortable - the hostess was really cheery and attentive, a very authentic feeling which made my time there all the better.

The first thing that was placed in front of us was the green tea. Normally something that I wouldn't care about but it was satisfying. I've come across far too many places where there is a bitter after taste but this was - I can't think of any more an appropriate word - nice.

Getting down to the food: The fish was fresh, no doubt about that. The reason why I marked this place down was that there was far too much wasabi applied between the rice and the fish, which overpowered a lot of the subtle flavors.  However, I did like the mackerel and the tuna.

Overall, I'm not sure if I'd go back there again. I wouldn't utterly oppose it but its not the first place I think of when I want sushi.
author: Krishnan S.

description:
I think this place is great!  The fish is fresh and they only serve REAL sushi...that is nigiri and nothing much else.  Like everyone said, it's true...no tempura, teriyaki, or katsu on the menu.  If you're looking for a Japanese restaurant owned and operated by Koreans or Chinese, don't even waste your time and the space (as everyone already mentioned, they're only open three or so nights a week and the restaurant seats only 12 people or something like that).  No offense against Koreans and Chinese who open Japanese restaurants (I am half Korean anyway), but for me personally I'm into the authenticity of Asian cuisine.  I mean, there are tons of people who like the "Japanese-American" style and that's why those types of restaurants are successful, and I like them at times, BUT I would choose a authentic Japanese restaurant any day. 

Anyway, back to Okina, although there isn't much of a variety, they have fish that is fresh.  I thought the sushi chef was really sweet and I had a great time chatting with him.  I thought the price was very reasonable too.  Definitely on my list of sushi joints in SF.
author: Jessica T.

description: Finally had a chance to try Okina.  The fish was fresh and I like the fact that there's not much rice in the rolls or nigiri. I would definitely come back.
author: Mary L.

description:
It's not often that I have the experience of going to dinner at a restaurant and leaving hungry. It's a testament to how lucky I am to live in a country where food is plentiful. It's also a testament to the fact that most restaurants are run fairly well. Okina Sushi was a rare departure and left me badly disappointed.

Okina is minimalist to a fault. A small place with virtually no decorations. The menu is extremely sparse. There's no edamame, miso soup, salad, tempura or anything else that you'd expect from a sushi restaurant. That OK, I thought to myself as I glanced over the menu, I'll just fill up on high quality fish. When our waiter came along to take my order he informed me that they had run out of hamachi. They were also out of prawns and unagi. I ordered some tuna and amberjack and a couple other pieces of nigiri. When I wanted to order more tuna our waiter apologized and informed me that they had just run out. At this point, there was almost nothing left for me to order so I paid the bill and left in disgust.

I would be more understanding if I had arrived there at the last minute but I sat down for dinner at 7:30pm on a Saturday. Even if they had had more fish to offer, the sushi wasn't anything special and the lack of options on the menu is just lame. I won't be back.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Loved it here. 
Simple, fresh fish. Really good sushi rice. Sweet little man who talked to us and laughed at his own jokes as he quickly made our nigiri for us.  
All the fish was fresh and tasted fantastic.  The Smoked salmon nigiri and the unagi were especially tasty.  The maguro, hamachi, jack and the real crab were lovely too, but something about the unagi at the place just hit the spot.  
We didnt stuff ourselves, but left very contented and all for under $30! 
We WILL be back. 
But beware, no credit cards!
author: Nilu r.

description:
M had been craving Okina's for MONTHS (literally since last November), and we finally made an outing up to SF last night to satisfy her desires. Thanks to Y, we were able to get quite chummy with the master chef and the waiter, and had a very large table reserved and waiting for us when we arrived (starving and ready to consume all fish in sight).

Side note: Definitely make a reservation before going, as the restaurant itself is absolutely TINY (literally a hole in the wall), and will most likely be filled to capacity if you show up unannounced. They had to turn away several people last night while we dined, as reservations caused the few open seats to be unavailable. 

On to the fish: Some of the freshest I've had in the while. I ordered chirashi for myself while my three dining companions shared an omakase. We also side-ordered extra saba, uni, and hotate (which sadly, I didn't get to try). The maguro, hamachi and saba were melt-in-my-mouth tender; the saba was particularly delicious. In that one bite of smooth, sweet, and salty fish, I imagined having the essence of the ocean in my mouth. The highlight of the night was definitely the UNI. I may be a little biased, as I am particularly fond of uni, but DAMN. That uni nigiri was seriously sex in my mouth. My tastebuds rejoiced with every bite as I closed my eyes to savor the sweet succulent flavor of the uni paired with the crisp, subtly salty nori and tangy sushi rice. MMMMMM. 

All that food for only $77! That's quite a steal, given the quantity and quality of the fish we were served. Plus all those tea refills :]

The chef carried on quite a conversation with Y: inviting us to return, and to "go out and play" with him. HAHA. Ojii-chan is a total OG... even at 69!!
author: Susanna W.

description:
home to a chef that as nobu refers as having "magic hands" and being in the mood for some sushi..i made my way here to share in the Okina experience (and complete the "magic hands" sushi tour- Murasaki, Ino, Okina-- nobu-san, honma arigatou!!)

luckily, we came in at the time we did as there were reservation placards on every table except for two spots at the bar.  there are about 16 seats total so making a reservation is recommended.  

the space is beautifully crafted with simple design and openness to allow interaction with the chef from every seat.  i loved being served directly on the surface of the bar as it boldly signals to the pride they take in cleanliness and "no frills" approach.

we started with the omokase (2 nigiri per order)
* hamachi- butter baby
* maguro- simple perfection
* toro- see basi l's review
* kanpachi- so fresh i felt like i tasted the water it once swam in
* iwashi- first time experience and was blown away by the distinctive flavor

then followed up...
* maguro
* toro
* iwashi
* tamago
* amaebi
* ika
* uni
* unagi

i can tell this is Kansai place as the unagi was unbelievable.  i haven't had an unagi party in my mouth like this since being at an unagi specialty shop in tanabe.

is was in sheer bliss as the price for all this and a large beer was less than $70!!!  two times more fish than i ate at Ino and at half the price!  i was floored.  the quality eats, atmosphere and service is sooo good.

if you are a round eye (euge l. tm) and refuse to click useful because you don't know what i ordered stop crying...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sushi_and_sashimi_ingredients
author: omar b.

description:
We came on a Friday night at 7pm (with a reservation!) and there were only 3 other patrons at the bar. The place is similar to Ino Sushi in Japantown in that the chef is Japanese and if you're sitting at the bar, they put the ginger, wasabi, and sushi directly on the bar. The decor is very minimal. The ambiance is lacking as it is pretty quiet in there when the chef is not talking. The chef was nice and really talkative once you get him started. It was a bit difficult to understand everything he was said to us. Like everyone else has mentioned, he thanks you a lot.

We've never done omakase before but we decided to do it this time and boy were we happy we did it. We had 8 pairs of nigiri: jack, hamachi (yellowtail), hirame (halibut), maguro (tuna), saba (mackerel), hotate (scallops), amaebi (sweet shrimp), and oyster. We also ordered smoked salmon, unagi (eel), and toro (fatty tuna). The menu was very limited. We had probably tried about 3/4 of their nigiri menu. Most of the fish seemed fresh but they were pre-sliced, which wasn't too impressive. I don't usually go for hotate but it was really good. The hamachi and hirame were also good. Everything else didn't wow me. The amaebi was the least fresh of all. It was purple in color and it wasn't crunchy enough. The maguro and toro looked and tasted about the same to me except that the toro was a mushier version of the maguro. 

Total for 2 people: ~$45. Cheaper than expected!

Do make a reservation to ensure you get a seat. When my fiance and I were the only two people in the restaurant, another couple came in without reservations and they were turned away. It must have seemed really odd to them, being turned away when the restaurant was practically empty. We suspect that they limit the number of customers per day to ensure that there is still fish left by the end of Saturday. By the time we left, the restaurant was a bit busier.  Also, if you come on a Saturday, the options may be limited as they are open only Thursday through Saturday. Cash only.
author: Tina T.

description: Good service, good food, unfortunately the cramped quarters made it difficult to talk.
author: Michael R.

description: Simple. Small. Superior. Sushi. Sashimi. Sans gimmicks. Nicely priced. Perfect rice. First rate chef. Most def.
author: wendella a.

description:
Its true, though I have never met him, I admire Nobu from afar. He knows his sushi! I dont always agree with what he says is awful, but I do agree that, when he says it is good, well.....it is great! 

I have been excited to try this place for a while and when Lisa W said she was talking me out for sushi on my b-day we decided that it was the perfect opportunity to finally try Okina. We weren't disappointed. 

The menu is simple and small, as is the actual restaurant. What makes is stand out is that everything is fresh, inexpensive and very, very good. I will be back and it wont be soon enough!
author: Drue C.

description:
I know...it's been less than a month since my last review, but my last experience with Okina has been sufficiently disappointing for me to downgrade.  -1 star for lacking consistency.  

Why disappointed?
- quality was just so-so
- uni is no doubt a great deal at $4, but looked a little ratty
- ikura also just so-so (slightly murky taste)
- chirashi was still good, but noticeably smaller

I think next time I'll try to just stick to the standard fare.  The notion of $4 uni is perhaps too good to be true...sadly.  I'll still go because it's close to my house and worthwhile for the price.
author: Fontane L.

description:
Beautiful, generous cuts of sashimi.  Fresh and flavorful, just as it should be. Like others have said, if you're stictly a roll person Okina probably won't float your sushi boat.  Not that the rolls aren't tasty, they're just very, very simple. 5 stars b/c it's not just good, but it's CHEAP! (about $3 for 2 pieces of nigiri, $3 rolls, $10-12 for 8 pieces of nigiri/chirachi). 

By the way, this is the most clandestine sushi restaurant ever. The sign literally blends into the woodwork. The place itself is tiny, with only a couple of tables and seats at the sushi bar (NOTE: they do take out). Strangest of all, it's open only three nights a week for dinner. I have a couple of theories: 1) The "retired sushi chef" that other yelpers have mentioned is actually a samurai sword maker and moonlights as a sushi chef, a la Hattori Hanzo, or 2) it is a front for some kind of illicit activity...uh, I hope that the Yakuza isn't going to kill me for writing that. Anyway, I hope that whatever it is, it stays around because it's awesome having such a gem in my hood.
author: Steph P.

description:
back to basics...thank you!....small shop restaurant and sushi bar....thank you!....small selection sushi and sashimi...thank you!...speck of small basic rolls...thank you!...one sake selection...cold, room or hot.....thank you!...one beru selection....asahi small or large....thank you!....open thursday, friday and saturday only 'til ten pm....thank you!....all bargain pricing....thank you!....cash only!...thank you!...

ordering being....omakase for three (note..self highly not recommend)....additional orders of sushi and avocado...two large asahi....two large sake room temperature....get total price out of way...filling meal...$hundred plus $twenty tip for three.....

finding omakase lacking special selection...spanish mackeral, tuna, yellowtail, smoked salmon and such....six pieces each...pair per person...finding smoked salmon sushi not liking taste..not fit for sushi...never seen or experienced in past...atleast sushi rice perfection in all....tuna, yellowtail, mackeral, etc....all at par and nothing noteworthy....sashimi slices bit small, but for price fine....large rice underneath job of filling full....additional orders of salmon skin rolls....disappointment in again smoked salmon skin....live prawns sushi seasonal and ordered....familiar good raw prawn chewy crisp taste....disappointment in head boiled..not fried...not the same boiled...making difficult and spiky eating....overall mission of dinner complete....overall feeling being unmemorable meal....
author: Hen A.

description:
Fish selection is sparse but I really didn't care because of the sheer volume of sushi I ate here for cheap.  Trained in Osaka, he prefers sweet over sour for his rice.  

Me and my cousin ate omakase x4 with hot sake x4 and beer x3 for $120.  Even when I wanted to complain, I kept it to myself as I believed I had no right to complain for what I paid.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Reservations please??  Wait what?  My wife and I went to this place trying to get some dinner, only to be turned away as they expected you to have a reservation.  Well...They are only open from 5-10 4 days a week...Who are you supposed to talk to get one and when?  The waitress was nice that tried to seat us, but with 1.5 hour wait time...Something is telling me that there is a slight bit of BS with the wait time.  

I would love to have tried their sushi, as I'm sure a lot of you would.  However, if you need to have a reserved space to try it...and you cant call anyone to reserve a spot...May want to look elsewhere for your sushi needs.
author: Beau S.

description:
4.5 stars.  We had the omakase.  Everything was so fresh.  I don't usually get nigiri because it's too much rice but so much care was taken by the sushi chef to make it perfect, I ate it all.  Plus, it was delicious.

I ate at least 10 different things which included tuna, salmon, halibut, shrimp, mackerel and unagi, I think.  A few of the items included shiso.  I love shiso.  My tea was constantly refilled and even though they were technically closed, they served us and I saw that they continued to let people sit after disclosing the items they were out of. 

I was sad about my sister leaving that day but the homey atmosphere and eating with good friends helped a lot.
author: Seong P.

description:
Okina is a plain, cute, diminutive sushi joint tucked away in the Inner Richmond (nb: everything that's not downtown or in my neighborhood or the mission i consider to be 'tucked away').  I had made a last-minute reservation for 3, and the nice lady didn't even bat an eye when my friends showed up with 3 others in tow, including a 7 year-old.

The menu, like the decor, is simple.  A few basic rolls - also available as temaki - and a standard compliment of nigiri.  I had hamachi, maguro, uni and a few others and thought the quality of the fish was above-average.  The green tea was also particularly delicious.

I plan to return to Okina with a smaller crew and a bottle of sake and see how it goes on the second round.  I recommend this spot, though.
author: Oliver N.

description:
You want five star sushi at a two star price, huh?  Follow my lead:

1)  Walk into Okina's. Show some respect for your sushi god and when you meet eyes with the chef behind the counter, bow like you mean it.

2)  Push the menu aside and declare that you would like the chef to prepare his choice of the freshest fish.  This action will be followed by a "Thank you (bow), thank you (bow), thank you (bow), ok absolutely, thank you (bow)."

3)  Sit and wait.  Use this time to prepare yourself for bliss.  This is it people; this is what I am talking about....

4)  Chef's choice assortment will arrive and before you devour every last delectable, melt-in-your-mouth piece of nigiri, be sure to say thank you.  

5)  Once you have finished your sushi, acknowledge the chef for his excellence.  This should be followed shortly by a little something "extra" from the kitchen.  In our case, the chef also came around to our table to thank us personally and made sure that we enjoyed it.  

6)  Pay your bill.  Ours came to less than $20 per person before tip!!!!  I repeat: Ours came to less than $20 per person before tip!!!!  This might be a good time to leave a little more than 20% on the tip.  
Oh, and did I mention we ordered sake too?!?!

Definitely the most bang for your buck in all of the San Francisco sushi world.  You couldn't ask for fresher fish at a price that is nearly impossible.

And check out their cleanscore - they have never gotten below a 100!!: http://www.cleanscores.com/746/Okina+Sushi
author: Ann W.

description:
When you walk into this quaint, but slightly gloomy hole in the wall on Arguello you feel like you might have found a gem. You sit down at the sushi bar and there's ginger, pickled radish, fresh julienned daikon, and fresh sliced cucumber in a neat pile on the angled wood counter that is your serving area. The chef is a sweet old man that comes off as classically trained and a no-nonsense type of guy. The place itself is no-nonsense with a very simple decor, feeling, and menu. The menu consists of a list of simple rolls, nigiri, and sashimi. You get a cup of green tea upon arrival, and there's beer and sake to choose from if you wish. The meal itself is simple, but it seems as though this is the way sushi is traditionally served in Japan. The rolls are good, and the nigiri and sashimi are fresh and flavorful. I especially liked the unagi nigiri. 

I really don't know what to rate this place. 3 stars or 4, I have no clue. C'mon Yelp, give us that have option. Since I love the mom and pop atmosphere of this true hole in the wall, and I appreciate the no-nonsense vibe the whole establishment has I give it 4 stars. Just know that if you're looking for a dragon-king-butterfly roll with ninja sauce you might be better off at some trendy joint in the Marina.
author: Al L.

description:
An authentic sushi bar with very fresh sashimi and a friendly staff. Although the place isn't large or look like a restaurant (you'll probably drive by and think it's just a house), this is hidden jewel! Prices are very decent considering the good quality of sushi, but NOTE THAT THEY ONLY ACCEPT CASH! (Otherwise you'll have to run over to the liquor store next door and use their ATM machine...)

Also, try to get there early otherwise they'll run out of their oysters (which are amazing....)
author: Valerie F.

description:
This restaurant definitely fits the term "hole in the wall". It's small and easy to miss driving by. It has seating for about 15 people, about six of those being at the sushi bar. It does have a very authentic feel. The chef and staff us Japanese, as I hear them chatting it up with another customer at the bar in their language. This is a place that only serves sushi with a fairly short menu list but the prices are very reasonable. For example, it lists two pieces if uni (sea urchin) nigiri for $4.50 (but too bad they didn't gave it last night). For those like me who likes to order a combo, their nigiri combo consists of eight pieces for $15. (Please note that the menu on their window lists a chirashi item which is crossed out on their menu inside.). Tge fish is fresh and very good. On top of that the chef is nice and friendly, and will smile and thank you periodically while you're still dining. 

Before you come here, check your calendar and see what day of the week it is. Otherwise you can easily be disappointed because they open only two days a week: on Friday and Saturday from 5pm to 10pm.  Also, this is CASH ONLY so don't count on using your credit card, as I found out in my first visit last night.
author: H K.

description:
So disappointed to give this review especially after hearing that Okina offers good sushi at a great value.  At $75 for two for the awful sushi & sashimi today, I wholeheartedly disagree on the value.

Things that went wrong at Okina tonight:

1) Omakase sashimi: Toro - better to get it from Nijiya.  Aji - was the quality of this fish supposed to be served at sashimi level?  Other fish - not memorable at all.

2) Nigiri - sushi rice needed more moisture.  Maguro was tasteless.  

3) Condiments - radish (daikon) and cucumbers were obviously not shaved in skilled manner.

4) Alcoholic drinks - poor selection.

The only good thing about this place was the sushi chef who was talking to you the entire time.  So glad that we had counter seats and had that distraction from the food.
author: Mami T.

description:
Solid sushi bar serving a simple yet satisfying array of nigiri.

No ornate rolls, no Americanized fusion Japanese food, just simple but well-made sushi. Rice had a nice chewy texture with enough give and good balance of salt, vinegar and sugar. Fish was well-sliced although a bit on the small side. Presentation was a bit tacky with the plastic faux-lacquered thing going on but they keep their prices low which compensates.

Some highlights:
Engawa nigiri - Fluke fin
Escolar
Uni - Santa Barbara
Amaebi - sad times, they don't have a deep fryer for the heads. =(

Overall a great experience. We didn't get to sit at the bar with the chef which would have been perfect but next time. Meal came out to $60 or so which for lots of nigiri, was perfect.

Recommendations: Whatever he recommends

Conclusion: Ita-daki-mas!
author: Daniel K.

description:
I love sushi. So much so that even when I'm watching Finding Nemo (one of my all time favorite movies), I find I can't say no to sushi. Is it wrong that I don't even feel guilty???

This past Saturday night I was being a lazy bum and flipping thru the channels on tv when i came across Finding Nemo. Woohoo! About 10 mins into the movie, the hubby calls. 

Hub: "We're on the way home, you wanna have sushi?"
Me: "Hell ya". Click. Run to the bedroom to change. Realized I forgot to say bye to the hub before hanging up the phone.

Our buddy Eric raved about Okina a few weeks back and wanted us to try it out. So this sat night we drove there. It's located in a random place. I don't think I would have ever noticed there was a sushi joint here.

It's a tiny place but right when you walk in, you feel like you're in Japan. Nothing flashy. Just a quaint, tiny ( i mean tiny!-very Japanese) place to get super fresh nigiri.  There isn't a lot on the menu, so like what other reviewers have said, if you want miso soup, tempura or teriyaki, you need to take your ass somewhere else.

We sat at the sushi bar, which i think if you come here is the best way to go.  We left it up to the sushi chef (I think also the owner, and get this...actually Japanese!) to create whatever he wanted for us.  All of the fish was amazingly fresh. The toro was so freaking awesome....it just melted in your mouth. The only thing I opted out of was the scallops (me and raw scallops do not like each other much- see review of Bar Crudo).  The chef was very nice and we all had a great time talking with him.  The prices were also very reasonable here too given that their fish is super fresh.

The only downside to Okina is that they only take cash. But prepared to come here with fist full of cash.

When we got home, I caught the end of Finding Nemo. It just so happened to be the part where the fishermen are catching tuna. 

Hmmm (slightly guilty feeling)
...eh...
them tuna is probably going into the cans (guilty feeling gone).
author: Mary L.

description:
Wow. 

Freshest, most authentic, deliciously simple and graceful sushi I've eaten in San Francisco. Maybe even in America, for that matter. 

I'm going to try to keep this review the same. Except I have to say just one thing...

Hirame nigiri. THAT is why you don't need tempura batter or mayonnaise in your sushi. Because when sushi is as good as Okina's hirame nigiri, it's good enough, just as it is. 

One more thing: 

EAT HERE!
author: Lisa T.

description:
Another 1 chef , owner operated sushi place for purists. The selection is limited to what is fresh and amazing. The diversity is in the preparation and presentation of the fish not the dizzying variety of fish. I wouldn't bother with the menu. I'd sit at the bar and ask the chef what is best. We did and were treated to wonderful cultural stories as well  lovely portions of hotate, marinated diver scallop, amberjack, hamachi, and toro sashimi and nigiri. This neighborhood joint has no flash or splash. Its all heart.

Cash only.
author: Sirima S.

description: This restaurant is the closest you can get to traditional Japanese sushi. Think Jiro Dreams of Sushi. This is not a place for saki bombs and California rolls. It's real sushi, cash only, and small, so I suggest making a reservation or expect to sit at the bar.
author: Janina T.

description:
This place is pretty good. But be warned, if you sit at the counter the sushi chef may be intimidating. He says "hai hai" a lot and barks orders to the waitresses in japanese. Usually he is saying "make sure they have tea in the cups and dont forget this or that"....

The food is served on the counter... like on the counter itself! This was a bit "interesting" as I have never seen this done before. And after it was done, the cleaning was done with like a towel... I am not sure how sanitary that is but as I was intimidated, I asked no questions. ( yes the wasabi, ginger and such went on the counter as well)

Cute place if you are looking for sushi... thats it, nothing else... not even miso soup. I suggest you dont be a hero and ask for this an that.
author: B H.

description:
O. M. Geezy. Bloody brilliant. 

A friend recommended this place to me, and it was literally such a tiny restaurant, that we walked by it twice before we realized it was there. We made reservations, also suggested by a friend since it has such limited seating, and I'm glad that we did. 

It was great, bc the main dining area (not including the bar or small waiting area) was probably smaller than my living room. But I loved the intimate and family-like feel that this gave the place. There wasn't a large variety of drinks to choose from, but I feel that their limited choices really allows them to highlight their food and for the focus to be on the sushi itself. 

I got the deluxe sashimi plate, and although at first I was a little disappointed at the size, later it dawned on me that unlike many American restaurants, or sushi restaurants in the States, Okina doesn't want its diners to eat for quantity, but rather for quality.
