Ahh. While I was a little embarrassed at first that my tendencies to stuff my face unabashedly have dumbed me down when it comes to recognizing quality food, I forgave myself and just enjoyed the experience. 

To sum up, this is a definite must for people who actually love sushi, and by sushi, I mean raw fish. Not the rolls that have been fried or drowned in sauce/mayo, but the kind of sushi where they want people to enjoy the taste of the fish, not hide it. If you're that kind of sushi-lover, than this place will def be your cup o' tea.
author: Bel P.

description: Excellent! Extremely fresh and really good quality fish. Get a reservation cause okina is a small restaurant with limited seating, get a spot at the bar if possible. Very traditional and simplistic sushi. The Uni was absolutely amazing, best I've ever had. Can't wait to go back as this is now my favorite neighborhood sushi bar.
author: Jeff H.

description:
First off, I need to thank you yelpers for saying that this place was reservation only otherwise I would have surely missed out.

Reservations only?-
So me being here on vacation from San Diego, I had time to kill after going to the academy of science before my flight. Whipped out my iphone/yelp app and found this small gem only accepted reservations. I called at 4:50 right before they opened, and got a reservation @ 5. Awesome that they accept reservations so short of notice. 

Review-
Upon entering the restaurant, I was greeted by the sushi chef and was seated at the bar where we were immediately served complementary tea. Might I add, it was DAMN GOOD tea. The menu was quite small, offering only roughly 15 different types of nigri, and 10 sushi rolls. While small, they offered all the basic sushi selections. My mom and I ended up splitting a deluxe nigiri assortment, 4 orders of nigiri and 1 roll which surprisingly filled us up. I have to recommend the kanpachi (yellowtail); A butter-tasting fish that melts in your mouth. Service was FAST as well. As soon as we ordered something, the food was almost immediately in front of us; albeit there was only one other party of 2 in the restaurant at the time.  Best part of all... the bill came out to a little under $40! Very inexpensive. 

Conclusion-If you're not a die-hard sushi lover and are looking for a selection of specialty rolls (i.e rainbow, crunchy rolls), you will be sorely disapointed. If you want to have a real authentic japanese sushi experience with excellent nigiri at a great price, this is your place. 

Afterthoughts: It also appears that this place is open only a few days a week (thurs, fri & sat?). On top of being reservation only, they must not make a lot of money leading me to a conclusion. They must be doing it because they love it...so awesome.
author: Michael S.

description:
When I'm really missing living in western Japan, this is the cure. The chef and his family who assist in the restaurant are from Hiroshima.

The sushi is very fresh and authentically prepared - minimal goopy sauces, fruit, and fried bits. The fish, however, is always fresh and immaculately prepared.

If you're inclined to eat late, do call ahead as they close when the fish is gone. Anytime past 8:30-9PM on Fridays is usually too late... 

For the price, I don't think you can find better sushi anywhere outside of Japan. Metcha oishii!
author: Sarah G.

description: Cute little joint with an OG sushi chef/owner. He's been doing it for 30 yrs and knows how to make real good, real authentic sushi. No fancy, americanized sh*t w/like 10 different ingredients. Just simple nigiris and a couple rolls like tekka and kappa. He also has set combinations for less than $15! I asked him how he makes a living off that, and he said that he's already paid off the restaurant and now he just does it because he loves what he does and doesn't care about profit. How awesome is that?
author: Emy s.

description: LOVE this place. The sushi chef is a total pro. This place is for an authentic sushi/sashimi experience with their high quality seafood and an intimate atmosphere. If you're looking for an extensive list of fancy rolls, you'll be disappointed. This place is all about quality, not quantity. Just get nigiri and you'll leave full and happy!
author: Suzi G.

description: Don't go here.  I don't want to run the risk of not getting a table.  Seriously.
author: Russ S.

description:
The best sushi in SF.

Toro, maguro, kaki, and uni, especially, were exceptional.  We took the chef's recommendation for our meal, and he definitely served up a platter of the best fish of the day.  This restaurant reminds me of my time in Japan.

The meal was simple, minimal, and straight to the point, which is all about fresh fish and masterful preparation.  What this restaurant lacks in selection, it makes up for in quality and authenticity.

In addition to the meal, we got a lengthy lecture/declaration from the chef on making the most of one's life by not living by others' standards and advice on how a 69 year-old man can have many girlfriends as a method of warding off wrinkles and the typical vices of old age.
author: Peter L.

description:
Rules needs to be posted before entering this establishment or else you will feel as awkward as I did by the chef. 

1.  Make reservations (which I did thanks to fellow yelpers). They don't take walk-ins. 

2.  Don't go hungry because there's only one chef and he can only put out so much sushi at any time.  ( this was a HUGE mistake I made )

3.  Order the chef's choice straight off the bat so that you will get 6 or 8 pairs at one time. If you decide not to order the chef choice ( like me ), keep in mind that 2-3 orders can be placed whenever the chef is ready for you.

4.   Eat sloooowly.  Food may come out as quickly as you order it, but it's going to be awhile before you will be able to order again. 

OVERALL:   Selection was limited yet tasty.  Orders came very quickly, but it takes forever to place another order.  I would've liked more Tobiko on the Tobiko Nigiri, but that's just me.  Very happy with the price at the end!
author: Aimey T.

description:
Though it is still early in my yelping career, I decided from the beginning that I would only try to review places if I had been there more than once. I foresaw having to make exceptions for either really really good first experiences or really really bad ones.

With Okina Sushi, it's because I had a really, really awesome first time eating there last night!

I'm not surprised that it took me so long to eat here even though I've lived in the neighborhood for 4 years. As a college student, the sushi bars of choice were either AI Sushi or Sushi Boom which, all you sushi fiends out there, know speaks for itself (sake bombs were and can be fun sometimes, ok?!). Now that I'm a tad older, wiser, and more willing to pay the price for better food, I'm proud to say that I have graduated onto bigger, better sushi. Okina seriously has the most fresh, most delectable, most lovingly made sushi I've had in a while. The saba and unagi were to die for. Akio, the owner, chatted up my friend and I with sincere kindheartedness and humor. Though he could have, he didn't get fed up with us when we kept having to ask him over and over again what were the different types of fish displayed in front of us and which was which. And Akio knows his business--he opened up Okina himself 26 years ago after only having lived in the country a short while. The place is still standing and doing amazingly well--gotta respect that.

I looove Okina and have a very good feeling that what I got the first time is what I will continue to get when I go back. Make sure you sit at the bar--Akio will hook you up!
author: Kate V.

description:
I heard so much good thing about this place. My expectation was high. 

The owner is nice. He is very friendly. The price is great. Only $70 can stuff you and your date up. But I don't eat sushi to feel full. If I wanted to stuff myself, I eat burgers and fries. 

 I did not like their toro or aji. The cut of fish was not the style I like. I had good time and came out feeling good. But really? Is this the place the everyone was talking about? I had a better sushi at Kaiten Zushi in Japan.
author: Mika G.

description:
I'm not really sure what the "one star" review people were talking about, but this place is incredible.

I recently started eating fish again after 8 years of not, and a lot of sushi still doesn't sit right with me.

Okina is the only place where I can eat sushi because their fish is *SO* fresh.  The price is right, and the staff are the cutest and nicest couple.  It is definitely a smaller establishment, better set up for a more intimate dinner with only a few friends as opposed to big groups (IMO).

Love it here.

Great food, friendly smiles, and nice atmosphere.
author: Jess R.

description:
I don't get the hype here.  I *THOUGHT* it was cheap but by the end I'd paid $30 for 8 plates.  Somehow I was expecting it to be more around $20.  Man I miss Tokyo and $1 plates of 2 pieces of nigiri.  Even at that cheap, it was incredibly fresh compared to anything you get stateside.  

Sushi Tomo was way better than here -- for the same cost the pieces were much larger.  I still lament the loss of that place.

The one thing I will say in this place's favor is that it has real crab.  The owner is a pretty interesting character too.

Oh and they have maki too -- not just nigiri and sashimi.
author: Eric X.

description: Drove by this place and decided to give it a try after reading up on the four star reviews from Yelp.  There was really nothing special about this place.  The decor is plain and so is their food.  We got the omasake and and a couple of rolls....noothing to rave about really.  The sashimi was not even fresh and they did not have my favorite wakame salad! That' a big no no.  Overall not too memorable and won't be returning.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
4 stars for the service, quality of food, and price.  The fish was fresh and a pleasant surprise.  We had the omakase and all the sushi was great, but the hamachi really stood out.  As for the rest of the menu items, don't expect a wide selection of sake or rolls, but the quality of what they do have and the price makes up for the small selection.

For the restaurant, it's definitely on the smaller side, but we made reservations and it wasn't a problem getting a table.  At the end of the night, we were caught off guard by the cash only payment as we didn't have enough cash and I had to make a quick trip to the ATM.  Aside from this it was a great night.

This is definitely a restaurant I'll be back to as we live in the area and it'll be great for a quick sushi fix.  Only reason they get 4* is because they're open only a fews nights out of the week and the cash only payment method.  Everything else was great.
author: klb l.

description:
Cute and small atmosphere with limited seating.  Sit at the bar and you get to see the sushi chef prepare your rolls, which is made once you order.  Everything was fresh...it's none of those sushi rolls that have been sitting there for a while.  

We ordered the salmon roll, spider skin roll, New York roll, salmon sashimi, and unagi nigiri.  You can't go wrong with any of those, but I really liked the spider skin roll.
author: Lisa C.

description:
The price is decent for the quality. My only gripe is that I prefer to have my fish sliced  to order rather than having it presliced (minus one star). 

Tasty? Yes. 

I love the shredded cucumber/radish side.

Tiny place, friendly people.
author: Evan W.

description: We waited a week to get a table the day after 4th of July since they are only open Thursday to Saturday.  Maybe we have a unrealistically high expectation, I wasn't really impressed with their sushi. I ordered the Omakase and the mackerel was really fishy. Other fish was OK and the price was really reasonable. There were other guests who walked in with out reservation were told that they wouldn't be served since they were fully booked for the night. I felt maybe the waitress/host was little bit rude. She was nice to us though.
author: T.J. Y.

description:
Definitely MEH. This was the first time Yelp failed me. Don't know why there are so many positive reviews...

Maybe we came at a bad time or maybe, just maybe, this place is mediocre (and I'm being fairly kind with my words...). Anyway, so PW and I made 630 reservations on a Friday night. We walked in and it felt like we walked into a really small library. There was one woman sitting at the bar talking with the chef and server. I was thrown off but immediately dismissed it, looking forward to eating the "fresh" sushi that everyone had raved about.

One of the first things I noticed was that all the fish was pre-sliced. Ummm...didn't know I was going to a Nijiya market. The second thing I noticed was that the fish tasted bland, rice was cold and the chef was very pushy. Okay so that's #2, #3 and #4. 

#5 - prices are cheap. I'll give them that...but you definitely get what you pay for. And you're not getting much. 

I feel bad for ranting...I rarely run into (and review) a 2 star establishment so yes, I'll be THAT person who gives the 1 or 2 star review among a plethora of 4 and 5 stars. Anyway, to each his own...I'm just not a fan of eating in a stale and quiet atmosphere without the good food to back it up.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
Best sushi in SF hands down.

Appropriate prices for good clean, fresh sushi.

I don't want to go anywhere else.
author: Shannon B.

description:
The first time we tried to eat here it was packed and without reservations, they pretty much told us to come back another day.  The next time I called to get a reservation and it was completely unnessary.  With the exception of a party of 3 who was finishing as we were starting we were the only ones in the place.  I don't think it's worth trying to figure out.

The selection was very limited and there was no uni (sad face) but the fish we had was all good.  What really sets this place apart is the fact that the fish is pre cut.  This is ALWAYS a deal breaker for me.  It always makes the fish taste dry and gives it a mealy texture-everywhere I've been except Okina.  If I didn't see the fish sitting there in that state I wouldn't have believed it.  

The real kicker for this place is how incredibly cheap it is.  Toro handroll was only around $3.  For Toro.  Insane.  We were in and out in about 30 mins and the wallet damage was incredibly minimal for the amount we ate.
author: M M.

description: Best and most quality sushi in San Francisco. Sit at the bar and eat whatever the master chef wants you to eat.
author: Jared W.

description:
What am I missing here??  I was so excited about the place because yelpers seem to unanimously agree that this place serves the best sushi.  It has no special rolls and only seats 10 people---sounds good to me.  But whatever we had I thought were just alright.  Good, but nothing to write home about.  

And my boyfriend and I are the type of diners that like to sit quietly and not have to interact with the restaurant more than necessary, so it felt really awkward to have the chef standing next to us, looking over for reactions after every single dish.  We'd say politely this is good and he'd say  "thank you very much" and we'd continue this endless etiquette game throughout the entire dinner.  

People might hate me for suggesting this, but maybe the story of Okina is just too delicious that it romanticized the food?  It's a mom n' pop shop that only opens a couple of nights a week; the only people working there are father and son; it's a small establishment tucked in a street/area hard to find.  It feels exclusive and intimate and secretive.  I think yelpers are suckers for places like that.
author: Candice B.

description:
The fish was very, very fresh, and the chef (I did not get his name) was a gracious host to the two of us at the bar.  Everything seemed authentic, though I have never been to Japan.  The menu is small, but I appreciate the fact that this is done to keep things fresh.  The scallop nigiri was beautiful, and we had to order it again, though strangely enough it wasn't as good the second time around.  The ebi was also fantastic, as was the urchin.  I did not care for the tamago, which is usually one of my favorites.  This one was not sweet, like I am used to, and was mealy.  Perhaps this is another style?.  

Also, the hamachi, which came two to an order like everything else nigiri, came with two small pieces of fish on one nigiri, and just one piece on the second.  Perhaps it was the last piece and he had to splice two together to make one nigiri?  I just thought this was odd, and certainly a departure from a few of the reviews of this "sushi master", from Toro E and Nobu K.  Perhaps you have to be more in the know, or display your knowledge a bit, in order to have impeccable food?  I did not see the magic hands.  Please elaborate more as I want to go back and give it another shot.

We did enjoy everything that we ordered, though none of it was mind blowing like my experience at Sushi Sam's in San Mateo.  I did leave feeling a bit unsatisfied, yet I certainly vow to go back and give it another try.  At the very least, it was good, fresh sushi at a fair price, in a place with character.
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description:
I love this place more than I love your mom. If you live east of Masonic, stay there. Find your own treasure. I promise to leave it alone if you stay away from here. 

There are no fancy rolls here. Don't order a rainbow roll. Don't think about a tempura concoction. Not even Teriyaki chicken. The chef is an undercover samurai and will cut the head off any feudal lord or person ordering seaweed salad that may enter the premises.

Well, he'll actually smile, tell you he doesn't have it and then say "Thank you."

The chef will say "thank you" a lot. It's nice.

But seriously, don't go here. You'll hate it. There is no wait usually. There is no loud techno. No on the anime and there is only one kind of sake and it's hot.

Go away now.
author: Christopher C.

description:
I don't understand why people would give this place more than three stars. Yelp ratings inflation syndrome, I call it. It's either that, or you don't know your sushi.

I'd give 2.5 stars, but since Yelp doesn't support that, I'm still not going to round up to 3 stars.

In terms of the quality of sushi, it's slightly above Tekka, but that's not saying much. I had various nigiri (maguro, hamachi, uni, aji) but after noting that most of the neta (fish) had seen better days, I stopped ordering and hit the eject button.

The shari was okay. I thought it was quaint that takuan was served alongside the gari. I was disappointed in the fact that I got served garden-variety commercial food service grade wasabi chock full of artifical fluorescent green food coloring. Man, I hate that crap. Give me real wasabi dammit!

I would have stuck around if there were other izakaya-style ippin ryori (small plates) to order, but alas no. I was a bit stunned when I was told there was none. Really tells you that this is a minimalist, bare-bones operation where effort is not really spent outside the procurement of the neta and cooking of the shari.

Since I speaka da language and struck up a bit of conversation with the itamae-san, I appreciated his kind gesture of offering up a slice of tamago as a nibble. Unfortunately, its taste turned me off. It was a bland, pure egg tamago-yaki with a slightly grayish-brown tint. My preference is to have it prepped with dashi, soy, mirin, sake, and sugar, with the hint of a golden brown exterior, just like how my momma makes it.

On the plus side, the joint was spotlessly clean as someone noted in another review. It's very spartan and pure in a Shinto shrine kind of way. I believe I spotted a little plaque/signage somewhere on the wall declaring that the restaurant was designed by some Japanese architect/designer.

As I walked out of the restaurant with an aborted meal, I was frustrated by how this great space was being let down by the food.

Bottom line: Yet another disappointing sushi/Japanese restaurant in SF.
author: Bono B.

description:
A great place to take a friend from out of town who enjoys fresh seafood in a elegant setting. The restaurant lies in a nice, clean, and a place shrouded in mystery due to its hidden location. Without much of an extravagant entrance, Okina still proceeds to have a steady and loyal clientele  The restaurant is sleek, modern, and surprisingly simple. The food is always fresh and of top quality. The menu is simple and charming as is the chef. 


I recommend (if money is not an issue)  requesting  "omakase" rather than just eating the same roll over and over. Omakase is a Japanese term to give the chef permission to serve the customer accordingly. A good choice for sushi connoisseurs because the deal will allow you to taste many different delectables  Remember to tell the chef if you are allergic to anything in particular or else he'll give you something with an itch at 3 in the morning. My friend and I had everything from Uni(sea urchin) to scallops and other fishies of the sea.

Price 4/5
Food 4.5/5
Atmosphere 5/5


P.S touch of class in this hole in the wall restaurant.
author: Jimmy K.

description:
Oh, if only they would add Wed. to their repitoire....I always seem to crave this sushi on Wed!!

A great place for quality sashimi or nigiri at a very low cost.  I typically eat quite a bit for $20-$25 pp (the menu looks like a throwback to 1979).

No corkage so feel free to bring your own wine.  They do have something but uh, bring your own.  Or, drink cheap decent beer, which they have.

The father/son team (I think??) that runs this place is incredible.  They will literally remember WHEN and with WHOM you last came in....(and this can get embarassing in date situations but that was a long time ago...).  Doesn't matter if you were last in 2 months or 2 years ago and also, doesn't matter if you were only there once before.  It's odd.

There is usually about 8-10 different types of fish/shellfish. 

The amberjack, toro (the price of normal maguro elsewhere), and unagi are always stellar.  I think he only gets smoked salmon, not salmon.

Just a wonderful place.  But, as I once learned the hard way, NOT a place to bring a crowd that wants a party ambiance.
author: Laurie A.

description:
Oishii des! I have never eaten four big plates of Nigiri Sushi in a row in an hour and a half. Okina Sushi totally satified my Nigiri Sushi craving. I'd go back anytime, especially since I live about 10 blocks away from it. Lucky me! 

LOVE: Toro Nigiri Sushi
LOVE: the price is super friendly.

HATE: N     O     N     E.

TIPS: Go get your fast pass n' your house key and GO!
TIPS: Don't forget your SAKE!
author: Inne S.

description:
SEXY OLD MAN

Seriously... that's what Akio the owner told me the restaurant name "means." He's hilarious and a master at his craft. The sushi is SO fresh and definitely prepared authentically. You'll see why. It's not a place to get fancy-fuzion fare --- with special rolls or flashy service. You'll get an amazing experience just by the simplicity and authenticity of Akio's sanctuary. You'll do best by sitting at the sushi bar and just asking him to serve you what's "best." He won't lead you wrong.

The chef is adorable --- especially when he laughs at his own jokes!  It's completely CONTAGIOUS!!!  First time I ever had jack fish or uni with quail egg.  Why?  Because I trust this guy.

He's SO VERY ANAL about how he obtains, inspects and serves sushi, sashimi, nigiri, etc.

Very old school Japanese --- he swears he's one of THE FIRST sushi chefs in the whole US of A.  I believe him.  He began his trade in Manhattan --- and now holds the most amazing hours in SF.  I'd kill to work just three days a week at five hours a day.... JEEZ!!!

The sushi is amazing --- but salmon (sake) lovers beware --- he does NOT choose to serve what he deems to be low quality parasite-infested fare.  Yep --- he'd rather have you fret and fume than hand you over on a gurney to the nearest ER.
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
I usually like my sushi with a lot of frills, sauces, and anything else to distract me from realizing I'm eating raw fish so initially the only thing that appealed to be on the menu was the california roll. However, with a little push from my boyfriend (who informed me that I would be a complete wuss if I ordered that), I got the nigiri regular combination- no frills, just rice and fish. And it was amazing. The freshest fish I've ever tasted. It was really quite an experience. I didn't order enough to get full, so if you go there with a large appetite, I would get the combo or just order a bunch of separate rolls. 

My only qualms with the this place is that they don't accept credit cards and anything you say can be heard by the other patrons since the walls seem to reflect and amplify noise.
author: May T.

description:
This place is a true "hole-in-the-wall." If you don't look hard enough, you'll drive or walk right past it. Once inside, you may be taken aback, as I was, by how small the restaurant is. I would say it seats less than twenty. 

Okay, if you're into restaurants that serve edamame, miso soup, and special rolls, go ahead and click the "back" button on your browser now. Seriously, you will be disappointed. The menu is small, one of my gripes, and minimalistic. We're talking bare, bare basics: simple rolls (e.g. tuna w/ avocado, prawn w/ avocado, smoked salmon skin), nigiri, and sashimi. 

Also, if you're really squeamish and hygienic, don't sit at the bar. The chef serves everything essentially on the counter...and your "plate" will look highly suspicious, because it resembles a tray more than a plate and is pretty worn. Well, whatever doesn't kill you will make you stronger, right? 

I'm assuming Okina Sushi is best known for their fresh fish, because that is pretty much all their menu offers and from what I had, I would say it is very good quality and reasonably priced. My boyfriend and I ordered almost half the menu and our bill only came out to $38 (CASH ONLY). I was full, but my boyfriend said, "well, that was a good appetizer, let's go to 7/11." He wasn't kidding, we really did go to 7/11 and he bought a cheeseburger big bite. 

All in all, I think genuine sushi lovers will really appreciate this place. Just don't expect a rainbow roll, okay?
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Nobu K...your sushi reviews are always perfect.  Following his super stellar review of this place, I couldn't resist dragging friends over to check this place out!  It was fantastic.  It's a neighborhoody, small sushi place with only a couple of tables and a bar.  Sit at the bar.  At first we were scratching our heads trying to figure out what to get (a very small menu)...but then the sushi chef just started dishing them out.  And they were ALL good.  The fish was the freshest that I've had at any SF sushi joint, the service was good, and we all left extremely satisfied.

Here's to you...sushi master Nobu!
author: Mark D.

description:
This place is pretty cool, but I don't think its better than Hama-Ko. http://www.yelp.com/biz/uSL7-qazmxfJq3IAqi3Gcg#hrid:oDAAeDRKhorLYhf4HsOuOA/query:hama%20ko
I'm not a hater. The sushi was fresh, but I need slighty bigger cuts with more variety. The cuts were even too small for Josie M!

The good: the service, the sushi chef, and the uni with quail egg!
The bad: small cuts, limited variety, smoked salmon, halibut w/ the green (mint?)
author: Harvey C.

description:
I think I've just found a new neighborhood spot if I'm craving nigiri.  Prices are low for the quality that you get.  The selection of fish is not as vast as some other spots but they have all the standbys like tuna, hamachi, unagi, etc. and some of my other favorites like the hotate (scallop) and amaebi (sweet raw shrimp).  We each had the omakase, some beers, and few additional orders of sushi for around $70 total.  

The chef owns the building so I'm sure he passes on the rent savings through his pricing.  He's basically retired and does this for fun...the guy is a definite character.  Only downside is this place is only open a few days a week.  

DSKO favs: omakase
author: Dik Shun K.

description:
Been there once. I love this place and I'll go back once in a while for good sushi. (Note: They open only on Thurs/Fri/Sat nights and seating capacity is very limited)

Place: This business has the one and only chef who's taking care of every order. No Kitchen staff. Chef pays attention to and has control of every corner of the restaurant, which makes me feel comfortable. You won't hear no childish chatting between young servers or insolent yuppie conversation. From the start  to the end, you can concentrate on your sushi while enjoying a good mature time in the very elegance of Japanese atomosphere. Also, Okina is located in the quite left-behind neighborhood of Inner Richmond, so you don't need to face a lousy bustle of main street on your way out, allowing you to bring home a fairy tale experience at the old man's house.

Price: It is hard to beat their prices on sushi and sashimi. I should admit this is one of the reasons why I want to repeat. Considering that you're not getting pre-made sushi from the moving belt, Okina deals are ridiculously far out. 

Food: Good quality fish and good quality sushi. I've had better sushi in the Bay Area and in Japan, but that doesn't take anything away from Okina. Please do not start a "authentic VS unauthentic" debate because items on menu are all authentic. I personally would avoid Tamago (omelet) simply because it's not my kind, but I won't blame their recipe. 

In general, if your expectation here is a fat ass hollywood banquet, you may not be satisfied to multiple orgasms. But if you're mature enough to appreciate a sensible dining experience with frugal yet nice meals, you will get more than you paid for!
author: yota L.

description:
I see that Okina normally gets either 5 stars or 3 stars. People who give it 5 stars liken the experience to the transcendental, those who give it three usually say something about mediocre fish. 

I have been there twice. The first time lived up to all of the 5 star reviews, it was mind blowing. The second time was mediocre. I think that the chef's hands were still magic, but the fish was just average. 

So, in conclusion, I think that both the praises and the criticisms that Okina receives are warranted, though the overwhelmingly positive reviews would suggest that the fish is great most of the time. I wonder what accounts for the inconsistency?
author: Lion G.

description: Great sushi place..the menu is simple but the flavors and ingredients are fresh and bold..the hubby and i ordered almost everything to try and with beer and a glass of wine spent less than $50!! Parking sucks but thats sf for ya..cant wait to come back
author: Kanani S.

description:
At the perfect intersection of food and value, this non-descript hard to find Th-Sa spartan sushi bar is pound for pound the best sushi restaurant in town.  The prices are what you find for sushi that floats on a boat but what you get is classical fresh traditional Japanese sushi.  Don't look for 49er, Caterpillar, Dragon or any other crazy sushi rolls that dominate other lesser sushi restaurants.  There are no soups, tempura, noodles or teriyaki....just fresh fish.

Chef Akio is an older guy who has been serving sushi for more than 25-years.  Friendly with a very Japanese sense of humor.

Cash only....come drink your sake and experience the purity of simple sushi eating.

Pos: best value for money, fresh fish, classical style for the purist at heart.

Negs: hard to find location, spartan interior, limited hours, cash only, limited staff.
author: Laurence H.

description:
This was - and still is - one of my secret haunts in the Richmond. I've never been to Japan, but small places like this takes me to that world. I like the quiet atmosphere it has. For me, my sushi experience is a religious one. So I do prefer the quiet atmosphere it has.

I'm a sashimi fanatic and I have never been disappointed here. I usually go "omakase" with the chef when I'm at the bar and I've always had a great experience. 

Damn, why did I review it...now you're going to want to come here and take my "spot".
author: Ted P.

description:
I have been looking for real sushi in the City for a long time, and got tired of finding Japanese restaurants run by Koreans... I was about give up finding real sushi in San Francisco, then I found this place! 

I read reviews of this place, and sounded great, so I went.  The sushi was so awesome! very fresh, and "Shari" was good too!! The restaurant is very cozy and quiet, and perfect to have real sushi.  It is very clean inside too, and had great service! 

I would love to go back sometime soon!
author: moshi m.

description:
I would advise serious caution here.   I have spent plenty of time in Tokyo so for those of you who believe this is "authentic" I'd suggest you think again.

Although it has a charming look to it, step inside and be greeted by an irritable sushi chef who said, as I asked about the fish, "why are you asking me so many questions".

He was not warm at all, the fish was NOT fresh (maybe a bad day, but still), and the selection was very poor.

Authentic sushi is a wonderful experience.  This was not even close.  Spend your dollars elsewhere, or else, be warned...
author: Jamie D.

description:
This place is absolutely amazing.  I would suggest two things:

1.  Sit at the bar and make conversation with the chef and owner.  He is an amazing person and is genuine.  He knows his fish and his sushi. 

2.  Always ask the chef what's fresh and just ask him to give you the freshest stuff.  And, he will always deliver.

I really wish the place was open more than just 4 days a week.  I want to go there all the time and forget that it's not open most wk nights.
author: Linda K.

description:
Real Japanese food by real Japanese chefs. Only open 3 days a week ... and sometimes it's randomly closed.

They do not have ridiculous rolls covered in flavor masking sauce ... this is the real deal.
author: Alex C.

description: Best bang for your buck..... authentic sushi comparable to Ino sushi but a whole lot cheaper...
author: John R.

description:
As you can tell from the other reviews, this place has strange business hours. The owner says its because he's smart and Americans work too hard. I admire his wisdom

The food is excellent and you must simply try it.  No more reading, stand up, grab your keys, and go!  The experience feels like the owner is doing you a favor.  And he really is!
author: Michael N.

description: A very unique spot in San Francisco. The sushi is incredibly fresh, the venue is VERY small (I'd call ahead on a Friday or Saturday night, they only have about 4 *small* tables, plus a sushi counter) and quiet, with just two staff running the operation. The menu is not very extensive. If you enjoy sushi with a lot of different sauces and additions to it, this probably isn't the place for you. If you want incredibly FRESH sushi, come here. The prices are very affordable. The only reason I am not giving this place the full 5 stars is because of the atmosphere - no music playing, dead silence - and the lack of selection on the menu. If they added just a few more items, such as a simple spicy salmon or scallop, and had some music playing in the background (you could hear every word of other conversations around you, without even trying), I'd easily give this place a 5.
author: Stephanie B.

description: VERY limited menu selection and seating capacity; only accepts cash. Other than those couple of drawbacks, if you're looking for a place with extremely fresh fish and a personal touch in the traditional Japanese fashion, then this is a great place to check out.
author: Brad Y.

description:
Kiss was booked out, and we didn't feel like Sebo or any of our other regular raw-fish haunts, so the boy and I hauled out to Arguello and Okina. And we're very glad we did.

Small place, no decor, limited menu, no pretensions, nothing fancy. Just good, traditional-style sushi and sashimi. Sit down at the bar, tell the avuncular chef you want omakase (he'll choose what to prepare) and let him plunk down tasty morsels on the bar for you. Don't camp out and chit and chat (it's rude), just eat until you're full, thank him, and pay the check that will be less than you think it would for good fish.
author: Lale A.

description: I've been going here since 2000, I'm a repeat customer for good cause! The fish is so fresh. He serves almost all raw stuff, so baked sushi roll consumers be ware, this is not the place for you! The chef is an absolute gem -- cute, charming, and funny, so sit at the bar if you need some conversation. If you're looking for something more intimate, there are a few tables. The bar has 6 seats available, and there are two tables that seat 4, and two tables that seat 2. Prices are great, service is great, so I always tip well over 20%. I can't wait to go back for my next visit!
author: Maria C.

description:
This place is definitely sushi heaven. My friend took me to this place since both her and I are sushi fanatics. What hit me the most was the hidden location and small space. However, when walking in, it had a nice authentic Japanese ambiance to it.

The place is really, really small, containing only 4 sushi bar seats and 3 tables. When I came in, 1 of the tables were reserved and all of the sushi bar seats were all taken or reserved. Seeing that 90% of the place was reserved, I knew it had to be a good place. Also, there was already a Japanese women dining there and she was conversing in Japanese to the chef for most of the time. When actual Japanese people go to a Japanese restaurant, you know that it has to be really, really good.

Since parking was really difficult to find (we had to walk 5 blocks), we were limited on time due to the parking meter. Service was really fast and efficient, and we still made it back with 10 minutes to spare out of an hour total.

The main thing was, however, was the food. The sushi was the most delicious thing I've ever tasted. The fish was soft and smooth, and went down your throat like butter. The soft texture in comparison to the hard stuff that other places serve tells you that the fish is fresh. Not only was the sushi good, but the prices were decent, or probably lower, for the quality of the food.
author: Burnette E.

description: We loved this place. Super fresh, amazing flavor, fantastic service. It is so small which greatly adds to its awesomeness. We were the first guests of the night on a Sunday and have to admit it was a bit quiet for my tastes, slightly awkward feeling but I can imagine this place hopping with customers and being a more comfortable atmosphere. The food was amazing, and fantastic prices. Casual dress but if I went here dressed up I wouldn't feel out of place either! It is so classy and with such beautiful interior details.
author: Gabrielle S.

description:
As my BF and I were having dinner here on Saturday, the Cheers theme song kept reeling through my mind. Where everybody knows your name... and that's exactly how it is by the end of the night as you say good bye to the ten other people in the restaurant. 

You heard right... this small little place seats only about 16-18 people. If you don't have a reservation, expect to eat somewhere else. If you do have reservations, be sure to show up a bit earlier. 

Food. Quality of fish was good. Fresh. Delicious. But quantity was scarce. The restaurant has only a limited amount of fish each night, so if you have an affinity for a type of fish... say... HAMACHI... I highly advise you to order that right when you sit down. If you're lucky, you'll probably get to enjoy two pieces. No such thing as raw salmon here, there is only smoked salmon. Ask the ninja chef why. =)

Price of food was good. The average price of nigiri was $3.50 and rolls at $4. Asahi and sake were also reasonably priced. Green tea is free. Cash only.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
it's wise to come only after calling ahead to make sure there's room
chef is great, tiny intimate place, sushi placed on the clean counter like Ino Sushi
the sushi rice has the slight extra vinegar kick here (very authentic), light on wasabi
mostly standard fish:
Maguro, Toro, smoked salmon, Hirame with shiso, Hamachi, Hotate, Kaki, Ikura
tonight, the hamachi was my fav
never seen pre-sliced fish (saba) that was actually good
and the prices can't be beat $3.50-4 for 2...impressive
and he'll thank you 5 times
author: Rob C.

description:
I give Okina 4 stars for good solid basic sushi. Nobu is right on this point.

Smoked salmon aside (god, I wish I had been forewarned but we went there on 6.16) Having worked in a traditional sushi restaurant and a contemporary one, I appreciate both sides as long as there are good chefs.

This chef/owner Akio was pleasant enough in a straight-shooting Japanese-serving-gaijin way. Read, blunt communication and plenty of polite formulas with us though *really* over the top friendly and chatty with our nihonjin friend. That's cool except for that he talked to her for an inordinately long time, not making eye contact with anyone else, and frankly I felt left out. 

Nevertheless, Akio has impresive hand skill with the fish (even though he does pre-cut his fish--a definite no-no in "traditional" sushi preparation). And, this place is cleaned and purified, as one of my Japanese friends puts it. This means way cleaner than ANY place that would get an "A" in LA's hygiene rating system.

The sushi is better than nijiya--sorry Mami. The prices are acceptable  too and you don't have to wait to unpack your groceries to enjoy!

The parking situation is BAD! This is a "hidden" location, meaning in the middle of a residential area where people apparently don't ever come or go considering the lack of spaces.

good, but not "oh-my-f-god-sushi-gods-are-in-our-presence." word.
author: G Z.

description:
Finally, after living across this street for a year, we walked into this place. Sure it's homey, sure but that's what makes this place comforting, like home. 

Omakase or chef's choice, is the way to go. And sit at the sushi bar to watch the chef prepare your food. The chef is this funny and cute old man who has been here 25+ years. You get hot green tea upon sitting down. The pieces of fish were fresh and delicious. Yes the salmon is smoked but that's fine, I like the difference in flavor. We had several different fish - salmon, yellow tail, halibut, tuna, unagi, real crab meat, etc. I really liked the nigiri that had shiso leaf in it. In addition to the omakase we ordered a tuna handroll, california roll, alaska roll and salmon skin roll. They were all very tasty. The waitress constantly made sure our hot tea was replenished.  

We will definitely be back!
author: Helena H.

description:
Last Night: the chef at Okina made me feel like a kept woman.  

I don't have the income to do "chef's choice" omakase, ever.  I do not have disposable income, and I'm not yet a trophy wife.

Lou and I sat down on a rainy Friday evening.  It was his last final and my last weekday of stuffing myself silly.  Sillyful.  
I made reservations for 5pm.  I arrived on time.  Lou arrived a little after.  We sat at the bar.  The chef was talkative and his English was very good.  The glass case was absolutely stocked to the brim with tasty tidbits of fish.  I could see small bowls full of shucked miyagi oysters, ikura, kani, hotate.  We were so overwhelmed that we did not know where to start.  
The chef suggested "chef's choice."  The prices on the menu were so reasonable: the uni was $4.
In no particular order:
toro
maguro topped with fresh sea plants
saba
spanish mackeral
halibut with shiso
hotate with baked gonads
oyster
uni
kani
and two others at least.  Maybe there were three more.  1 slice of tamago for dessert.  1 large sake and 1 large beer.
total was $63.xx.  
I could not believe my eyes.  There is a new contender for my sushi husband.  At these prices, I can afford to eat here weekly!  But I'm not sure if I'll want omakase, I'm rather fond of my ika, aji, uni, uni, and sake.  
Reservation only.  Cash only.  This guy is great.  He's nearly 70 years old but he acts and speaks with great strength and ease.  
The walk up the hill and around the corner from the BF's place is quite attractive.  
Such a sushi place so close and I never knew.
author: Christina C.

description:
This is the best kept secret!  You walk by on a regular day and you think its a "whole in the wall business" in a striving neighborhood.  Its never open and the the sign says closed.  But walk buy on a Thursday, Friday or Saturday night and you'll see a little light on inside.  You'll find yourself intrigued and want to walk under the Japanese print cloths that drape in front of the door and turn the knob to see a room the size of a studio apartment.  

With one of the most heart-felt greetings you will feel compelled to sit and wait for a table (if one is not availble), have a cup of tea on the house and watch the chef/owner work his magic behind the sushi bar.  When you do sit and place your order, you may notice that you won't have all the fancy choices of a normal Sushi restaurant down there on Geary, but when your order arrives, you will be more than pleased to taste the tender succulent pieces of fresh fish that you won't find anywhere else.  Your food will melt in your mouth and because the prices are more than reasonable, you will find yourself wanting to order more.  When the bill comes, with no urgency to leave, you will be surprised to see how much food you got for what you are about to pay and realise that you spent almost half as less than you would have at the sushi bar down the street.
author: Tina C.

description:
I did not see what all the buzz is about at Okina.  Yes, the fish was fresh, but nothing to write home about.  Also, just to clarify, Okina does only sushi omakase, not the full on omakase with non-sushi small dishes.

I will have to say that the atmosphere is really quiet and if you're talking above your six inch voice, the entire restaurant can probably hear your conversation.  Overall, good, not great.
author: Eric S.

description:
I really want to like this place.  I really do.  The owner/chef is a sweet old Japanese man who really loves his craft, seems to know his fish, and is very attentive to his customers.  The restaurant is a little hole in the wall in a residential area -- it's literally the size of your living room, with 3 tables and a sushi bar for 6.  They serve only sushi.  They have rarer selections like sardine.  The prices are extremely reasonable ($3 for an order of tuna nigiri).  Everything about it should make me love it.   

But I don't.

I've come back twice now thinking "maybe last time was a fluke"....but it doesn't seem that way.  Why?  Well -- the sushi is just not right.  The rice has a texture of day-old refrigerated rice.  Kind of crusty and not homogenously sticky.  And the fish is cut paper-thin.  There's barely enough of it to catch a flavor of the fish...and then it's gone.  

It's really disappointing too -- this place has all the ingredients for greatness -- an attentive and creative chef, great fish, great unique selection -- yet they fail.
author: Eugene F.

description:
Sitting at the counter the semi-retired chef/owner:
- kept our condiments (wasabi, gari, and takuan) refilled without asking,
- checked with us several times if the tea was satisfactory, 
- chopped up interesting conversation throughout our meal about the Philippines, food, and work,
- served up his food with a giant ear-to-ear smile, 
- and watched us as we ate to be sure we were enjoying ourselves. 

It was my most enjoyable experience at a sushi bar and will definitely be making regular visits. Oh, the fish was good too.
author: David G.

description:
As others have said - only come here if you love nigiri sushi.  This is not a California-fusion places and do not offer any fancy rolls.  That's why this place is so cool and special - this is much more authentic and sitting at the sushi bar is a fun experience.

The limited hours have kept me away though.

Best parts: Simple menu, very fresh fish, authentic experience
Worst parts: Limited hours, cash only, limited selection
author: Bessie T.

description: This place should have a note that says "RESERVATIONS ONLY". I could not really rate it, because I was shunned out of the restaurant. My bf and I went to the place on a Saturday evening around 6pm. The place was empty besides for one group of 4 people eating there. The waitress asked if we had reservations, which we did not, and proceeded by saying "BYE", nothing else, she waived us out of the place and continued saying "bye". Pretty rude I thought, especially for what seemed to be a very slow night. With the amount of places to eat great quality sushi in the Inner-Richmond this place must be doing great to shun people away. Not going back!
author: Pokimonkey S.

description:
Stark. 

This is the one word I would use to describe both the atmosphere and the food. Bright lights, white walls with no pictures, very few tables and so quiet that you can sometimes hear a pin drop (ok, I exaggerate, but you get the idea). 

No Miso soup.
No Salads.
No deserts
No credit cards
Only sush and sashimi.

In a Seinfeld episode, this place would be referred to as the Sushi Nazi.

We ordered omakase (Chef's recommnedations) for both sushi and sashimi. We also asked for the price before putting through the order.

The waitress arrived with the sashimi and told us that it was $41. This was for a small selection of fish. The fish was good, but not fantastic and the pieces were VERY small.

My partner asked for a bowl of rice, and a bowl with about two tablespoons worth of rice was brought.

Then the sushi plate arrived for $17. Some unusual selections including oysers and Uni.....but none of the sushi was outstanding and all very small pieces. The only thing that was good was the price of the sushi.

Don't go......much better out there.
author: Laurence N.

description:
Bare boned sushi.  
Very fresh.  Very efficient (I love Sushi Zone, but Okina sushi master is 10x as fast).  Very simple.  Very good jack fish. 
But don't trust the 10pm thing.  He'll close when he wants to close.
author: amanda g.

description:
I was disappointed.  I think all the reviews really got me excited and I ended up setting the bar a bit too high for Okina.  

One, there's a very limited selection of fish on the menu, just standard fare such as tuna, ebi, uni etc.  Nothing too exciting.  I ended up ordering primarily the specials for the night such as amber jack, toro, striped bass, and several favourites (uni, amaebi, scallop, ikura, and hamachi).  

Two, I agree with all the other yelpers that yes it is indeed fresh and the service is great, but i wasn't too impressed with the scraggly cut pieces of fish nor the portion sizes for the amount I paid.  

Third, the toro was not toro, he served us Maguro.  

Our bill for two was $40 and we left still hungry.  To satisfy our sushi craving, we ended up going to Kabuto to finish up our dinner for the night.
author: Miss H.

description:
I tried to eat here once before and called beforehand to see if they could take a small group.  Their response was, 'please come again, we have run out of fish'.  I think that sums up the size of the establishment.  The sushi here is good.  The menu is small and dont expect them to have everything on the menu anyway, even if they are able to accommodate you.

I think this place is actually a 3.5.  I needed something more though in terms of ambiance, drink selection, menu length, and pickled ginger.  Even just some soft music would be nice or a plant.

I'm filing this restaurant under 'local sushi'.  The kind of place that you go to when you feel like sushi, but not going out of the neighborhood.
author: Rob U.

description:
The menu is beautifully simple, the fish is fresh, the sushi chef is charming, and they take reservations.

Only for true nigiri sushi lovers.  I loved it but S thought they should have offered more rolls.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
Wow. By far the best value for nigiri I've seen in the Bay Area!

Oishii!
author: dj z.

description:
Damn, are we missing something here?  It seems that everyone of us that gives Okina a sub-4 star review feels the same: neta is too thin, shari is kinda dry, selection is mediocre, BUT the interior is nice and the service is great.  We all really wanna love this place, we really really do!

Maybe I gotta give it another try, maybe something was off tonight, I dunno.  I mean, I ordered the omakase!  What did I get?  Something that was "acceptable" in its quality; no more, no less.  Everything was adequately fresh, but just way too small and a little... how can I describe it... "off"?  

Damn, I just don't get it.
author: Ryan D.

description:
It definitely feels different to sit at the counter, where food is delivered to you under a roof and directly on wood. The highlight here is the sushi chef....a little cookie, a little nazi....a good mix. He keeps the menu short and focused while the portions are small but honestly priced. You can have a totally satisfying dinner for $20 and be delighted by the laughing bursts of the chef.
It's his house in the end....
Shari is on the well cooked and acid side, not overly sweet.
author: Dario B.

description:
Found a new awesome sushi place.  My friend recommended this place, she calls it one of her "secret sushi places".  It's because you can walk by the place and never notice it was ever there.  There's just a tiny wood sign that's just over the door and that's it.  
Went there early because we didn't have an reservations, they took us in right away and we had a choice of sitting at the counter or table, me and my gf picked the counter, which was the BEST choice.  We sat there just staring at the tiny menu that didn't have a lot of items like we thought there would be.  We were about to order until the old man that's doing the sushi asked if we wanted the chef recommendations.  We just said "ok".  If you go there and the sushi chef ask you if you want the Chef Recommendation, say YES or ask for it.  
Everything he put down was just amazing.  I only remember some of the names of the items he gave us, Toro, Uni, Halibut.  Right next to me there were 2 girls that were about to order their own items and then saw what we had, they hurried and changed their minds and had the chef recommendations also, that's how good it was.  One other guy that was leaving said one thing, "sir, you are an artist"!  I agree. 
Sushi chef was a really nice guy, he chatted with the patrons and cracked jokes, you can see the work he was doing.  
This is one place you have to go to.  Also the prices are not expensive for sushi, more in the lower moderate range.  
Must go to place for sure!
author: Peter L.

description:
Great traditional sushi served at a sushi bar with an angled counter that allows the chef to place the sushi in front of you without plates.  

The owner / sushi chef Akio Matsuoka told us that his name was James Bond, and even shared with us his secret to staying young and his philosophy of life.  

The fish was fresh and the most inexpensive and yet high quality I have ever had.  The hamachi was better than the toro on our night.  Ask for the uni hand roll - super good.

We will definitely be back.
author: Joel K.

description:
I'm not a sushi snob, but eat here I did, and it was excellent. The place prides itself in its food and as such, does not carry a pretentious attitude about the decor or the menu.  Located in a very quiet part of Richmond, the restaurant carries a very simple (short) menu and a very simple and clean atmosphere.  The nigiri and the delux sushi were bomb, and as I am a big unagi fan, I can tell you it was out of this world (AND LARGE PORTIONS!).  For the first time that I can ever recall, I finished all the portions.... and honestly, very tasty.

A friendly environment too, the waitress was very attentive and kind and the chef personally thanked us for coming and gave us high-fives.  Oh yeah, and it was unexpectadly cheap.  :)
author: Vicky B.

description: Been in the neighborhood  for  a while and finally tried Okina. Why did we wait? Should have come here sooner. Nothing fancy and def. not over priced. We ate our way through the menu and and left full and happy.
author: Kim C.

description:
With six seats at the bar and a couple of tables, this hidden sushi bar is on the small side.  Only open three nights a week.  Simple, traditional menu--there is no 49er roll.

The fish is delicous and always very fresh but, like San Francisco, is kind of on the cold side.  Just sit back and let the chef/owner/upstairs resident pick what's next.

Or so I've been told. Regrettably, San Francisco's arcane and prejudicial health regulations do not allow me to dine inside this restaurant.
author: spot d.

description:
Okay...this place was a secret low key place...but yelpers seem to voice it out loud to the masses.

The sushi sensei knows how to make his rice perfect and the prices are great. Parking is good and one can even try to park on Fulton if you get there early enough. 

It is generally packed, but prepare for it and enjoy.
author: miriam b.

description:
my favorite sushi place in the us. the fish is always fresh (bought the morning of) and the best grade. the portion is japanese (less than half the size of the typical american sushi - i am not a hater, just giving a visual image). there aren't any fancy rolls here - just the basics. 

the first time we came here without a reservation, the chance of getting a table was slim (come back next time or order take out). we made a reservation the following week and every time we wanted to eat there.

ok, sushi time. our must haves are tuna, eel, yellow fin, scallops, spanish mackerel, mackerel, and halibut. sometimes, we couldn't get the halibut because we came around 9. however, if you like halibut, call in advance and ask to reserve some.

the chef is talkative (when he is not extremely busy). the service is always quick, attentive, and nice. 

the decor is authentic simple japanese.
author: huong n.

description:
Oh my god the fresh fish.  The nigiri.... the prices...

Usually I love the complicated Americanized crazy stuff in them rolls. But this place brings out what I am sure is the only 'purist' part of me.  I like the fish, I like the rice.  I don't need anything else.   

And I can afford to just get the fish here too.
author: Heidi P.

description:
Very fresh sushi for relatively cheap prices! 
The Itamae is very nice too!

The only thing I didn't like was the smoked salmon.  I prefer it regular.
author: Du D.

description: MAKE A RESERVATION! Great LITTLE sushi place. Nice decor. Only down side: doesn't take credit card. We were fortunate enough to get there early when there was a table available. Friendly staff and good food.
author: Nathan S.

description:
One would think a place hidden, that only opens from Thursday to Sunday and seats 14 at maximum capacity with a limited menu would have something spectacular to present but no, it doesn't. 

First off, the nigiri rice ball was too big and dry. Secondly, all the fish was already pre-cut (WTH!- what the heck). The tamago...ugh, it was dry and bland. I tend to like Tamago with a hint of sweetness, but this Tamago had absolutely no sweetness to it. 

On a more positive note, I did enjoy the extra pickled yellow radish he gave me, although it's not something you would normally eat at a sushi restaurant. The waitress was nice and prompt. Well, we were the only customers there at the time, so it shouldn't have been that hard for her.

It didn't knock my socks off, but I might go there again.
author: tina h.

description:
I would give Okina a better rating as it is very traditional and the restaurant is petite, not crowded and has a friendly mom-pops atmosphere. The fish is fresh and the price is good.

However...it is thee most quiet place I think I have been to and when you walk in, everyone (the 12 living souls + chef and waitress) gets a fantastic look at you, who you are,what you're wearing if you have a reservation and who you are with. And for some reason, everytime the door would open, the same silent feeling would sweep across the room. Conversation level is pretty much at negative decibels...so it can be semi awkward if you will.

We ordered Omakase...it was good but about 45 minutes later, realized that the first sushi plate was the only thing you were eating unless you ordered everything else a la carte. Typically you see some cooked fish, or cooked rolls but they had to later inform us that there is no cooking there. 

Will go back next time in preparation to order more food.
author: MJMH H.

description: One of the best sushi restaurants I had. Great service, delicious sushi/sashimi and really cheap.
author: Dennis P.

description:
There is not a huge selection of fish at Okina, but what they have is amazing.  

I have gone to almost every sushi spot in San Francisco and Okina ranks amongst the top.  

I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Max C.

description: I tend to like odd places - and I was thrilled when I first walked into this "hole-in-the-wall". The place had this "best-kept-secret" vibe to it. Unpretentious and quality, this one-family operation is committed to serve fresh fish. Do not expect uber-fancy creative rolls, just a limited traditional staff on the menu. I am not very much into omakase style (allowing chef to feed you), but this place is intimate enough to try it at the bar. Tip: no credit cars are accepted, and reservation are recommended as the place is tiny.
author: Lana L.

description: Really great basic sushi. No frills, no whacky rolls. To me the sushi itself gets 5 stars but I like to call it quiet sushi as there is so little atmosphere and the music is barely audible that it's kinda weird in there. I feel like I should never talk above a whisper. That said it is a nice little neighborhood place that lives by it's own rules.
author: Douglas C.

description:
I am reluctant to write this review because maybe it will encourage more people to go. 

Fortunately, one of the great things about Okina is that it  is not for everyone. It is not a Japanese restaurant. It is a brilliant little neighborhood sushi spot. Sushi is all they serve. It is a place that faithful customers go back to again and again. With simple good food, clean minimalist decor, and gracious service. I have been sent away on the grounds that "there was not sufficient selection" that night.

They are open from 5 - 10 Thursday, Friday and Saturday, there is only seating for 16 which is divided between three tables and a bar. 

I'm sure there is better sushi and more appealing atmosphere elsewhere, and if those are the things that you are looking for then please go... it will leave more room at the bar for the party faithful to watch the simplest kind of magic.
author: Julianna L.

description:
Hands down - my favorite sushi spot in San Francisco.  

Moving back to the east coast has come up quite a few times in the past year, and whenever I've thought about the places I would miss in San Francisco, Okina is one of the places that comes to mind first.  I think about food after all the fabulous people, of course.
author: Sassy S.

description: I'd wanted to try this place for months, but they're only open three days a week and we just couldn't seem to make it happen.  It was definitely worth the anticipation.  The sushi chef, a 68 year old Japanese man who's owned the restaurant for 27 years, is as talented as he is warm and hospitable.   We sat at the counter, ordered omakase and put ourselves in his hands.  Don't ask, just eat it.  Bring your own sake and the corkage is $5.  I'm not kidding.  If you think it's possible to reach a sushi pinnacle where it just can't get any better or fresher, then here's where you'll find it.  If you don't think it's possible, then this is where you'll change your mind.
author: P J.

description: This is the perfect sushi restaurant. It's small, cozy, and quiet. The menu is simple and the sushi is some of the best I've had. Sit at the sushi bar and order up a storm!
author: Korey C.

description: I love the sushi at Okina! It's simple, fresh and tasty! The space is small, so I suggest making a reservation and allow enough time to find parking. Although, there is plenty of parking on Fulton, a few blocks away. The chef is professional, yet has a quirky sense of humor. He is one of the best and a personal favorite of mine:) I have no interest in going to the typical SF sushi bar with a four page menu of gourmet rolls etc.. This is more traditional!
author: Lori A.

description: Okina Sushi is unbelievably good...extremely fresh fish, and completely authentic. No baked salmon rolls or rolls drown in spicy sauces on this menu. If they have the fatty tuna, definitely give it a go..it's probably the best sashimi I've had in San Francisco.
author: Brianne K.

description:
I regret that I am writing a review now.  

I just did not want to expose this place more to public.  They have only three tables and one counter, and the chef (no chefS, only one guy who looks SOOOO Japanese! :) is very nice.  The service could be slow sometimes but come on, it's real fresh made sushi right in front of you.  

I definitely recommend you to sit at the counter, talk to the nice bald man who looks like martial art master.  Their sushi was definitely THE BEST IN THE NATION so far.  One hidden small place far from restaurants...  It's one nice story in this city.

By the way, Omakase (meaning let the chef decides what to serve!) 8 pieces of sushi from 10 bucks...  That's SICK.  And they are not all eggs or all avocado crap, or just CUCUMBER ROLLS!
author: T T.

description: This teeny tiny restaurant (bar with around 4 seats and about 6 tables tot?) tucked away in the Richmond district is one of my favorite spots for sushi. The bare boned menu is authentic and reasonably priced.  And the fish is *amazingly* fresh. The chef/owner and the one server there provide low key, friendly and efficient service.
author: Trinh T.

description: I really like this place. Simple and basic, no frills sushi. What you see: small place, a few tables and a 6 seat sushi bar, 1 waitress and 1 chef. What you get: the freshest fish you can find, a friendly and talkative (though not very understandable) chef, oh, and also INCREDIBLY FRESH FISH. And amazingly affordable as well. Great place, will go back often.
author: Josh G.

description: I've only been here one time and its been almost a year but I seriously can't stop thinking about the sushi here!! It was fresh and was very creatively constructed. We sat at the sushi bar and told the chef to serve us whatever was special for the day (i recommend that you do this too if you go!) and it was great sashimi after another! yummmm...i think i need to go again soon!!
author: Cecilia S.

description: Went to Okina for some sushi tonight and had some of the best fish I've had in S.F.  This restaurant is tiny, with maybe four tables and some places at the sushi bar.  And from what I can tell, all they serve is what I as a honkey, will call sushi.  They have maki, nigiri, and sashimi, not a huge selection, but they do it quite well.  For my party of three we ordered chefs choice which came with a little of each of those, deftly arranged on a big platter.  The fish was fresh and tasted very good.  I really liked the salmon skin rolls we were served and the makrel was prepared perfectly, very good. It was just enough to fill us up, and for as much as we had, the price was a lot less than I expected.
author: Adrian L.

description:
straight up honest review - no frills:

the yeahs:
quaint and authentic venue
attentive and personable service
pretty fresh fish.  yummy california rolls with real crab.
the best uni and quail egg ever wrapped in fragrant roasted seaweed (this is what earned the extra half star to make four)

the meh's:
portions too small - even for a little girl like me.
smoked salmon didn't taste too fresh
could use more selection (no miso soup, salad, or coke!)
author: Josie M.

description: This is definitely one of my favorite sushi spots in the city.  It's clear that sushi is this man's passion.  I've loved every meal I've had here. There aren't a bunch of fancy rolls on the menu, just the best, freshest fish in the city.  Very limited sake selection, but we just bring a bottle of our own.
author: Cosmolicious L.

description: The only way I found this Sushi bar was because I lived next store to it when I first moved to the city and "Thank Goodness"!  If traditional Sushi is what you are after, without the Spider rolls and tempura, then this is the place.  Has been around for years and Aquino(Owner) is dead on with the freshest fish carved perfectly.  Only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is that it is open Thursday, Friday and Saturday only.
author: Steven S.

description:
i'll never ever go back to this place.

this place may be the cleanest place in sf, but the whole floor smells like swimming pool.  fish -  not fresh, nori - soggy, rice - too much sushi vinegar. the chef was keep making racial slurs and when he asked if we agree with him or not. that's when we left.
author: ringo m.

description: I hate to review this because I don't want it to get any more crowded, but it's just too darn good! Try the jackfish, which is always amazing, and otherwise, just sit at the bar and ask the chef for recommendations (the fatty tuna is often absolutely delicious, too). It's obvious he takes a lot of pride in his work. Try to go on a Thursday or Friday. By 8 pm on a Saturday, they may be running out of the best fish.
author: Nicole S.

description:
CHOOOOOOOOOOO (prounounced cho) UME!!!!!!!!!

After coming back from living in Japan, I was *deep big sigh* tired of seeing and tasting fake Japanese-American sushi.  Don't get me wrong, I love my favorite fruit, avocado, but when it comes to authentic sushi, OKINA does it best.  I had it on Saturday night and I was already craving it again Sunday late afternoon thinking dammit! I have to wait until Thursday because it's only opened Th-Sat.  My only tip... get there early or else he'll run out!

I came in with:
A reservation for 6
A frustrated belly because it was so dang hard to find parking
60 bucks in cash
Tons of GENKI-ness
5 other friends with gynormous appetites
1 HUGE bottle of Sho Chiku Bai sake

What we didn't get:
Toro & Hamachi

What we got:
- Hot sake  AWWWWW YEAAAAA...
- A number of nigiri inc. jackfish, a variety of shrimp, maguro, tamago and more
- The runner up nigiri: kampachi wrapped in shiso leaf.  anything wrapped in this leaf just kicks it up a notch
- All the good stuff ran out so they turned away other customers and we had special service for the rest of the night until they closed
- A passionate, charming sushi chef that laughed, joked and talked with us about his family and how he came to SF with 3 knives
- Surprise number 1 of the night was the raw scallop nigiri with a bit of lemon juice that zings like a lightening bolt in your mouth, but smooths over with a velvety texture leaving the experience from the beginning to middle to end unforgettable!  We had to ask for another!
- Surprise number 2 was that I paid 25 for my portion which has never happened to me in my life!
- Of course, stuffed big bellies and drunken good times
author: Yoko H.

description: The Balboa Corridor has been in a continuous state of restaurant reinvention, with an annual, repetitive case of "out with the old, in with the new." One thing hasn't changed: Okina, who have occupied their piece of Arguello & Fulton for a long time. How does Okina manage to continue to happily serve the local hood and USF students? By keeping things simple: fresh nigiri, simple decor, cozy ambiance. One note: womenfolk seem to get "extra attention" and I DO mean "extra"...like "too much Thanksgiving turkey exra attention," like syrup smothering griddlecakes extra attention," like "too much ketchup on your dog" attention. But hey.... good sushi.
author: Johnny C.

description: I can eat here every day but they are ONLY open on Thurs. Fri. & Sat. evening. The owner has been making sushi at this location for 25+ years and he enjoys what he does. Every piece of sushi he cuts is perfect and the service is excellent.
author: Deb C.

description: A hidden gem. No frills - just great food and good service. We will definitely be going back.
author: Katie S.

description: The food here is super fresh and price is very reasonable. I suggest you make a reservation. This place is tiny so you may need to wait for a long time if you don't have reservation.
author: Lisa J.

description: Best sushi I've had in the city. Hate to post it, but feel obligated to let people know about this great place.
author: k. w.

description: Thank you Okina for the best sushi experience I've ever had!!!  Prices here are the best in the City and you won't be disappointed.  The freshest assortment of toro, hamachi, and uni I have ever had in my life.  The salmon roe with quail egg was so delicate and fresh, the flavor melted in my mouth.  The uni was the freshest and had the mildest flavor.  Hamachi was rich and buttery.  Okina has the freshest sushi in SF with the cheapest prices.  The waiter is the most attentive and courteous, and the sushi chef is able to make magic with his hands.  Best sushi in SF by far with the freshest fish and cheapest price.  I LOVE OKINA!!!
author: Darren I.

description: sushi was great as nobu said.  authentic!  I loved the size, the presentation, and the nori and wasabi too.  the menu is very small! only sushi!  it may have been cheaper than other places but we still spent $50/ea...  we are alcohol drinking sushi eatin' piggies.  i  talked a lot with the chef, too.  he is a genuinely friendly man and has a passion for the art of sushi.
author: Dawn P.

description: ok I live right around the corner and have never eaten here but I give this place five stars because the owner is the nicest guy on the planet.  When I walk past him I greet him in Japanese and now he recognizes me when he sees me in the city and greets me.  Just a really nice guy so I can't see how the serives or food at his place could be bad since it seats 5.5 people.  Too bad I don't eat fish or I'd be a super regular.
author: Nick L.

description:
You've gotta be kidding me!

Dank, dark, and musty smelling place.

"Pre-Cut" fish. Definitely a third-tier establishment.
author: frank g.

description: Delicious and super fresh sashimi.  A pretty small selection (no rolls, etc) because they serve only the freshest fish they've had flown in that day.  The owner/chef is very nice, and you always get good attention because the place is teeny - only 4 or so tables, and 6-8 seats at the bar (where he serves the food directly onto the countertop).  Since it's so small and they're open just Thurs/Fri/Sat, it's worth coming early (I've also seen people call in reservations for tables).
author: kate g.

description: Short and simple, this place blew my mind.  No more no less, I shall for sure be back!!!
author: Nicole F.

description: Okina is super quirky and the owner and waiter are sweet hearts. Their hospitality alone brings us back. We love the simplicity, the fresh fish and we appreciate that the owner has been doing this for 20-some years. This is where we go when we get sick of how trendy our neighborhood has become. It just reminds us that there are still little hidden gems in SF that are mellow and welcome all people with out attitude.
author: London E.

description: Very traditional sushi place; a couple of maki rolls, nigiri and sashimi.  That's it and it's awesome.  The only downside is that there are no hot dishes and it's a cash only place open 3 nights a week.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Open only TR, FRI and SAT. Great little "hidden gem." Very good sushi/sashimi and minimal rolls with good prices. And that's all there is, no bells, whistles or flashing lights. This is a real bare bones sushi place that has only the sushi bar and 3 tables. There's one chef and one server. With that said, don't go and ask for edamame, the chef doesn't do that. No Wakame salad either, and no 35 different types of sake to go along with your sushi tasting menu. This place is not that. They only take cash and when the Chef's tired or had enough he'll ask the diner that just walked in at 8:15 pm on a Friday nite to lock the door behind him. How can you not love that?!
author: cora j.

description:
Others have covered the basics, but a few comments:

- Akio is in his 60s, not his 80s, or at least that's what he says

- they do serve sake, but I think only 1 kind

- I haven't experienced the running-out-of-fish on Saturday problem. so don't worry about that too much

- this is not the place to take friends who say that they like sushi, but won't actually eat raw fish

- it's also not a place for vegetarians
author: David D.

description: I loved this place. I didn't even know what shiso was until it was served to me here with jack fish. Now I can't stop thinking about it.
author: Kelly S.

description:
i loved it here! it wasnt like other sushi places where things are all fried & stuff. this is straight up japan sushi! loved it! my cousin didnt like it at all because she never seen a place like this. but it's ok. we only had 3 things & it was good to me! very very good! the girl next to us got the chef's recommendation & it looked sooo good to me! because i'm the kind that eats sashimi. so i will come here again with my friend that loves sashimi! hopefully i will get to try the sashimi next time. 

warning! if you got used to all the other places with fried sushi stuff, dont come here because it's a whole different atmosphere.
author: Jenny H.

description: Really great fresh nigiris at this joint. I love the lil setup in this place and eating at the counter is fun cos he places all your orders on the "dashboard" (platform) and the chef is really nice and friendly. The fish was so fresh that it kinda melts in your mouth. He does his omakase by pieces...so as many as you want to eat,  you will be charged accordingly and it was so unbelievable reasonable. If you are looking for crazy rolls, this is not the place. The menu is somewhat limited but I really love the taste and quality of the food and the warmth of the chef. This is certainly the best kept secret ever!
author: Topazskye L.

description:
one word....overrated!!

perhaps i came to okina on a bad night, but to be honest, a restaurant should be measured by its ability to serve high quality food day after day. and im reasonable enough to think that maybe its not so bad since so many people have said good things, but i have to air my frustration and disappointment.

first, we walk in around 730, and the waitress says we can be seated immediately, but must finish by 830 to make room for another reservation. not that big of a deal, but a little odd to hear and definitely the first time i have ever heard that. i mean, its not like we came in at 815 or something, so was it really necessary?
