on to the fish. what a disappointment! very sparse selection of fish...they didnt even have fresh salmon, only smoked. and their toro? i was shocked to see fish that had the same bright red color as the maguro! it lacked the pinkish color and marbled fat that you typically see, and it definitely didnt taste buttery. and dont even get me started on the nigiri presentation! many of the nigiri were not sliced properly, resulting in jagged edges, disproportion to the rice, inconsistent size, and overall, a very, very sloppy attempt at what is normally considered an art.

i dont care how cheap this place is. sure its almost half the price of some places, but surely not worth the money saved for such a mediocre experience. 

i will say, however, that the unagi was incredible. but thats about all the praise i can give this place.

will i ever go back? probably not, unless this place someday gets to 300 reviews and remains 4 stars. otherwise, i'm back on the hunt searching for something that can live up to ino sushi.
author: David C.

description:
I've never wanted to review Okina....but alas, I think it is finally time.

Look, hands down, this is the best place for SUSHI - ya know, raw fish, rice, that whole deal - in the City of San Francisco. I know that's a bold statement, but it is the truth. How do I have the authority to say that? Well, I just do. Simple as that. I've been going to Okina for over 2 years now, and I haven't had one bad piece of fish. Ever.

With that being said, do me a favor: Don't patronize Okina (too much). As another yelper said, if you did go here as often as (we) I do, then I'll have to fight you for a table, or a spot at the bar next to Akiyo-san. And that'd be bad news.

I can understand why some folks are anti-Okina -- it is kinda a cult-ish place, with the same "followers" (regulars) who are there week after week (like me!). That doesn't jive well for some. Neither does the fact that he accepts cash only, he cuts his fish ahead of time (so that he can manage serving 14 people fairly quickly!) and he doesn't offer anything outside of fish, fish, and more fish.

Go to Okina. Eat good fish. Be happy!

(and be sure to try the Kampachi!)
author: Leigh R.

description: I actually ate here over two years ago and had a wonderful experience.  The restaurant is tiny and quiet, the fish is fresh and simple.  Having lived in Japan for over two years this restaurant reminded me of many I ate at in Tokyo.  There is only one sushi chef and he is Japanese so the experience is more personal than most places you've been to in the U.S.  That being said, sometimes there is a line to get in and sometimes you are the only one in the restaurant.  But if you want to eat fresh delicious sushi and talk to the person you are dining with - this is the place.
author: V T.

description:
Given all the excellent reviews of this restaurant I was really looking forward to my first meal there.

My happy anticipation ended when I was seated at the sushi bar in clear view of pre-cut piles of previously fresh fish that was now air-dried, discolored, and lacking full flavor.  It was the least appetizing visual I've ever encountered in a situation in which freshness, rather than interesting cooking techniques, is the primary ingredient sushi should offer.

Perhaps if you are very new to sushi and don't mind the looks of the fish and the lack of variety of presentation,  you will also enjoy Okina.  Certainly the sweet simple atmosphere and the lovely staff are as pleasing as everyone else has noted- it's just not nearly enough to entice me to go there again.

If you are accustomed to eating sushi from freshly sliced fish, you will not feel that Okina is a bargain at any price- I paid $36 including tax for 8 orders of two pieces each.
author: paula c.

description: Yummm. The sushi was so fresh and delicious. Careful there is wasabi in the rolls. Rolls or Sashimi is about the only thing they have though so if your looking for some teryaki or tempura go elsewhere. And all they have is booze or tea no soda. The Sashimi was AWESOME!! So if your looking for a simple fresh and delicious sushi place this is your spot.
author: Seanna S.

description:
(addendum: the more i think about it, the more i i realize i'm not into the sushi here. but it's still charming)

regardless of the sushi, EVERYBODY SHOULD TRY OKINA at least once just to get acquainted with the sushi chef.

he is the sweetest, kindest, most down-to-earth sushi chef ever!

i couldn't believe how wonderfully lovely he was. a warm smile and convivial attitude. and the host was also a pleasure.

i also love okina for the restaurant design and facade. so simple and hidden away. it is really minimalistic and intimate. 

good for a date. check out my pictures if you want a feel for the ambiance and look. love that "port hole" in the wall. it glows. 
http://www.flickr.com/photos/bittermelon/sets/72157594550762890/

i ordered basically EVERYTHING on the menu. 

i knew we'd be in good hands when he plopped down a mix of radishes, cucumbers, ginger right onto the counter (i'm a big fan of this method - using the counter as a plate). 

okay, but here's the confession:

i didn't think the sushi was fantastic or mindblowing. yes, it was good, certainly superior to 99% of the sushi establishments in the bay area. but something was lacking...not sure if i can pinpoint it. 

regardless, everything is fresh and artfully made. just nice to look at.

the unagi was plump and dense, more like a real slab of meat than most unagi - which falls apart easily, melts right on contact with your mouth, too elusive a bite. 

this was the first time i tried amaebi, and i'm glad i did it at okina. 

okina is a superb experience, but again, it's not because of the sushi.
author: jennifer y.

description: The freshest fish I've ever had! I went to this place once and am so happy that I as able to track it down on here so I can go back! Delicious, melt-in-your-mouth Toro. Nice atmosphere and delicate food presentation. I can go over $30 easily, but that's a good thing!
author: Judy R.

description:
delicious.  fresh.  authentic.  friendly.  cozy.

doesn't get much better for me
author: J B.

description: I live a few houses away so I've known the owner since I was a little child.  He would hook me up with so much stuff! I know exactly what goes on at this establishment. Great pure sushi and a wonderful environment. No california rolls here folks. Keep the crowds coming because it's not a secret anymore!
author: SF N.

description:
The fish was pre-cut and dry. The nigiri was different because the fish was sliced very thin while the rice ball was big. When I ordered sashimi the chef refused and said 'sushi is better.' Though he was nice enough to give all the customers sitting by the counter the free tamago nobody wanted, the tamago was so cold that it numbed my front teeth.

Uni was $4. Ika was Seasonal.

I went because my friend highly recommended it. Maybe it was a bad Saturday. May try it on a Friday to see if he has fresh fish.
author: Bias W.

description: All these reviews are correct!!! Great fresh sushi, sits about 16 people in the restaurant (4 waiting seats), and a really nice Chef.  They really do make you feel appreciated
author: Jesse O.

description: Once you come here, you'll understand how this place is run. Basically there are only few tables and 6 seats in front of Sushi Counter. One sushi chef and a waitress. That's it. This place is very small and you cant expect super fast service here. But just like sushi bars in Japan, you should come with great patience and just feel the zen atmosphere. I really enjoyed the experience but my advice to you is that dont come here to stuff your stomach. Enjoy your food slowly so you will be satisfied when you leave. Be aware no credit cards!!
author: Shumi S.

description: Nobu's right! Great experience and just what I was looking for. Quiet, intime, delicious fresh fish and great prices. I'll be back.
author: jim b.

description: Returned to Okina a number of times since my first visit - not only because it's across the street from my house - but for the amazing tea, fresh nigiri and uber-friendly service. All at the best prices you'll find in the city.
author: Kelly R.

description: Very cute, hole in the wall, sushi place in the Richmond. Very hard to find because they don't have a large sign out front. Don't come here if you expect to eat sushi rolls. Came here on a first date and basically ordered Chef's choice and was pleasantly surprised by the assortment of nigiri that we were served. The quality of the fish here is great and very reasonable priced. Although dining here ended up being somewhat of an adventure in terms of what I ended up actually eating, I really enjoyed my meal here.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
i have to admit, i would give this place four stars and a half... too bad there's no half haha

also, you really have to look for this place bc you wouldnt know it's a restaurant just by passing it. 

the place is small but homie. you can tell some ppl there were regulars. portions are not that big but the fish is super fresh. i eat sushi a lot. i can tell when it's good. also, there arent that many selections. it's more of a sushi/sashimi place. they dont have combo dinners and such. 

i was afraid the price was gonna be expensive but it's not at all. 

this place is by far my favorite japanese restaurant so far.
author: Eliza C.

description: Best I've had in SF! I haven't had sushi like this since I've been in Tsukiji.
author: Alton Y.

description: Am I missing something?  I expected more from all the rave reviews.  Granted the chef/owner  is pretyy adorable but as for the food - I didn't find the portions that good, the prices that cheap or the fish that fresh.  As another yelper noted,  I'm not even sure the toro was toro - it didn't melt in my mouth.  The amaebi had a weird brownish tint to it - maybe because it was already prepared ahead of time.  I also felt that too many of the items had shiso leaves in it.  I told the chef that I would eat anything so just give me his freshest favorites and he kept serving tamago!  Sorry, I really wanted to like the place but it didn't happen for me...
author: Amina B.

description: if you cant appreciate true nigri please dont insult a legend by coming here... stay away so i can enjoy authentic japanese at its finest...
author: Nic M.

description:
simple math - best value for quality fish in the city.
you can come but please don't tell anyone.
author: Minotaur N.

description: I went to Okina for something new and I saw that it had great reviews. The pieces of nigiri were small and the quality of the fish was not that good. The yellow tail in particular did not look that good. My girl friend is vegetarian and there was nothing on the menu for her to order. They did not even know how to make vege sushi that was inspired. I first thought it was cheap but because the pieces were small and I had to order extra, it ended up being more expensive than some better places.
author: Jamie M.

description: This place is so cheap and the sushi is pretty good.  5 stars right there.
author: Jason C.

description:
i'm not a big fan of the shiso leaf.  but it was included with our orders of jack/halibut/toro.  we got to the restaurant around 8:30 saturday night and they were out of hamachi (my fave).   the best thing i had was the shrimp and avocado roll.  kinda sad to say a roll was the best thing at a sushi place.  in general, i thought the fish was too cold and lacked flavor.  

but the chef makes the experience and the price isn't exhorbitant...which probably means we will be coming back.

next time, i'll make note not to sit at the bar...so i can pick out the shiso leaf without any guilt.
author: Adela K.

description: Tiny place with a big heart.  Three small tables and a sushi bar with seven seats.  They take reservations and I suggest you make them.
author: Tom H.

description:
The Best Deal Sushi in San Francisco!

Only open Thurs, Fri, & Sat from 5 - 10pm. Go early for the best selection of fish!

The decor feels like you are sitting at a real authentic sushi stand in Japan. Warm personal service from the waitress who will replace your tea mug every time it is low. Give your order to the chef and watch him work his magic, thank you profusely, and plop your nigiri down on the counter in front of you like a pro.

The fish is fresh, most nigiri are $2.50-$4.00, and the quality is what you would expect for double the price. They even have toro for 6-8 dollars! Admittedly it is not the practically falling apart buttery melt in your mouth kind, but it is still a bright pinkish super high quality fatty maguro cut. You simply can not go wrong with this place!
author: M. W.

description:
Very traditional sushi.  Don't expect flowing lava rolls, exploding dynamite, or even spicy tuna roll.  Just fish, rice, seaweed, with a smudge of wasabi.

Sit at the bar and go omakase.  It's the easy way to get stuff that's not on the menu.

4 stars for the food, +1 because the chef is a super nice guy!
author: Chris C.

description: This place is truly a hidden gem.  Open 3 days a week, Okina serves a limited amount of different kinds of sushi for surpisingly cheap.  I'm not a big sushi fan myself, but I enjoyed the quaint little experience with friends. Sushi in general doesn't really fill me up.  It takes about $30 worth for me to feel satisfied.  Friendly service, too!  Adios!
author: Scott G.

description: Omakase all the way!    Okina rocks and it is cheap.  Don't forget to get reservations!  If you are a true sushi afficianodo, you must goto Okina.
author: Stan V.

description: Okina is in an elite class of sushi restaurants in the US. Okina san has been serving it up in this traditional way for 26 years in the same location. He's only open Thur/Fri/Sat evenings, and it is well worth it to make the trek to the inner Richmond to enjoy it. Enough said. If you do not truly appreciate traditional Japanese sushi, you may not like it as you will not find americanized rolls here :). I don't want to hype it too much tho--keep the crowds away.
author: John D.

description: Best, freshest fish in San Francisco.
author: Adam L.

description:
Why one star? You might ask yourself.  I tried to decide how many stars racism served with decent food is worth and it is worth one star.  

I went to Okina about a year ago with my girlfriend, who happens to be Japanese.  We showed up pretty late and I was starving.  The old sushi chef barely looked at me and spent all night talking to my girl friend in Japanese.  I do not mind this at all, and often enjoy hearing her converse in her native tongue.  The evening would have been fine except that he was being racist and insulting me in Japanese right in front of my face.

Over the course of the meal he asked her why she is dating a white guy, to break up with me and date a Japanese guy and told her to bring her girl friends ONLY next time she comes.  

The chef also made a point to get out a newspaper clipping the day after the United States bomb Hiroshima and go into horrible details about his personal experience in Hiroshima.  You could not write a movie scene with worse ambiance and uncomfortable situations.  

I was hungry enough that I did not confront the old man on his treatment of me and my girlfriend.  I decided that it was instead my duty to write a review about his bad behavior to share with fellow Yelpers.

On a final note, I love Japanese food and culture and would urge sushi lovers to spend their money else where or brush up on their Japanese to hear what is being said about you and your company.
author: Casey H.

description: Many Japanese restaurants in the city offer menus packed with a legendary number of dishes (none of which are that good).  This is definitely not one of those places.  Although the menu is limited, the basics such as nigiri, sashimi, and hand rolls are included, and the sushi quality and taste are good.  The cuts are relatively fresh, and some are seasonal and at market price.  The place itself is pretty small, there are 4 tables and 6 sushi bar seats so if you go on a Friday night like we did, expect a bit of a wait.  The sake and house wine are really cheap and only a couple of bucks.  What made this place really stand out was the price, and I would go back on value alone.
author: JoKr M.

description: First off, this is one of the most basic Japanese restaurant we've ever been to in the US (definitely reminds us of our stays in Japan) and if you are willing to accept that, you'll understand the 3.5-4 star rating. No special rolls, no cooked foods from the kitchen, ie. tempura and no more than 16 seats in the place, which somewhat resembled the downstairs of someone's home.  It's either rolls(no spicy tuna since they do not have hot sauce) or nigiri.  Great price for the value, toro nigiri for $6 and amaebi nigiri for $3, don't know where else to find these prices.  We wouldn't go to the Richmond just for this restaurant but if we were already in the area and felt like getting sushi, we'd dropped in.
author: bunnymouse k.

description: My 2nd favorite mom and pop  traditional sushi spot.  The prices here are very reasonable for the quality that you get.  I was a little thrown off the first time I sat at the sushi bar and the chef placed my order directly on the wood display area instead of using plates.  The service is fast and friendly, especilly for a traditionl sushi place.  I always get my entire order within 10 minutes of ordering.  The only downside is that the place is only open 3 days a week and street parking is hard to find sometimes.
author: Janny J.

description:
Sushi - fresh and yummy, reasonably priced, good structural integrity and consistency (note - not many veggie options)
Service - attentive and prompt, but not pushy
Size - its small, but has a laid back vibe; we went early because it can be hard to get in otherwise
Noise level - I loved that it was easy to talk to and hear everyone at my table without having to raise voices
Location - right around the corner . . . fantastic!
author: Kristin B.

description:
I'm still learning my way around sushi and like to try new places around the neighbourhood, so went here with my wife one Friday night.  The folks operating the restaurant are friendly, and even though we didn't have reservations they found us a table in this small venue (even though all other tables were empty for our entire dinner, save a couple of folks at the bar).

The food came fast, but therein lies the downside.  It seemed to arrive a little to fast, and the fish seemed a little dry, not glistening as though freshly cut.  Our assumption was that they maybe cut a few standards and have them on hand for the evening...  Was pretty tasty, and I'm sure it was very fresh, but as I'm learning that good sushi is about more senses than just taste (I'm thinking texture, look...) I'll have to say 3 stars.
author: Andy M.

description: Craving a snack, I happened to be in the area and decided to drop in on Okina.  I had heard about the size of the establishment and braced myself for a wait.  Surprisingly, no one was there.  I easily scored a seat at the counter.  It's so true about the sushi chef...expect to be thanked many times over.  He is soooo nice and very skilled in his craft.  The wood counter is used to serve up your sushi...saves on plates and it's also an indication how serious they are about their sushi here.  A quick glance at the wall and you'll see their health inspection card of 100.  It's impeccably clean here with a minimalist design.  To continue with the minimalist concept, their menu is only sushi and sashimi, which suits me fine.  Since I was only snacking, I stuck with ordering nigiri...no maki for me.  I scanned the menu and ordered up my usual fare of amaebi, uni, and hamachi.  I was hoping for some sake (fresh salmon) but all they had was smoked, which surprised me.  I opted for a kani (fresh crab), which out of the nigiri that I ordered, really didn't do it for me.  The fish was very fresh and it easily won me over.  I won't say it was the best that I've had, but it definitely deserves the praise that it gets.  The hamachi was exceptional tonight and I decided to order 2nds.  My gracious host then informed me that he had Toro, which isn't even on the menu.  Having had the worst toro ever at Miyozen in Emeryville, I was looking for someplace to win me over with toro again.  Okina restored my love for toro once again.  Oh, and I did have 2nds of hamachi.  Total cost, $27.50 with TORO!  Next time...sashimi.  Great little not-quite-hole-in-the-wall sushi joint in the Richmond.
author: JeFF T.

description: tiny tiny little place but huge huge taste! i love sushi and though i've never been to japan, i feel like this is how it would be there. tiny little place with a limited menu but super fresh and super yummy. we went through all the nigiri on the menu. the idea of having a party there seems non-existent as there are only 6 spots at the sushi bar and maybe 6 spots at the tables. if i lived close enough i would get take out from here all the time as the prices are incredibly reasonable.
author: N T.

description: Love this place! I've been to Okina a few times and it's always great. Before my last visit, I've always been at a table, but definitely sit at the sushi bar if possible. We got the chef's special and kept getting more and more amazing nigiri until we were stuffed. At first look the menu may seem limited as it lacks many of the "specialty rolls" popular in other restaurants, but the freshness of the fish is the reason to come here.
author: Lindsey S.

description: great sushi in SF.  last week we went and they had the finest toro i've ever had , so fresh it almost moved in my mouth.  a true neighborhood spot.
author: Zoe J.

description: 4 stars for very attentive service. So friendly. But it's such a small setting, and I dunno if this was because of the time of night, but it was freakishly quiet. Like eating sushi in a church. I prefer my restaurant settings to be a bit more lively. Otherwise, good sushi, good staff, and a nice little neighborhood to hang around at after dinner.
author: Joseph R.

description: Fantastic! One of the best and most authentic places to have sushi in San Francisco. I am Japanese (first generation), and I wouldn't be surprised if I found a place like this in Japan. And inexpensive to boot. Ask the chef what's recommended. It's a small menu, but that's way better than having a large option of weird mutated things like 'caterpillar roles'.
author: Cat L.

description: We had a great dinner at Okina last night. The chef is an absolute sweetheart, the fish is very fresh, and you can't beat the price. We had reservations at the bar and ordered omakase. With the size of their selection which is somewhat limited I'd say we probably tried everything they had. I didn't have a bad bite the whole night. Our favorites were the Thai red snapper, the halibut and the anchovy nigiri (which I hadn't had before!). Unfortunately they were out of uni. I like though that they won't serve something they don't believe is quality - they only serve smoked salmon because they don't like the quality of fresh salmon available. Service was fast on getting us some fish straight off which I loved, some places you wait forever for your first items. For four people with drinks and enough sushi for four hungry folks to all be full, it was $120 including tip, which I thought was amazing. We usually pay at least that for 2 people. We'll definitely be back! One note - cash only. We were relieved to have cash on us.
author: Sarah R.

description: serene experience. almost meditative. go with a close friend or SO, and do not attempt to go with more than 4 people. fresh, friendly and intimate. some really top notch sake in their collection. the menu is simple but doesn't lack any of the flavors you might be craving for your sushi expereince.
author: Adrienne P.

description: Okina is good for value sushi. I like how they don't use salmon and instead use smoked salmon... not because i don't like salmon but rather because of the dangers of eating farmed salmon (which is most of the salmon you see in sushi places) as there are more contaminants in farmed salmon. I've never personally gotten sick fr/ salmon and actually I don't know anyone who has, but i think the toxins in it are bad for you. So it's good when a place actually recognizes the dangers and doesn't give it to you. I ordered the Chirashi and enjoyed it much as they provided the japanese radishes on top of the normal Chirashi toppings. For $10-11 for my Chirashi, I'm sure to be back. (It's not the best sushi i've had in SF, but its' definitely on the more affordable side.)
author: Jeannette L.

description: i love the sushi in there so much, especially the hamachi, tuna and hotategai !!! the sushi chef  is funny and humurous
author: STUSSY Dude E.

description: As Joy said, it's inconvenient, unadorned and delicious. Please don't go there, so that I can get a table.
author: Heather D.

description: Yep.  You do want to come here if you have a chance.  I am slightly biased because it is around the corner from my house but you will not be disappointed.  The space is very small, but cozy, good idea to make reservations if you can.  I saw that some people have complained that it is only open a few days a week, but the truth is that means you are getting a fresher product.  No fish keeps very long, but many restaurants will keep it till it goes bad.  That can't even be an issue here since they are only open 3 days a week as far as I know.  Everything I have had here is great, and it is a good idea to just let the master behind the sushi bar, or the waitress to just guide you, they know what it good for that day.  The people here treat you with the upmost sincerity and the food stands up to their service.  If you want some fresh, awesome sushi...look no further.  The only downside is there is no music, but I have found it is kinda nice because then you can just talk at a regular voice and hear your conversation.  It doesn't hurt the vibe much.
author: Timothy O.

description: The fish was so fresh and delicious. The menu was pretty small but we enjoyed our dinner. I hope they will expand their menu more. The service was pleasant and the sushi chef was nice.
author: Keromi K.

description:
$32 for sushi for 2. seriously? not that i am complaining.

excellent sushi. i love the radish, cucumber bit that comes with the wasabi and ginger. 

great service, unique space and experience. 

the only suggestion would be to dim the light. and, maybe have some warm   small dishes for the cold nights :)
author: Diana L.

description: I had very little expectations from looking at it from outside, didn't even see it.  But after trying, WOW its good!  The yellow tail tasted like toro.  The sushi chef was funny in a way, very kind.  I would recommend this to anyone
author: josh r.

description: Small, quiet dining setting, nice for a date if you feel like being patient. Minimalist rolls. Tasty and fresh.
author: A. T.

description: Very Good! a sushi master. Better than Masa's of New York!
author: Andy H.

description: The freshest fish.  Interior is austere, the chef is like a sushi monk.  When you enter you might feel that you are back in Japan for a moment because of the politeness.  Save it for a special occasion.
author: Nick M.

description: Not impressed at all...sure, its pretty cheap, but the quality was not that great. It seems most people found the sushi chef friendly, but I found him to be actually unfriendly and, quite honestly, rude. I won't be going back to this place; there are so many better sushi places to go to in the city.
author: Karen S.

description: Ate sushi at Okina recently after a 3 yr hiatus from the restaurant and found it not to be satisfying.  Went with a couple of friends and each of us gave that look of "something doesn't seem right" - the ordering process at the bar was inefficient (I finished all of my sushi before my friend ordered his) and the sushi taste was just ok.  With a menu so simple (compared to some of the other Geary street sushi bars with hundreds of rolls), the sushi should have been more satisfying in flavor and texture (my nori (seawood wrap) wasn't as fresh).  Well, we left quickly and unsatisfied (minus $20 each) and walked to another sushi place to eat.
author: Beau W.

description:
damn this place is hard to find...its so small and dark but now i know, its right next door to the market.

okina is a SMALL place...max capacity is 18 ppl (including the bar seats). and they're only open 3 days out of the week for dinner only...I was lucky enough to snag the last 2 un-reserved seats for the nite at 6:15pm, moments later 2 different couples came in & they were actually TURNED AWAY b/c they're "full" for the nite. so, if you want to check this place out...make reservations--i cant stress that enough & i went on a thurs. nite!!
the fish--do get the omakase, chef's choice. he'll make a few nigiris (i had 5 varieties) and plop them on the wooden slanted board at sushi bar. the sushi will be priced the same as on menu but he picks & chooses (pheew! good thing i asked b/c you know, "chefs choice" i dunno if thats gonna cost more or whatever). so, i had hamachi, hirame, tuna, and 2 other nigiris that i cant remember (damn short term memory)...all was really fresh & tasty. put in an order of uni too...YUMMY!!! but no ikura for the nite which i was super bummed about otherwise that would've completed my usual sushi meal.

the prices are very decent...all nigiris come in a pair, price range from tamago nigiri $2.50-uni $4.00 (most expensive on menu--but pretty cheap for their fresh quality). this place really is a gem...cant wait to go back for real sushi--yes, the raw stuff..none of those silly gargantuan rolls! my dining buddy & i had 8 different nigiris & a small sake, total w/tip & tax = $38

CASH ONLY!!

p.s. really sweet sushi chef & waitress..and true Japanese!!
author: Yolanda L.

description: sushi chef is very warm and talented, and really cool sushi bar setup.  also, fairly tucked away, so it wasn't crowded.  can eat a ton of quality on the relative cheap.
author: nelson s.
